Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will respect the wishes of the residents of the district and retain the classification of the Bute Post Office as an Official Office.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. I, Dr Paul Robert Neuman, Leader and Lord of Knights of the Order of the White Cross International, a humanitarian knighthood for the defence and protection of life, jointly with officers and members of the Order and with citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia by this our humble petition respectfully showeth:

That I, jointly with and on behalf of the undersigned petitioners voice our concern and objection about the proposed legislation of the so-called Plant Variety Rights Bill 1981 and that I claim, according to the nature and principles of my organisation, to have a mandate to defend the silent Millions of Life-forms which are unable to defend themselves and are not represented otherwise to protect their fate and future and also the majority of people, who are not or very little informed about the consequences of this Bill and whose freedom and wellbeing is at stake, should the Bill become Law in Australia.

Since time immemorial, life has dominated Earth and has formed in the course of evolution a Web of Life, composed of animals and plants which are depending on each other and are adjusted to each other within their Eco-system. Man, as part of nature and being bound to the laws of nature, must suffer the consequences if this nature is brought out of balance. The new life-forms, this Bill will allow to enter Australia, are tailor-made creations of genetic-engineers, aliens and monsters to our eco-system, but fit to open an entirely new marketing opportunity for food and chemicals. Scientific achievement or not, the Gene-manipulators play a wicked Leggo-game for international finance and the chemical industry. I hold, that the natural species in Australia or elsewhere in the world have not even the slightest chance to compete with the invaders from man's laboratories, since the new creations are invested with the power of money, using man's abilities, man's Laws and man's chemicals to clear the way for gene-manipulated commercial Mono-cultures, designed and controlled by those who hold the Patent Rights over these plants.

It requires no imagination to realize that all power for dominance over people is contained by those who control the food. Indeed, control over all beings bound to eat. Over farmers and horticulturists as to what to grow, how to grow and with which kind of chemical to treat. It also means control over licenced breeders of the new varieties, who may be directed to refuse supply to certain growers as the patent owners feel fit. Beneficiary of the entire exercise is the chemical industry which is eagerly buying up already such patents, thus the toxic pollution level in the environment must rapidly rise as a result of such policy. In the final analysis, I am convinced, that people in fear of famine due to possible repercussions, will to a great extent surrender their freedom and dignity to the will of those, who are in control of food. It has been voiced in various circles of Science and Philosophy that the potential of genetic engineering and cloning can be more devastating than the Nuclear-Bomb and I believe, a unification of gene-manipulation, cloning, computer-technology and international finance together can form a power able to result in a sort of Domesday for the world as we know it. It may be the beginning of a ''Brave New World'' similar to that, described in Huxley's novel, but whether mankind can survive it's own creations or vanish together with nature, remains a question mark.

When the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives deal with this Bill, they may also consider the religious aspects of the matter. Australians, being so close to nature, have naturally a strong attachment to the Creator. It is not unlikely that spiritual divisions may be enhanced amongst people over this ethical atrocity, indeed, the scientific take-over of creation is in a sense a dethronement of God as a control over all beings. I am awaiting in anticipation the protest of the World-Leaders of Religion to come to the defence of the Divine Creation, since they do so very often on the subjects of procreation and abortion and I pray, the very same Leaders will not 'side with the powerful' as they usually do. After all the foundation of Judeo-Christian Faith is at stake.

I am sure, the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House do share the pride of all Australians over the unique beauty of this continent and the natural composition of it's diverse life forms. Surely no-one of sound mind would wish to see this marvel of the Pacific Region being harmed and finely transformed into gene-manipulated mono-cultures, and yet this very Plant Variety Rights Bill 1981 is the door-opener for such a future. We believe, the driving forces behind this Bill did get away with far too much already in Australia. I refer here to the chemical pollution and the concerted efforts of that industry to increase the sale of toxic chemicals to the agricultural community. Many housewives nowadays fear the method of high pressure salesmen: ''Foot in the door and no retreat.'' Australia is well advised to keep her doors tightly closed to the salesmen of new life-forms.

We cannot undo the scientific 'success' of cloning and gene-engineering, but the people of Australia can refuse to legalize their own dependence upon the mercy of Multi-National Corporations. Such corporations generally do not break the Law openly, but rather lobby for the introduction of new laws, tailored to fit their future intentions. The present Bill, we believe, is a typical example of this kind and will give full cover of the Law to any foreign body or person as outlined in Division 2 Section 12 of the Bill and Division 1 Section 10 states unmistakably that virtually every plant of commercial interest falls under the Bill.

The promotes of gene-engineering may praise Interferon as a Wonderdrug, capable of eliminating cancer. We hold that from the very same corner of the industry once DDT was praised to be the Wonderchemical, capable of eliminating the insect-pest, but yet the insects have not suffered real losses in the long run, while the environment of the planet is cursed with a dreadful chemical which causes constant harm to nature now and in times to come and we believe, since the increase of cancer incidents appear in correlation with the increase of chemicals, it may be wise to reduce these chemicals rather than adding more to it, including substances derived from gene-manipulated matter.
I conclude, jointly with the undersigned petitioners that:
(1) The Plant Variety Rights Bill 1981 bears destructive consequences for the environment of Australia.
(2) Due to protective chemicals, required for this kind of plants, the toxic level in the environment must increase.
(3) The independence of people and the free trade is endangered.
(4) The Peace of Faith is likely to be disrupted.
(5) The beneficiaries of the Bill will primarily be Foreign Corporation.
Should this Bill become law.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that:
The Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia reject the Plant Variety Rights Bill 1981 entirely and in all parts.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Television Services in Remote Areas
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain residents of Tarcoola (electors of the Division of Grey) respectfully showeth our request for the reception of television.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that a Remote Areas Television Earth Station be installed, at the Government's earliest convenience, to enable the citizens of Tarcoola and surrounding areas to receive television via the Intelsat Satellite.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, because of the repudiation by the Minister for Transport of his undertaking to end the unfair bias against Western Australia in relation to domestic air fares, this House requires-
(i) the Minister to immediately reconvene the Holcroft Committee to enquire into the recent extortionate increase in air fares between Western Australia and the eastern States, and
(2) the Committee to rigorously apply the principles enunciated in its report to eliminate the high degree of cross subsidation which currently disadvantages travellers to and from Western Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move-

SPEECH.PARA: That this House, noting the report of the World Council of Churches on the condition of Aboriginals in Australia-
(1) supports Amnesty International in commencing preliminary investigations into instances of serious legal discrimination against Aborigines in Australia, and
(2) condemns-
(a) the racist policies of the Governments of Western Australia and Queensland, and

(b) the failure of the Commonwealth Government to use its (i) constitutional powers to override racist State policies particularly on land rights, and (ii) power to introduce effective anti-racial laws, proper health programs, better housing, improved education and employment opportunities for Aboriginal people.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Prime Minister. Has the Government decided on a huge increase in sales tax of more than $800m-an increase in fact of 39 per cent? Has the Government also decided to increase personal income tax collections by 22 per cent, which is the equivalent of $11 a week extra per taxpayer? Does the Prime Minister recall that the Government pledged in this House on 12 March that greater indirect taxation 'should be accompanied by a noticeable reduction in personal income tax'? Would he regard this as evidence of another solemn undertaking to the electorate being broken by the Fraser Government?

—I am very conscious of what the Government said to the House on 12 March of this year when it explained in a statement the reasons why it was not going to move to a broadly based indirect tax. The decisions that were announced last night represent no more than a modest broadening of the taxation base in a very limited area. Any suggestion that one can liken what was announced last night to the type of change that was in contemplation earlier this year, which included amongst other things the introduction of a retail turnover tax and also, as an alternative, the introduction of a broadly-based indirect tax including not only the major expansion of the wholesale tax base but also the introduction of a tax on services, is without foundation. I think the true way to measure the increase in indirect taxes in this Budget is to compare the rate of increase in indirect tax in the prospective financial year 1981-82 with what occurred in 1980-81. If the Leader of the Opposition does that, he will find that the differences in increase between the two years are minor indeed.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and relates to his attendance last week at the South Pacific Forum meeting in Vanuatu together with the attendance of the Deputy Prime Minister on behalf of Australia. Can the Foreign Minister explain to the House the nature of the course of action which the Forum decided on to assist in bringing about the independence in particular of French territories in the Pacific area? Can he give the House an indication of the nature of the support that Australia will be giving to such efforts, particularly bearing in mind the very positive statements which were made by the Deputy Prime Minister in Vila?

—I thank the honourable member for his question. As the House will know, the Australian Government's policy is that all people should be able, by free act of self-determination, to decide for themselves the form of government they want. That policy applies to the French territories in the Pacific to which the honourable gentleman referred. The issue was raised at the recent meeting of the South Pacific Forum and discussed at length. Interestingly, after this discussion the Forum decided by consensus, without any opposition, that a delegation led by the Prime Minister of Fiji should go to France and convey to President Mitterrand the concern of the Forum members that progress should be made towards the independence of the French territories in the Pacific. I think this is a sound, common-sense approach to what is a very difficult and sensitive issue, because it has to be remembered that in the case of New Caledonia, anyway, the Melanesian population is not in the majority. Therefore, the handling of the independence issue has to be approached with great care. The timing of the visit of the delegation to President Mitterrand has been left at the discretion of its leader, the Prime Minister of Fiji. The Australian Government, through my colleague the Deputy Prime Minister, gave strong support to this initiative. I hope that it will lead to movement on the part of the new French Government towards what we all regard as a desirable objective-that is, independence for the French territories in the Pacific.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Is it a fact that the Camp David Accords have brought the first real peace between the two major military powers in the Middle East after a period of 30 years and four wars? To enable a step by step process involved in solving the problems of the Sinai, the West Bank, Gaza and the Palestinian people to proceed, did the Camp David Accords and the Israeli-Egyptian peace treaty propose a United Nations peacekeeping force without super-power involvement being stationed in the Sinai Peninsula to facilitate a final Israeli withdrawal from that region? Has that proposal the support of both the Australian Government and the Opposition? What barriers exist to the raising of a United Nations peacekeeping force? What action is this Government taking to remove those barriers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that the Camp David Accords and the Egyptian-Israeli peace treaty have had a significant effect in reducing tensions in the Middle East. I understand that those Accords and that peace treaty had the unanimous support of all honourable members of this House, as the honourable gentleman suggested. It is a fact that peace now exists between Egypt and Israel, the two major antagonists in past Middle East conflicts, not that that has resolved all Middle East problems. The failure to solve the Palestinian issue and the present difficulties in Lebanon illustrate that only too clearly. It is true that, in an annex to the peace treaty, reference was made to the composition of a United Nations force, excluding the involvement of any permanent member of the Security Council. It was against the possibility that the United Nations may not be able to fulfil its role that the United States of America undertook, at the time of the signing of the peace treaty, to ensure the establishment and maintenance of an acceptable multinational force. Of course, it is this force that the Egyptian, Israeli and United States governments are presently endeavouring to form.

ANSWER.PARA: In my statement to the Parliament in May I expressed regret that for various reasons, including the prospect of a veto by the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, the President of the Security Council was unable to agree to United Nations involvement in the implementation of the peacekeeping arrangements in the Sinai. Accordingly, for the immediate future anyway, United Nations involvement is not an option.

Honourable members should be aware that, at a meeting with the Secretary-General of the United Nations in New York in July, I raised again the question of a United Nations force to be responsible for peacekeeping arrangements in the Sinai. Dr Waldheim confirmed the earlier advice that I had had from the President of the Security Council and he stated categorically that United Nations involvement was not an option unless and until the Soviet Union indicated that it would not use its veto against United Nations participation. In reply, I expressed to the Secretary-General the hope that the option of United Nations involvement at some future date could be kept open. I understand that the parties to the multinational force agreement also want to keep that option open for the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Transport whether reports are correct that Brisbane Airport is to be closed for three hours a day, beginning in September, because of a shortage of air traffic controllers. Will this also mean that air space over much of Queensland will be uncontrolled during this time? If so, what moves are being made to increase the numbers of air traffic controllers in Queensland and elsewhere to bring their numbers up to strength? Will the Department of Transport resort to importing air traffic controllers from overseas if numbers cannot be found in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The reports that the Brisbane Airport will be closed for short periods as from 10 September are correct. The actual periods of closure are yet to be determined. We are discussing with the airlines the period that is least likely to cause disruption to the travelling public. The partial closure of the Brisbane Airport is due to a very severe shortage of air traffic controllers in Australia. We are short of 110 air traffic controllers. We are training air traffic controllers to our maximum capacity. We have in hand plans to transfer some air traffic controllers to Brisbane in the near future, but that will not have any real effect on the situation until some time next year. We are also recruiting air traffic controllers overseas. We have had some success in our recruiting campaign in the United Kingdom and also in Hong Kong. We are, of course, looking to other areas to see whether it is possible to recruit a few more.

ANSWER.PARA: Quite clearly, there is a shortage of air traffic controllers and there has been a shortage for some time. There is a very high wastage rate among them because of the intensity of the work that they perform. It is not easy to recruit people who have the qualifications or the stamina necessary to carry out the task. We are most concerned about the problem and we are taking every measure possible to ensure minimum disruption to services to Queensland. We are taking every measure possible to recruit and to train additional air traffic controllers to overcome this immediate problem. I might add that I have also asked my Department to make sure in whatever arrangements it makes that there will be no closure of the facilities at Brisbane over the Christmas holiday period.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Health to an advertisement which has appeared over recent days concerning FAI Healthcare Insurance and featuring the Honourable Harry Jago who is identified as a former State Minister for Health. The advertisement says in part:

QUESTION.PARA: And remember, you may be entitled to additional tax deductions at 32 cents in the $1 on your total medical and hospital costs.

I ask the Minister whether that statement concerning possible tax benefits is correct. I also ask whether the statement attributed to Mr Harry Jago that 'FAI Healthcare Insurance gives you the best possible health cover available' is correct. Does FAI Healthcare Insurance come within the ambit of the National Health Act? If it does not, will the success of this insurance scheme in creaming off the low health-risk people and taking them away from the insurance schemes offered by the registered health funds increase the health costs of those people who are insured with registered health funds?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, my attention was drawn to the advertisement in a very broad sense. I have not read the fine detail contained in it. I have not seen the words quoted. The rebate of 32c in the dollar for basic health insurance is available only to those people who take out health insurance with a registered health insurance organisation. The FAI is not a registered health insurance organisation. So people taking out insurance with companies such as FAI will not be eligible for the tax rebate, as suggested in the honourable gentleman's question.

ANSWER.PARA: I have no comment to make about Mr Jago's participation. Nor do I have any comment to make about his alleged statement that FAI offers the best cover. I do not agree with that, but it demonstrates that the Government has in place a health scheme which offers to individuals within the community a range of choices which enables them to pick the form of health insurance which they believe is most suitable for their circumstances.

As to the last part of the honourable gentleman's question, I think that people who take out insurance with commercial organisations should look very carefully at the fine print in relation to the cover offered. All in all, I am not aware of any evidence that commercial insurers are taking a high proportion of individuals away from the registered health insurance organisations. Therefore, the community rating principle is very largely in place, as the Government intends. Finally, I advocate that all members of the general public look very carefully at the alternatives that are offered in health insurance. I advise them to think very carefully before they decide not to insure with a registered health insurance organisation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industrial Relations will recall that some time ago an announcement was made to the effect that steps were to be taken to deregister the Builders' Labourers Federation. Can the Minister tell the House the present status of that proposed application?

—A great deal of work has gone into the preparation of the case to be lodged with the Federal Court to apply for the deregistration of the Builders' Labourers Federation. That work is very well advanced and I expect to be in a position to advise the House next week when the application has been lodged.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Mr B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Prime Minister's attention been drawn to the words of the Governor-General, Sir Zelman Cowen, in the publication 'Technological Change-Impact of Information Technology 1981'? He stated:

QUESTION.PARA: Information processing equipment . . . could well become Australia's largest [import] in the decade of the 1980s unless concrete steps are taken very soon . . . Australia is rapidly becoming totally dependent on imports for the supply of its information technology . . . This directs attention to the vulnerability of a computerised society. What if sources of supply are threatened in international crises . . . [and] by vulnerability to acts of terrorism?

I ask: Does the Prime Minister agree with the Governor-General's remarks? Is he aware that Australia's capacity to create its own information technology, both hardware and software, was destroyed on the basis of a political decision by the Menzies Government in the 1950s? If so, what has the Government done or does it propose to do to overcome Australia's dangerous overdependence on foreign owned and controlled information technology? Will the Government as a matter of urgency take steps to encourage the development of Australian research and manufacturing capacity in information technology?

TALK.START.PARA: —I would not want to comment on any remarks that the Governor-General might have made, but the Government obviously is concerned for the implications of modern technology in the Australian economy. We established an examination under Professor Rupert Myers for that particular purpose.
—But not on this subject.

—On the broad subject of technological change, yes. We have made a number of decisions as a result of that report. If there is any particular information that I can give the honourable gentleman in relation to the particular aspect of the subject which he--
—You have missed the whole point.

—No, I have not missed the whole point. If there is any particular information I can give the honourable gentleman on the particular aspect that he has raised, I will be in touch with him again later.
—On a point of order, Mr Speaker: The point that I was making--
—The honourable gentleman is not making a point of order. He is repeating his--
—You have not heard me.
—He is repeating his question. The honourable gentleman will resume his seat.
—Will you hear me on the point of order?
—I call the honourable member for Calare.
—Mr Speaker, on the point of order: Am I not entitled to raise a point of order and are you not prepared to do me the courtesy of listening to what that point of order is before you make a decision?
—The honourable gentleman will resume his seat.
—Will you hear my point of order?
—The honourable gentleman will resume his seat.
—Will you hear my point of order?

—The honourable gentleman will resume his seat. If he does not do so, I will have to deal with him. The honourable gentleman said that he raised a point of order. I allowed him to raise it. His opening words were 'The point I was making' in relation to his question. Obviously what he was going to do was to complain that he did not get the answer he wanted. There is no point of order.
—Mr Speaker, with respect--
—Is this a point of order?
—Yes, it is.
—I call the Leader of the Opposition.

—I suggest that for the proper harmony of the House it would be better to listen to at least some of the substance of the point of order before determining your attitude. Otherwise we are going to have disharmony quite unnecessarily in the House. The honourable member has not made his point of order. You may be anticipating completely incorrectly. I ask you whether you would be generous enough to reconsider it in the circumstances. This honourable member is not the sort of person who takes vexatious points of order, I think you will recall.
—As a matter of courtesy to the Leader of the Opposition and at his request, I will allow the honourable member for Lalor to make the point of order.
—Mr Speaker, my point of order was that the question raised with the Prime Minister was the question of the vulnerability--
—Order! The honourable gentleman will resume his seat. There is no point of order.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Transport. What progress has been made towards the expansion of runway facilities at Mascot Airport after some four years or perhaps five years of inquiry? Has the New South Wales Premier yet made any decision on this matter? Will restrictions on commuter aircraft and perhaps on intrastate aircraft services have to be brought in soon, unless a decision is made? Is there any truth in the suggestion I have heard only recently that Brisbane may soon take over from Sydney as Australia's international gateway?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, we have received a reply from the Premier of New South Wales. Mr Wran has replied to a letter from the Prime Minister, making it quite clear that the New South Wales Government is not prepared to co-operate with the Commonwealth in the development of a close-spaced parallel runway at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. In fact what he has done is to turn his back on the people of Sydney and the people of New South Wales. As far as the major airport needs of Sydney--
—So did Willis and so did Lewis.
—Well, you said that. Does that make his--
—The Minister will resume his seat. The honourable member for Newcastle will cease interjecting. The Minister will cease taking notice of interjections and will continue with his answer.

—The truth of the matter is, of course, that Mr Willis agreed to it. Mr Wran agreed five years ago to co-operate with the Commonwealth in setting up a major airport needs study committee involving both Commonwealth and State officials. But in December 1979 the New South Wales Government decided to withdraw its officials, leaving the Commonwealth officials to make a report. The Commonwealth has agreed to the recommendation for a close-spaced parallel runway to meet the immediate needs of those people wishing to use Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. They happen to represent 60 per cent of the travelling public in this country. It has been Australia's No. 1 international and domestic airport, but it will rapidly decline from that position day by day as a result of this inactivity on the part of the New South Wales Government.

ANSWER.PARA: There is not the slightest doubt that there will be restrictions on the traffic using Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. I have made it clear to my Department that I will not stand by and see regional aviation, general aviation or commuter services singled out for those restrictions. If there are to be restrictions at Kingsford-Smith Airport they will apply to international, domestic, regional, commuter and general aviation alike. Let no one bask in any complacency that the restrictions are going to hurt just one section of the community. They will apply right across the board. Mr Wran can carry the blame for that with him throughout the forthcoming election campaign.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Treasurer. Is it the case that the Budget strategy presupposes a level of private capital inflow this year of $7 billion or more, which is an even greater amount than the record and extraordinary $6.5 billion inflow of last year? In view of the fact that the surplus of this private capital inflow over the deficit on the balance of payments current account adds to the money supply and this year, as last year, is expected to account for some 45 per cent of money supply growth, did the Government, in drawing up its Budget strategy, give any consideration to reducing the rate of growth of the money supply by controlling private capital inflow rather than increasing taxes on the Australian people? If that course was considered, why was it not adopted?

—It is true that the Budget is based upon an assumption that the rate of private capital inflow will be between $6,000m and $7,000m and will make a contribution to private sector foreign exchange transactions of about the same level as occurred last year. The honourable gentleman's question, like other questions from the Opposition on the subject of private capital inflow, assumes that one can turn the tap of foreign investment in this country on and off without damage to the long term level and pattern of that investment. It is necessary, if the development of this country is to proceed, for us to have foreign capital. There are simply inadequate reserves of domestic savings to support the sort of investment that is going on in Australia at present. When the honourable member for Gellibrand and the Leader of the Opposition talk about controls and blockages on private capital inflow, they are advocating a slower rate of growth, because there is an insufficient volume of domestic savings in this country to support the current levels of investment. If the Opposition argues for less investment in Australia at present, it is arguing for lower living standards, higher unemployment and less growth.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: BEEF SHIPMENTS TO THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Primary Industry any new information regarding investigations into the substitution of horsemeat in export boneless beef shipments to the United States of America?

—I confirm that investigations have concluded that horsemeat is contained in the samples of the 1,200 cartons seized from the Profreeze meat company at Richmond. The Australian Federal Police is investigating the matter to see what further samples are available. Only some of the 1,200 cartons seized so far have been tested. It can be assumed that there is what I would like to call some racket going on in the meat trade. The Government is treating the matter very seriously.
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I draw your attention to Question on Notice No. 2760.

—The question on notice asked by the honourable member for Lilley is very broad. I would not wish to allow a broad question of that nature to prevent the seeking of information about a matter of major national importance on a confined basis which relates, as I understand it, to the seizure of certain shipments and the testing of them.
—I accept that, Mr Speaker, as it is of national importance.

—The matter is presently before the Bureau of Animal Health and the Federal Police, which are investigating it. The only other point to add is that I hope to bring into the House within the next couple of weeks of this session a Bill to increase markedly the fines that are presently applicable in instances of this nature. At the moment the maximum fine is a mere $1,000.

—I ask the Treasurer a question supplementary to the question which has just been asked of him by the honourable member for Gellibrand. The Treasurer will recall in his answer confirming that the Government is anticipating an even larger foreign capital inflow this year than last year; it will be in excess of $6,000m and possibly as high as $7,000m. Does he recognise that the implication is that the Government must also anticipate an appreciation in the Australian dollar during this fiscal year at least as large as the 10 per cent general appreciation that took place last year and in particular cases rising much higher, as high as 38 per cent against West Germany? Does he recognise that the effect of appreciations, especially such significant appreciations, is to disadvantage the traditional farm and manufacturing export industries and manufacturing import replacement industries? Finally, does he recognise that an appreciation of this level, on top of the appreciations which have already taken place in the preceding 12 months, would effectively wipe out protection for the majority of Australian manufacturing industry?

—I will pick up the last part of the honourable gentleman's question and correct him immediately. The highest levels of protection for a large part of Australian manufacturing industry are in respect of those industries that enjoy quotas. Exchange rate appreciation, far from reducing protection for those industries, in fact increases it to a massive degree. The really high levels of protection in Australia are in respect of the industries that are subject to quotas. I refer, of course, to the textile, clothing and footwear industries, the motor vehicle industry and a number of other industries. Any suggestion in those circumstances that exchange rate appreciation lessens the protection to those industries is diametrically opposite to what precisely happens. It is true that the private capital inflow is likely to be of about the same order as last year; but, of course, the current account deficit is projected to be somewhat larger and, as a consequence, the net monetary effect of that private capital inflow is likely to be about the same. I will not make forward speculations about how the Australian dollar will move. Its value compared with other currencies, including the American dollar and the Deutsche mark, is affected not only by what happens to our currencies and to the Australian economy but also obviously by what happens in domestic conditions in both of those economies. I can only repeat what I have said to the honourable gentleman on many occasions: Anti-inflationary objectives will remain dominant in the determination of our exchange rate policies.

—I inform the House that we have present in the gallery this afternoon members of the Nigerian Parliament's Committee on Federal Capital Development, led by Senator Alhaji Rufair, Chairman of the Committee. On behalf of the House, I extend a very warm welcome to the members of the Committee.

—I rephrase in everyman's language the question directed by the honourable member for Lalor to the Prime Minister. Is he aware that, in the 12 months ending 30 June 1981, the value of computer equipment imported by Australia rocketed to $587m? Is he aware that for 11 months in 1980-81, compared with a similar 11 months in 1979-80, the value of computer equipment imported by Telecom Australia rose from $380m to $502m? Do figures such as these have an effect on our balance of payments situation? Does the Prime Minister regard the warnings that there will be greater import reliance in this field as such as to motivate the Government to pay special attention to increasing Australia's ability to produce computer equipment?

—One of the reasons for the growth in Telecom orders would no doubt be the growth in demand for telecommunications services. The capital program for Telecom has been very large over recent years. It will be very large. Even so, in some areas there are still delays in providing services. I have no doubt that the increase in imports on behalf of Telecom would be in part at least as a result of the very great demand for the services that it provides and the increasing range of services that are open and available to businesses.
—But proportionately we are worse off than anybody else. That is the point.
—Order! The honourable member for Lalor will remain silent.

—The honourable gentleman also needs to understand that this economy has been growing quite strongly by comparison with other advanced Western countries, many of which are not growing at all. Some are even stagnating or shrinking in terms of their product. As a result of that, it would be natural to find an increase in imports over a wide range of areas. I suggest that, if the honourable member for Fadden believes that there is too much reliance on imports in any particular area, he take the matter up with my colleague the Minister for Industry and Commerce.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Industry and Commerce and refer to the automotive complementation scheme which relates to exports. Is the Minister aware that this scheme is coming into some disarray because of the allegations certainly made by the automotive parts manufacturers that there is manipulation of the scheme by transfer pricing in respect of exports and imports? Is he further aware, in the detail of that, that the Borg Warner factory at Wodonga is in danger of closing because the transmissions will not now be sourced from that particular factory and further that the complex skills of die casting, particularly in New South Wales, are about to be extinguished? Accordingly, as the whole of the automotive component industry is in danger of collapsing, I ask: What proposals does the Minister have in mind to guarantee that we retain those skills in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Lynch The Rt Hon Sir P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable gentleman for the question relating to the automotive industry. He will, of course, be aware that Cabinet will shortly have before it the recommendations from the Industries Assistance Commission, together with the work which has been undertaken in recent times by the various departments which are involved in the Standing Committee on Industries Assistance. I anticipate that the Government will approach its early discussions on the automotive reference some time in September.

ANSWER.PARA: So far as export complementation is concerned, the honourable gentleman would certainly understand that I have never hidden the fact that export complementation to the components industry is a matter of gainers and losers. It has been designed to provide Australian industry with the capacity to move technologically with the world industry. I believe it has produced very significant dividends to the industry to this point, but at the same time I recognise that inherent in what the honourable gentleman is saying is that some companies have been disadvantaged by virtue of the additional overseas sourcing which has been provided both to automotive manufacturers and to some specialist component manufacturers. The question of transfer pricing is a matter for the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs. I will have the matters that the honourable gentleman referred to assessed through my colleague the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs and provide him with what information is available.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Prime Minister aware of an article which appeared in the Hobart Mercury dated 1 August 1981 and which in essence refers to the role that the Premier of Tasmania played in the recent Transport Workers Union of Australia strike? My question is a direct one: What role did the Premier play in solving the TWU strike?

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. It is not within the ambit of a Minister of this Government to determine what role the Premier of a State plays, nor is it within the responsibilities of the Prime Minister's portfolio. The question asks for an expression of opinion, which is contrary to the Standing Orders.

—The point of order is not sustained. The Prime Minister was engaged in discussions with people about settling a dispute. As I understand the question, it involved the Premier of Tasmania and discussions with the Prime Minister. Therefore the question is in order.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me relate to the House some of the events that occurred over that weekend and during that period. There had been discussions before the weekend involving the Deputy Prime Minister, myself, the Minister for Industrial Relations and, I think, one or two others and the Australian Council of Trade Unions because of a serious situation which was developing in relation to not only the Transport Workers Union but also certain matters which looked as though they could involve a total national stoppage on the Australian waterfront. For that reason-I have paid due regard to this-the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions approached me and said: 'Will the Government participate in talks in an effort to see what can be done to resolve some of these difficulties?' As a result of that, a statement was issued by the Government and the ACTU. Sir John Moore also was present at those discussions on the Friday, I think it was. It was basically a sensible statement but one which also recognised that the rigidity of the indexation guidelines was making some trade unions feel that they were not able to have their cases heard and argued before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. A form of words which had the support of the ACTU and the Government and which might have relieved some of that pressure was placed in that statement.

ANSWER.PARA: In the event, there was an attempt based on that document to get the Transport Workers Union to go back to arbitration. The ACTU was significantly involved in that. Other Premiers were also involved. States of emergency, we need to remember, had been declared in more than one State, and Premiers were in touch with me concerning the severity of the dispute-whether it was likely to become a full national stoppage or what might be done to relieve the matter. The Minister for Communications also was involved because he had been having discussions over the same weekend with the Minister for Industrial Relations on disputes in relation to Telecom Australia. Therefore he was involved with me and the Minister for Industrial Relations in the discussions that took place over that weekend and on the Monday. Part of the problem was to get the Transport Workers Union to accept arbitration. There was a belief that it ought to. There was a prospect at the time that its problem might be resolved through an anomalies conference, even though I think Deputy President Isaac had indicated that the Commission could not make a judgment of the kind that the union had wanted.

In the process of persuading the Transport Workers Union to accept arbitration, Mr Wran was in Melbourne because of a certain Australian Labor Party meeting of which some honourable gentlemen here would be aware. I think he undertook through the New South Wales Trades and Labour Council to see what influence could be exerted on the TWU. Either the Minister for Communications or the Minister for Industrial Relations rang around other States again to try to establish the circumstance where some influence could be brought to bear on the Transport Workers Union to accept arbitration. In the process of that, through my colleague the Minister for Administrative Services, an approach was initially made to Mr Lowe. After that I discussed the matter with Mr Lowe. He indicated a wish to help because Tasmania was being--

TALK.START.PARA: —Is this a sunset answer?

—I think it probably will be. I thank the honourable gentleman for reminding me of the time. Tasmania had been very severely hurt by the Transport Workers Union dispute, in many cases more severely hurt than other States. I have to say that, up to the point at which my colleague the Minister for Administrative Services had approached the Premier, it appeared that the State was not doing a great deal to assist itself. I should also say that in my conversation I pointed out to Mr Lowe that other Premiers were doing a good deal to protect the interests of their States. He said in that conversation that obviously he wanted to do what he could to protect Tasmania. The action seemed to be in Melbourne and I offered to make transport available to him to come to Melbourne, again with the objective of getting the Transport Workers Union before arbitration. I think that is a quiet and accurate description of events.

ANSWER.PARA: I would like to make one other point only, and that is that nobody who was involved in these matters and nobody in any of the discussions that the Government has had with the Australian Council of Trade Unions over recent months has sought to make any political capital out of the attempts that people from different spheres have been making to solve difficult problems and problems which concern many Australians. I think senior officers of the ACTU, and the Government certainly, recognise that the level of industrial disputation is not really in anyone's interests. It is certainly in the interests of all Australia to overcome that effort as much as humanly possible and to establish a better industrial environment. I think it is a great pity that that particular article ever appeared in the Hobart Mercury, because it was not in accord with the spirit of what had been taking place over the weekend. Since the Opposition does not want any further questions I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Government's imposition of increasing hardship on first home buyers, existing home buyers and people renting homes, resulting from rising interest rates, declining availability of housing finance and cutbacks in public housing expenditure.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Next to unemployment, housing is the most serious social problem in this country. This Government has deliberately sacrificed both private and public housing for foreign control of unplanned and unco-ordinated resource development in this country. I want to deal with some of the social problems arising out of this Government's economic policy. Last weekend the Sydney Morning Herald reported the plight of a young couple living in Sydney's outer western suburb of Penrith. The family was forced to put its home up for sale because it could no longer afford its mortgage repayments. According to a real estate agent in the area, about 100 homes are for sale in the Penrith area, but rising interest rates and restrictions on the availability of housing finance meant that few people could afford to buy those homes. As a result, while the total repayment debt for existing home buyers went up by around $20,000 in the past 18 months for a home loan of $30,000, the selling prices had moved down on houses and land in this area.

SPEECH.PARA: Not very long ago a young couple could buy a modest home on the periphery of the Sydney metropolitan area, delay having children, both go to work, save and scrape and forgo other needs in order to get their foot on the bottom of the home ownership ladder. They would borrow to the limit of their means and trust that they could get themselves to a position where they could improve their living standards with the security of having their own roof over their heads. Alternatively, they would consider selling their first home and use the capital gain to buy another home better suited to their needs. But this young couple in Penrith had that avenue closed to them. They faced the prospect of little, if any, capital gain and possibly a loss. They faced insecurity and the prospect of increasing hardship resulting from a continual erosion of their household disposable income. So they decided to put the home up for sale. They intended to buy a caravan. For them, buying their first home was a move that put them on the path of downward mobility. Yet these people were lucky enough in the first place to get access to home ownership.

There are many who are even worse off. The Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr McVeigh) admits that he has no idea of the number of homeless people in Australia. He can neither confirm not deny the estimates of the welfare groups that there are about 150,000 homeless people throughout this country-young, unemployed, elderly, deserted people-people who have been dispossessed as a result of the callous policies of this Government. The Minister can neither confirm nor deny that there are about 250,000 people across Australia excluding Aboriginal people who suffer an outrageous neglect of their housing needs, who are living in mobile, temporary or makeshift accommodation. The Minister cannot tell this Parliament how many people spend their nights in the back seats of cars, in parks or in alleys. He cannot tell us the extent of overcrowding in sub-standard, overpriced rental accommodation. The Minister does not know these details. The Government does not really care and it cannot possibly develop appropriate housing policies when it cannot understand the housing problems. It is prepared to sacrifice the housing sector to make room for corporate investment and foreign speculation.

In July this year, before the last round of interest rate rises, the Sunday Telegraph reported a survey conducted by the social workers in the western suburbs of Sydney. This report linked the stress of loan repayments with child abuse, drug-taking, mental illness and abortion. The survey revealed a trail of broken marriages and shattered dreams for hundreds of married couples. The men were working full time with as much overtime as they could get. In many cases they even had a second job. The women were going out to work, often at night. The survey found that despite both partners working they were incapable of keeping up with rising costs-whether in the form of higher loan repayments for those paying off their homes or the widening deposit gap for those seeking to buy their first home. The survey also found that this pattern of scraping for funds put pressure on the marriage and on the family, particularly the children. I have quoted from two newspaper reports and I commend the sensitivity of the journalists involved. Why do we not have government publications detailing such facts so that government can make a decision arising from these findings? The Government seems unwilling seriously to examine the impact of its policies on people.

The rate of interest is only one aspect of the effect of rising housing costs on household disposable income. But that effect is made more acute in a context of employment insecurity, partial wage indexation, casualisation of work, cutbacks in social services, rising petrol prices, increased health care costs, rises in charges for public services and increasing indirect taxes. The combined impact of these Government policies hits people, particularly little people, hard. This is part of the policies of this callous Government.

Since February 1980 the home loan interest rate from savings banks has increased from 9.5 per cent to 12.5 per cent. For the average mortgage of $30,000 this has meant an increase in repayments over the last 18 months of $65 a month. Over the same period, average earnings of wage and salary earners have increased by only $30.50 a month. Real household disposable income has been eroded by this Government's redistributive measures. Around 80 per cent of income recipients in Australia get less than average weekly earnings. House and land prices have been increasing in most capital cities, especially in Sydney and Melbourne, beyond the reach of the average income household. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table setting out the quarterly average of monthly median prices for houses and home units in Sydney and Melbourne for the period June 1965 to December 1980.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. In the December quarter 1975 the median house price in Sydney was $33,500. Average earnings were $167 a week. At that time the value of a home was 200 weeks of average earnings. In the December quarter of 1980 the median price of a house was $78,700 and average earnings were $278. The value of the house was then 283 weeks of average earnings. Since that period the median price of a house has moved to around $84,000 and interest rates have gone up still further. In my view interest rates on housing have not peaked yet and they will rise still further. Several effects of these changes need to be understood. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard several tables showing the changes in monthly repayments of different loan sizes at varying interest rates and the deposit gaps for home buyers on average weekly earnings for different house prices and home loan interest rates.
