Professor Hakim was in no sense a political dissident and one is even more concerned at the loss to the world of this eminent humanitarian and gravely disturbed to learn that his property was confiscated by the Islamic Republic on January 14, two days after he was murdered, despite legal protests, and that his family is without the protection of Iranian law.

The Federation of Protestant Churches in Switzerland, through its Human Rights Commission has declared its belief that the new constitution of Iran should include protection for all religious minorities so that Professor Hakim's family and fellow Baha'is may enjoy religious freedom.
Before I conclude I want to return for just a moment to the question of the Zoroastrians. A letter that appeared in the New York Times on 21 January 1979 pointed out:

Over the past millenium, most Zoroastrians have fled to India, where they live in freedom and safety; these have come to be known as Parsis. The Parsis have distinguished themselves in commerce, science and the arts (Zubin Mehta, conductor of the New York Philharmonic, will be well-known to your readers). But some 27,000 Zoroastrians remain in Iran, mainly in Teheran and in the Yazd area.

That is considerably less than the number of Baha'is. The twentieth century has been the most appalling era in terms of religious and tribal persecution. The elimination of six million Jews in Europe in World War II stands out, but there are very many other horrific examples in other continents. The Ayatollah Khomeini presides over one of the most unattractive regimes in the world today with strong elements of obscurantism and cruelty. In the Iranian Bulletins, the news bulletins of the Committee for Defence of Political Prisoners in Iran, published by Index on Censorship in London in 1979 there is an introductory comment by the writer, Edward Mortimer, which says:

. . . the future of human rights in Iran is far from being assured, and it is still possible that the revolution will in the end produce a new dictatorship no less savage than that of Mohammed Reza Pahlavi. It would not be the first revolution in the world to follow such a cycle. What would be wrong would be to attribute any such tendency to the Islamic and or anti-Western character of the revolution and the regime that is emerging from it . . . It is hardly surprising if they suspect the good faith of criticisms of their new rulers emanating from the West in the name of freedom or human rights . . . Even those of us in the West who did speak out against the Pahlavi dictatorship in the days of its strength have to admit that we were quite unsuccessful in changing the policies of our own governments towards it.

I point out that the Baha'i faith has not emanated from the West. It is not something imposed historically. It is something that has arisen out of the Iranian tradition, out of Iranian history. This persecution is a black mark against the record of the current Iranian Government. Why are we in the Australian Parliament raising the question of the Baha'is, people who are mistreated in a distant country? The reason, of course, is that we recognise our common interest-we are all part of the human race. Before I close I should mention that the honourable member for Hawker (Mr Jacobi) was very anxious that I should indicate his very strong support for the motion. He has had many representations on this issue. The matter was raised-the honourable member for Mackellar should be congratulated for doing so-because of the common bond, membership of the human race.

TALK.START.PARA: —They opposed the human rights standing committee in the Parliament. They opposed that when they had the chance. That is to be deplored.
—That is to be deplored, but there will be a unanimous resolution here today. I close with the famous words of John Donne, the great metaphysical poet, which express the feeling we all have:

SPEECH.PARA: No man is an island, entire of itself; every man is a piece of the continent, a part of the main; if a clod be washed away by the sea, Europe is the less, as well as if a promontory were, as well as if a manor of thy friends or of thine own were; any man's death diminishes me, because I am involved in mankind; and therefore never send to know for whom the bell tolls; it tolls for thee
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES: PROPOSED PROCEDURES COMMITTEE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That a standing committee be appointed to maintain a continuing surveillance of the practices and procedures of the House of Representatives with a view to making recommendations which would enhance the role of the House and its operational efficiency.
(2) That the committee consist of four Government Members and four Opposition Members to be appointed by Mr Speaker after consultation with the Party Whips.
(3) That Mr Speaker also appoint a Chairman of the Committee who shall have a casting vote only.
(4) That any additional terms of appointment of the committee be the subject of a subsequent resolution of the House.

The motion which I have moved arises out of a select committee of this Parliament which met some years ago to examine the procedures of the Parliament and to make recommendations in respect of a committee system for the Parliament. That committee was the Procedures Committee of the House of Representatives. The purpose of the committee I am seeking to set up is to provide the means by which the House itself can review its own procedures, can make recommendations or can have recommendations on changes in procedures brought before the House to enhance and improve the efficiency of the House and the role that the House plays in the government of the country. Unfortunately, in recent times the Standing Orders have ceased to be the prerogative of this chamber. That prerogative has been transferred outside this chamber, largely to a committee of Government back bench members and the Executive. That is not the manner in which the Standing Orders were handled when you and I, Mr Deputy Speaker, came to this Parliament. At that time they were dealt with on their merit by members of this chamber voting without party whip. So whilst the Standing Orders were not all that we would have liked, and certainly advantaged the Executive to an extent which is probably beyond the wishes of most back benchers, they were approved in free vote by members of this House at the time they were put forward.

In recent times the procedures by which changes to the Standing Orders have taken place have almost always consisted of an Executive resolution and a subsequent reference to the Standing Orders Committee after a long term of practice based on the change. Whilst one does not deny the input of the Executive into the chamber, it is highly desirable that a house of parliament should reserve unto itself the right to consider its own procedures and to bring forward wherever possible recommendations which would amend those procedures in such a way as to make them more effective for the house of parliament to carry out its function.

It can be argued, and I have no doubt that it will be argued, that there is a Standing Orders Committee. The House of Commons also has a standing orders committee and has found that it is not a satisfactory vehicle for examining ongoing matters relating to procedures or new procedures which may be desirable for a parliament to fulfil its role in a society which is ever more demanding on members of parliament and the government of the day. Clearly, in the Westminster system, the parliament has more than one role. First of all, it has a responsibility to facilitate the government of the country by enacting and dealing with legislation in a manner which does not unduly inhibit good government. It should seriously inhibit bad government. This chamber has allowed to pass from its control the procedures by which it operates. I do not deny that resolutions are carried by a majority of members, but on almost all occasions now when Standing Orders matters are dealt with, they are carried by a majority of members after party decision and on party lines, and rarely with any adequate consultation with the Opposition. Usually it is a take-it-or-leave-it proposition.

The Standing Orders Committee, as I have already mentioned, does exist. It recommends the form in which new procedures should be written into the Standing Orders of the House. It is not a committee which has a capacity or could have a capacity for ongoing consideration of changes or for examination of the manner in which this chamber operates as a house of parliament. The Standing Orders Committee is cumbersome. Its personnel alone prevent it from meeting regularly or from carrying out any investigation other than a cursory one. It has one advantage. Because of its personnel, those things to which it agrees are usually able to be presented to this Parliament almost as a fait accompli, although some of its recommendations have not been adopted in the past, and unfortunately a number of reports of that Committee have never been listed for consideration in this chamber.

Quite seriously, a procedures committee would give us the flexibility that is necessary to examine our procedures. One would hope that the members of such a committee would be experienced in the operations of parliament and would recognise the various roles that this chamber has to carry out. It would give this chamber the opportunity for self-examination of its procedures on a continuing basis. Clearly, recommendations would come back to this House and the House would determine whether or not those recommendations were to be proceeded with. If they were to become part of the Standing Orders or the regular procedures of this House, one would expect that the Standing Orders Committee would ultimately draft and present the necessary Standing Orders.

Procedures committees operate successfully in other parliaments, and are a far more flexible and a better vehicle than the Standing Orders Committee. We have no means now by which we can bring about a review of our procedures on any specific matter. An honourable member may list for debate in this chamber a resolution of the Standing Orders Committee but the chances of it actually being debated are almost nil. Certainly there is no vehicle by which such a matter can be seriously considered by members of this chamber or alternatives which can be considered to meet any given situation.

We are not seeking in this motion to bring about a decision-making function, but merely to bring about a facility which would enable this House to examine itself and to report upon itself to its members for their determination on how its procedures should be conducted. We have had many changes in recent years, some good and some bad, but none of which would not have been better had it been the subject of substantive consideration on the best means by which the Parliament could conduct certain items of business, and none of which would not have been better had it not received the unanimous recommendations of this House. For instance, in recent years we have had the introduction of Estimates committees. When I say that they are a farce, I think that I reflect the majority view of the Opposition and the majority view of members who have participated on those committees. They have been set up without any substantive consideration of what their role is, other than to take the debate out of this chamber, which seems to be the only role they perform, how they are to be conducted, the nature of their business and what time should be allocated to the conduct of that business.

I think that members of this chamber, meeting as a smaller committee, giving consideration to a need on occasions to conduct outside this chamber business which normally would be conducted in this chamber, in order to permit there being greater time for the major debates which should take place in this chamber but do not, would have come down with a more workable proposition than the one we are faced with. We have legislation committees which I think are of doubtful validity as regards functioning effectively as part of the operations of this chamber. Agreements have been made, and they have been broken.

I believe that in future this Parliament will have to devise a means whereby matters not considered to be of major consequence and therefore able to be debated outside this chamber, can be debated outside this chamber, and whereby the procedures for doing that should if possible-it is possible-be devised by members of this Parliament meeting to determine procedures that will bring about the best possible resolution of the problem that faces this chamber. The business which now goes through this chamber and has gone through it for the last six or seven years, is probably 10 times as great as that which went through this chamber 20 years ago, when some of us were not here. Nevertheless, it is undertaken in a time frame which is almost exactly the same. It is probably 50 times as great as that which took place in the immediate post-war years. For instance, the conciliation and arbitration legislation of 1947 was debated in this chamber for four weeks. Other Bills have been before this chamber for longer periods. Now such legislation takes two hours to consider, sometimes even three.

There are no means, and there have been no examinations of the procedures whereby substantive and important legislation can be adequately considered by the Parliament without necessarily being considered on the floor of this chamber. The Senate debated the Freedom of Information Bill, which is presently listed on our Notice Paper, for almost a year, and the Bill was before the Senate for longer than that. A similar situation occurred with the marriage Bills which were before this chamber not that long ago-in 1974-75. The debate and consideration in the Senate was 10 times as long as that which took place in this chamber.

In these instances our procedures are not conducive to proper examination of matters which are important to honourable members and to the country. We are supposedly the chamber which is responsible for the financial affairs of the country. We have no procedures for examination of the financial statements or the financial considerations which come before this chamber. This Committee would not, in any way, jeopardise the Goverment's control of the Parliament or its ability to run the Parliament. It would not jeopardise or reduce the standing of the Standing Orders Committee or its members. It would enable a continuing debate and examination of the methods by which this chamber does its business. It would enable new ideas to be examined in detail and tested and either put forward to the Parliament as suggestions for change or rejected. Majority views of honourable members from both sides of the Parliament would be reflected in that Committee.

We are confronted with a situation where we can maintain a stubborn insistence on a committee which cannot carry out the functions of considering changes which may be necessary, we can adopt procedures whereby examination by this chamber as reflected in a committee can take place or we can take the third alternative which, unfortunately, is the current position where the party empowered determines, on party lines, the procedures and Standing Orders of this chamber. This is an unfortunate departure from what was a very satisfactory arrangement at an earlier time. The Standing Orders, considerations and matters of actual conduct of this chamber which rested with individual members-I fancy that they still do in the Senate-have been transferred largely to an executive and party function. That has occurred, especially in the party sense, because of a vacuum which exists in the ability of this chamber to conduct its business. There is no facility for someone who wants to make an input into consideration of change. We have party back bench committees examining the change where really the Parliament itself should be looking at that change.

This motion arises from a unanimous decision of a parliamentary committee which reported to both Houses in 1976. At that time it was chaired by the former President of the Senate, Sir Magnus Cormack. It had previously been chaired in its initial stages by myself and subsequently by the honourable member for Scullin (Dr Jenkins). All of the honourable members of the committee supported this recommendation. I believe that it was supported by the majority of honourable members of this chamber at that time. At this time the House should give consideration to adopting a procedure which is eminently successful elsewhere and which would enable this chamber to look at its own procedures in an objective, rational and sensible way on a continuing basis. The Standing Orders Committee should deal with matters of form and Standing Orders which actually govern the chamber. There are two roles in this matter. A procedures committee would fulfil a very necessary role in the future of this Parliament. The Parliament tends to have stagnated and fallen backwards in its place in the parliamentary government of this country because of its inability to cope with the increased workload and the changes which have taken place in parliamentary and political operations in this country in recent years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Dr H.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have much pleasure in seconding the motion. It is not surprising that I should do so when the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes) has pointed out that I was the Chairman of the Joint Committee on the Parliamentary Committee System which considered this matter and made a recommendation. One of the fears is that the proposed committee is seen as replacing the Standing Orders Committee. The Standing Orders Committee is concerned with the form of words put in the Standing Orders which are to be applied. I suggest that the Standing Orders are not reviewed enough. When they are reviewed they are generally concerned with subjects that are discussed in the House or discussed by honourable members privately around the House and given some impetus.

SPEECH.PARA: This Committee is not suggested as a competitor with the Standing Orders Committee. It is put forward as a sensible procedure for suggested initiatives to be examined, discussed and their practicability tested and, finally, for the matter to be put before the House for decision and for incorporation in the Standing Orders. One feels at times that many of the practices and procedures do not require changes to the Standing Orders; they just require a change in the attitude of the House in the day-to-day functioning of Parliament. Over the years there has been a changed functioning of Parliament. There is the question of the volume of legislation and the question of the increasing demand by executive government on the time of the Parliament in putting matters forward.

One must ask whether Parliament exists just simply to provide that time for executive government. Should it not, after all, provide time for the elected representatives of the people to discuss a number of matters that are of importance? One has only to read a number of debates that occur on the Estimates for the Parliament to see that there is a lively interest amongst a number of honourable members on practices and procedures. Suggestions may be made for certain changes which are tested, but there is no discussion or testing of the effectiveness of those changes.

One thinks of the recent setting up of Estimates committees, legislation committees, expenditure committees and so on. Who tests them? When do we get a chance as a parliament to examine how they function? It may be found, from their functioning, that there should be an alteration in their role, that they should be given more powers or fewer powers and that they should use procedures which are more appropriate to the matters that are before them. For example, the legislation committees so far have dealt with the committee stages of Bills. While some of the Bills have been technically difficult, they have not necessarily been controversial. The operation of the legislative committees has been effective in that amendments and suggestions from Opposition members have been accepted and incorporated in the legislation. Is it necessary that all second readings of Bills are dealt with in the House, or is it appropriate that they be dealt with by these committees after being presented to the House? Who can make a recommendation to parliament with regard to it? Surely it is not a matter of party opinion that the parliamentary procedures used in dealing with such legislation are the ones that must be used.

I suggest that with this sort of committee, which is set up to have a look at our practices and procedures, one would probably, after reasoned discussion, get a very practical attitude on the matter and an opinion which would be unanimous. The Joint Committee on the Parliamentary Committee System comprised members from both Houses and all parties. There is not always sweet accord between both Houses of this Parliament, yet the report that was presented on that system was unanimous. It was a report on which senators and members, with wide variations in points of view politically, had been able to agree. They suggested to the Parliament that its recommendations should be implemented. One of those suggestions related to the surveillance of the practices and procedures of parliament. Honourable members will recall that members of that Committee visited other parliaments and heard of their experiences. That reinforced our belief that a practices and procedures committee-or whatever title it was given-would be of benefit to this Parliament in adjusting those practices and procedures to allow maximum participation of all members in the matters that Parliament should deal with to prevent it being bogged down on whatever action the Executive Government required it to take so that broader issues could be taken on and debated.

One of the matters you, Mr Deputy Speaker, will know has been raised is the relevance of our Question Time. I will not talk much further on that. We have the argument about whether answers to questions are relevant. That is always a bone of discontent between the Opposition and the Chair, and one for great joy for the Government at any time. But it does downgrade the information that we get from Question Time. In Question Time in other parliaments, such as the British House of Commons, a two or three line question to a specific Minister is printed. After the short and succinct answer is given, there is an opportunity at the discretion of the Speaker for supplementary questions. A discretion that we do not allow the Speaker of this Parliament. With good will and such a procedures committee, we may well find there is overwhelming agreement on the matter. That I believe, would be quite an improvement in the procedures of this House.

Should we set up standing committees? I will name one that I served on, the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation. I am very proud of that committee. I wonder at times whether a committee such as that should continue year after year when subject matters are raised in Parliament by members, and by petitions that never get an airing before a parliamentary committee. That is one of the procedures that I would like to see examined. I am not trying to judge that matter. I am saying that this sort of committee made up by four Government members, four Opposition members and a chairman who obviously, having the casting vote, would probably come from the Government side of the House-so there need be no fear in that respect-could decide just where we should head on this subject.

I believe that there is a desire amongst most members of this Parliament that we should review our practices and procedures from time to time to protect the interest of the ordinary back bench member of the Parliament to see that matters of national importance are able to be discussed in the Parliament and that these discussions allowed by practices and procedures are manifestly fair to all concerned. The practices and procedures committee that looks at these matters may ask about petitions which may come before the House. I know they are read by the Clerk and then referred to the appropriate persons. But surely there is a place for some of those to be discussed by this Parliament. I invite honourable members who have been here for some time to ask how often this practice has occurred.

I recall, when I first became a member of this Parliament, that there were petitions by the thousand on the killing of kangaroos. That is one example where a series of petitions did produce the House of Representatives select Committee on Wildlife Conservation. I believe that that was a matter in which the Government Whip of the day, Mr Max Fox, had a great interest and he was able to persuade the Government to take it on. But that is not the proper procedure in Parliament. The petition is made to Parliament. Surely we can define a bipartisan approach through a practices and procedures committee that would enable us to look at these matters and say: 'These are reasonably routine petitions. We expect such petitions, but this one is of particular interest to the Parliament and the Parliament should proceed to do something about it'.

I strongly support the setting up of a practices and procedures standing committee for the House. I believe that the Government need have no fear that it would bring about its downfall. I think all honourable members would realise that it would improve our practices and procedures in the House. There are many other arguments which I could advance if it had not been for the fact that I had about three minutes notice to second this motion. Certainly there is no backwardness in my support for this motion for a standing committee of practices and procedures of the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Mr G.O'H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I reply to the arguments of a previous Speaker of this House, the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes), who moved this motion, and to a most distinguished Deputy Speaker of another Parliament who, of course, has had some historical background in relation to the Joint Select Committee on the Parliamentary Committee System.
—You are not suggesting that I am an historical relic, are you?

—I am not suggesting that you are an historical dodo at all. I feel that I must take a lot of notice of what these two gentlemen have said today to this House. They have, of course, done what we did when in opposition-that is, put the position forward from where they sit. In some ways I must differ-I do not think very greatly-from what they have said. At the core of this whole debate is the proper balance-I do not think anyone has mentioned it yet-achieved by Parliament as a check and control on Executive power. That is really what this debate should be about. Again this magnifies the difference between where I sit currently as a slightly senior Government back bench member and where the two honourable gentlemen sit as highly important members of Her Majesty's Opposition. Under the current Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser)-and I am not being political in any shape or form-the back bench system, the number of committees and the power given to those committees resolves, in my view, any problems regarding the check and control of Executive power. For the first time I chair a committee that is quite entitled to refuse-and in fact has refused-leave to a Minister to introduce a certain matter into the party room. So we get the position within this Government, contrary to other governments, where this House-I suppose this is one thing that is genuinely perturbing the two Opposition speakers in this debate-becomes, in some ways, the House of ultimate self-justification. Apart from patching up procedures such as amendments agreed to subsequent to decisions being made, that is really what it is today. Decisions of government are now being taken not one step below this Parliament-in other words, by the Executive or in the party room-but in many cases one step below that again. Therefore, Mr Deputy Speaker, you will excuse me, if I say that the reasoned argument that the honourable gentlemen put forward did not convince me about what should be the core of this debate, that is, whether there is a proper parliamentary check and balance on Executive power.

SPEECH.PARA: The matter of Estimates committees was mentioned by the honourable member for Corio. He put forward a view on the Estimates committees which I do not hold. If ever there is a responsibility on this Parliament to function as a check and balance on Executive power it is to mount those Estimates committees properly. That is what they are about. I can think of an instance when a team from one party in this Parliament-I will not mention which one it was-succeeded in having nobody there when an industrial relations Bill was being considered. If one is talking about check and balance and the role of the back bench members of parliament, one should get one's perspective right because that is a complete example of the proper check that there should be within a limited portfolio responsibility on Executive power. I was disappointed to hear the honourable member for Corio treat the Estimates committees in a cavalier fashion in that instance. He also questioned-maybe this is what is worrying him-whether the structure is right and whether the power of such a committee, for want of a better phrase, is correct. If it has done nothing else, it has improved the capacity of this House to scrutinise every Minister's portfolio eight to twelve times more than this House and the Committee of the Whole used to. Some honourable members used to make parochial speeches for their local newspapers. I did the same thing; it was a marvellous opportunity for it. That was the degree of scrutiny of the Executive estimate by this House. Do not let us run away from the fact that we have taken big strides. I ask the House to remember that within the Government back bench structures today there is real power and a real check on Executive power emanates from that source. That power was not there before.

I shall now refer to the speech made by the honourable member for Scullin (Dr Jenkins). He said that the role of the Standing Orders Committee now was primarily a matter of deciding on the form of words that should be used. Even that is not true, as I see the situation. The last meeting of the Standing Orders Committee was on 3 December 1980, a little while ago now. Maybe the honourable member for Scullin, the honourable member for Corio and the member for Wakefield should have been promoting the fact that we needed another meeting. I do not know; that is another matter. As to whether the Committee simply looks at the form of words, let us look at some of the matters still under consideration by the Standing Orders Committee.

Firstly there is the Standing Orders Committee's report relating to petitions and parliamentary privilege tabled November 1979 but not considered by the House. In regard to petitions, I point out in passing that we have had two very solid days of presentation of petitions. No member of parliament has really listened to them, other than to listen for his own name to be read out, which is a matter of gross offence to the honourable members concerned and of even greater offence to the people who had that petition put down by their local member of parliament. Secondly, the Standing Orders Committee is to look again at the appointment of expenditure committees and their incorporation in Standing Orders-hardly a matter of words. It is also to look at discretions to the Speaker, quorums, divisions, closures, points of order generally-perhaps merely a form of words in that instance. It is to look at Question Time, which is surely a matter of substance, including the length of questions, and the House of Commons practice. That is not just a matter of words. It is to look at notices of motion, their content and the method of giving notice-'bringing down', as I would term it. The appointment of a committee on procedure is also mentioned. That, of course, is precisely what we are debating today.

If, on the agenda of the Standing Orders Committee, item 6 states 'Committee on Procedure', perhaps an idea ought to emanate there. I inquired earlier today as to whether the form of motion brought down by the honourable member for Corio could not be looked on more properly and more usefully as a sub-committee of the Standing Orders Committee on the Standing Orders basis. I was informed-I have no doubt quite accurately-that currently the Speaker does not have the power to bring about such a sub-committee in line with the Standing Orders Committee. Maybe that is one thing the Standing Orders Committee ought to look at. But as long as it is on the agenda for the next meeting, I should have thought that the first step would be to convene the Standing Orders Committee and to move that that be supported. The honourable member for Corio has not seen that as the proper course, for reasons I do not fully understand.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I tell you?
—Yes, I would be delighted.
—It is listed there because it was on the Notice Paper in my name in reverse order to the presentation to the House.

—I accept that as a reasonable matter. It does not alter what I said, though, and that is that I think what ought to happen is that the Standing Orders Committee ought to decide in favour of it, and if it does that it is a matter of action by the Government to bring it down. Maybe that is the way it will go anyway.

SPEECH.PARA: Another matter that I ought to refer to is that under the current structures of the Fraser Government the very people from the Government side who are on the Standing Orders Committee-I think the member for Corio or his colleague suggested they were probably the proper people-are experienced people who ought to be members of that standing committee and are, of course, the ones with the least time. I am not refering to the leaders of the House; I am referring to people such as myself who, under this system, have very little surplus time. I ponder upon whether we need another standing committee. I am concerned that there are now so many committees when one considers the party committee system as well. This causes a sort of mental constipation to occur within the system, and it is very difficult for people who are very busy on a wide variety of committee structures to get the sort of dynamism and result which I think the honourable member for Corio has in mind.

Those are my current views. I do not hold the view that the honourable member for Corio is doing anything he should not. I do not hold the view that there is no room at all for a standing committee on procedures; there might well be. But I point to the structural problems in having more and more committees. In contradistinction to the growth in the number of members of State Houses of parliament, both upper houses and lower, over a 20-year period, the number of members of this House has gone down by one and gone up by one in the 17 years I have been a member of parliament. It may well be that to mount committees properly with competent people we need more federal members of parliament. I think that time will come. I hesitate to speak without a great deal of thought on this problem and to give complete carte blanche agreement to the proposition of the honourable member for Corio. To bring it down now might not do justice to the system that the honourable member for Corio wants to adopt. To do it justice it must be mounted by experienced people who have a sense of history and a knowledge of how the committees function. We are asking the busiest people in Parliament to take part in yet another standing committee to be set up on a long term basis. I repeat: The argument must be about the proper check and balance on the Executive by Parliament itself. That is what it is about. If we are to argue that, as I think we should-it should be discussed-let us be consistent and give support to the other structures, such as the Estimates committees, that this Parliament so badly needs if it is to adopt its proper responsibility in checking the actions of an Executive.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that everybody in the House appreciates the interest of the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes) on matters such as this and the valuable role he has played in looking at the structure of Parliament and making Parliament more effective. I thank him for moving the motion. I think a number of the honourable members who served on the committee which examined these matters-the Joint Committee on the Parliamentary Committee System-in fact involved themselves more closely with the operation of committees of the Parliament both in the Senate and in the House of Representatives. That was an extremely valuable committee which came forward with a number of recommendations many of which have been adopted over a period.

SPEECH.PARA: The proposition being put by the honourable member for Corio is, indeed, an extension, as I understand it, of the work that was done by that committee on committees, as it was called. The report of the committee on committees, in fact, made recommendations on a number of important areas but I think the most significant ones related to the scrutiny of government activity by the Parliament. That scrutiny process, in fact, devoted itself to mainly financial matters, budgetary decisions, the decisions of government lending up to the Budget and the general administration of government. It also devoted itself at some length of the proposition of legislation committees.

Those two recommendations, whilst not completely in the form recommended by the committee on committees, have been adopted. They were pursued by a number of people. I remember the work of the honourable member for Scullin (Dr Jenkins) in this regard. In particular I remember the way in which the honourable member for Moore (Mr Hyde) followed through, in fact, to bring into place some of these ideas. Much of the work was developed privately within the ranks of the Australian Labor Party and also within the ranks of the coalition. We came to a concensus and, in fact, established legislation committees which have not been used in this Parliament as yet. But I hope that they will be used because I found the discussion and the effectiveness of legislation committees, whether they be for complicated legislation or for simple run-of-the-mill provisions that can be dealt with quickly--

TALK.START.PARA: —Very valuable.

—Very valuable indeed. In fact, we have been able to allow members to examine and scrutinise legislation with care and proper attention to detail. That has resulted in more effective and better legislaion and in better laws being made for this country. The other element that has been taken up by the House has been the decision that we should establish committees that look at the Estimates in the Budget. The honourable member for Moore was particularly keen to pursue this matter. The House has adopted for the last two years the process of Estimates committees. I personally see value in that process. I think those committees will continue or not continue depending on the value that is seen for them by members of this House.

SPEECH.PARA: The matter that has been raised by the honourable member for Corio, however, goes beyond that point. The motion that he has moved seeks to establish a committee to maintain a continuing surveillance of the practices and procedures of the House of Representatives with a view to making recommendations which could enhance the role of the House and its operational efficiency. My colleague the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Giles), I think, put a compelling case as to why part of those activities should be, in fact, put to the Standing Orders Committee. The establishment of that committee is set out in our Standing Orders. Its role in fact should be to look at the functioning of this House and to enhance the role of the House through amendments to Standing Orders procedures. My view is that these matters should best be dealt with in the way that we have been dealing with them.

Parliamentary reform and the efficiency and the enhancement of the operations of the House of Representatives have occupied the time and the minds of many people, mostly unsuccessfully. One individual seeking to bring about reform or change has a very difficult problem in convincing his colleagues that his ideas can be successfully adopted. But a number of individuals working together have been successful in having the Parliament look at a change to sitting hours. That has occupied the minds of parliamentarians on many occasions. Experiments have been tried; some have failed. In fact, they mostly have failed. But we are about to launch into an experiment for a change of sitting hours. I believe that a committee of the type envisaged by the honourable member for Corio would suffer the same difficulties that an individual suffers because one would have a group of dedicated enthusiastic individuals who would spend all of their time convincing their colleagues of the wisdom of their recommendations.

There is great reluctance in many ways to change the manner in which we operate here in these chambers. It is difficult to do that. There are vested interests perhaps, with each individual having his own vested interest in the style of life that he has here, in the requirements of the chamber and in the requirements of the Parliament. I suggest that further consideration be given to this proposal so that, in fact, the basic thrust of the matter can be taken up to see whether it be by means of Standing Orders committees, whether it be by agreement between the parties or individuals to pursue certain matters with their colleagues, or whether it would be practical to extend the scope of the Standing Orders Committee of the House of Representatives. I am not sure whether this will meet the needs and the requests of the honourable member for Corio.

I see merit in what the honourable member has proposed. I see obstruction in bringing it to achievement with any real success. I think we all know that in order to have enthusiastic membership of committees of this Parliament there needs to be some sense of fulfilment. There is not enthusiastic acclamation, I would think, for people to get themselves involved with the proposition of the honourable member. But I think there is interest in achieving the objectives he has laid down. I suggest to the honourable member that, privately and in discussion, a number of us may be able to pursue this matter to see whether we can establish a satisfactory method of working. Within the Government for five years we have had a committee which has worked to seek to establish parliamentary reform. There are a few successes on the board. Those successes are worthy successes. They relate to the factors that I have mentioned-the examination of Estimates and the legislation committees. I would like to see this progress continue because it has been a satisfying part of my time in the Parliament to see changes made.

I would like to conclude on the note that whilst I appreciate the thrust of what has been proposed and the comments made by the honourable member, I think his proposition to establish yet another committee would not meet with the approval of the House at large. But the objectives should be something in the mind of every member. Perhaps other techniques can be adopted to achieve the honourable member's objectives.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —In reply-I just want to respond to the debate on this matter. I want to thank all honourable members for the consideration they have given to the matter. I do not believe, as the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Giles) has indicated, it is a satisfactory situation that because the back bench members of the Government are satisfied with the methods by which legislation is considered outside this chamber, this chamber or this Parliament should abrogate its responsibilities as a parliament. Honourable members are, in fact, elected to serve in the Parliament. Whatever other activies they take are consequential on that, not part of it. My motion follows a recommendation of the Joint Committee on the Parliamentary Committee System. It deals with a practice which is adopted in other parliaments. It is highly successful. I believe that it would not become a lobbying exercise or an excercise whereby members seek to impose limited views. I think a broader consideration of matters and their practicality would have to be considered by such a committee otherwise its reputation would suffer. I am sorry that the Government is not prepared to adopt this procedure.

SPEECH.PARA: I say only one thing. The matters read out by the honourable member for Wakefield are listed for consideration by the Standing Orders Committee. The Speaker has taken the opportunity to list for the Standing Orders Committee a number of matters which are, in fact, on the Notice Paper of this chamber and other matters which have been raised in debate by members in this chamber. The reason the matters are still listed for consideration is because the Standing Orders Committee is a cumbersome committee and its personnel are almost totally unable to deal with any sort of discussion other than in an extremely cursory manner. The matters will stay listed for consideration. If my memory serves me correctly, I think the time taken up by Standing Orders committees in the last three Parliaments would not add up to one working day.
Question resolved in the negative.
Sitting suspended from 6.1 to 8 p.m.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 18 August, on motion by Mr Viner:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Mr B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 4 August 1822, in a letter to W. T. Barry, James Madison, who had been the fourth President of the United States, wrote these words:

SPEECH.PARA: A popular Government, without popular information, or the means of acquiring it, is but a prologue to a farce or a tragedy, or perhaps both. Knowledge will forever govern ignorance and a people who mean to be their own governors must arm themselves with the power knowledge gives.

Those wise words, 160 years old, are really the whole rationale of freedom of information legislation. But the legislation when it came in was a profound disappointment. Certainly, after it was worked over by the Senate it was a great improvement on its original form. It was still not as good, I think, as the American legislation of 1966 as amended in 1974 and certainly not as good as the draft Bill that was prepared by the Australian Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs.

The long-awaited Freedom of Information Bill should be more accurately described as a 'Public Service Preservation from Disclosure' Bill. It is perhaps better than nothing. There are some guidelines which will enable citizens and organisations to gain access to information in the possession of the Government of the Commonwealth as set out in clause 3 of the Bill by, and I quote:

(a) making available to the public information about the operations of departments and public authorities and, in particular, ensuring that rules and practices affecting members of the public in their dealings with departments and public authorities are readily available to persons affected by those rules and practices; and

(b) creating a general right of access to information in documentary form in the possession of Ministers, departments and public authorities, limited only by exceptions and exemptions necessary for the protection of essential public interests and the private and business affairs of persons in respect of whom information is collected and held by departments and public authorities.

The tragedy is that the comparative breadth of the first paragraph of clause 3 is really cut back very considerably by the broad exemptions and exceptions created by paragraph (b). As Patrick Cook suggested in the National Times, perhaps the best way that the Bill could be described is as the 'Ask Me No Questions and I Won't Have to Waste Time Lying' Bill or, for those honourable members who follow the television program Yes, Minister, the 'Yes, Minister' Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —An excellent program.
—It certainly is.
—Frightening.

—It is frightening but I think a substantially accurate impression of what happens in Australia. There are a number of points about the Bill that are disturbing and I wanted to take up a number of the references made last night by the honourable member for Chisholm (Mr Harris) in his speech. The first question is that of retrospectivity. Originally there was to be no retrospectivity at all, but now there is a degree of qualified retrospectivity in respect of personal files-the capacity to go back and correct errors or omissions that are significant with respect to one's own personal file. The honourable member for Chisholm dismissed any claim for general retrospectivity. 'Why,' he said, 'people might be hunting back through files for the past five or 10 years'-as indeed they might. And so they should. I make the point that the United States legislation of 1966, as amended in 1974, does provide for retrospectivity and the result is that it has been possible to go back and to examine a number of very contentious matters on the historical record.
—So they ought.

—So they ought, as the honourable member for Hawker says. One could just mention very briefly some of the matters that have been raised of very general public concern. The Rosenberg case, for example, was not a very popular case in 1953 and it still arouses a lot of sensitivity in American breasts. But it has become quite clear from the papers derived from the Rosenberg file that whatever the guilt or innocence of Julius Rosenberg, one can only say that the case against Ethel Rosenberg was absolutely threadbare-conceded in prosecution files-and that essentially her conviction was sought because it was thought it would apply additional pressure on her husband to speak. But there was not even a prima facie case against her. Whatever one's view of the Cold War there has been a general concession that United States justice did not operate correctly in her case.

SPEECH.PARA: One might argue that the Ethel Rosenberg revelation indicates a weakness in the United States judicial system, but I think, to the contrary, it shows strength when it is prepared to make files available even in a case as sensitive as that one. The United States in fact has not suffered from these revelations. If we consider the case of Alger Hiss, we find very serious weaknesses in the prosecution case. It is quite clear from the Federal Bureau of Investigation files that very significant information was withheld from the prosecution case. If it had been put to the jury in the way that Australian prosecutors put a broad case to the jury-that is, not just a narrow and segmented case-it is difficult to see that Hiss would have been convicted.

In the case of the assassination of President Kennedy, it is now patent on the basis of documentation brought out by the freedom of information legislation that there were grave deficiencies in the way that the Warren Commission operated, although the final conclusion reached by the Warren Commission may well be correct. What one can say pretty safely is that one could not safely reach that judgment on the basis of the evidence that the committee looked at. There may be other factors that have to be taken into account as well. We know a great deal more about the operation of the United States Government than we do about our own Government, partly because of the access to the documents related to the Watergate affair. We know a lot more about the relationship of the Mafia and government agencies and, most significantly, because there are no exemptions granted in the United states freedom of information legislation, we know, and the United States citizens know, far more about the operations of the Central Intelligence Agency or the Federal Bureau of Investigation than we do about the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation or the Australian Security Intelligence Service or the Office of National Assessments.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the Government.
—And the Government. The point that the former honourable member for Fuller who is trying to interject will no doubt raise--
—Wentworth.

—Yes, the honourable member for Wentworth. It just escaped me for the minute. There has been a constituency in between as well. The honourable member for Wentworth will no doubt be able to take up the point as to why we should be so much more sensitive on these questions than the United States. Is it because the volume of secret information we have is so much more significant than it is in the United States? One has only to state that proposition to recognise its patent absurdity.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a whole number of issues, some of them historical, that one would like to know about in Australia. One of these, for example, would be the relationship of the Armed Forces and the civilian government in Australia during World War II-an issue I have raised before-to find out more about that potentially explosive situation where the Army was executing significant numbers of New Guineans, at least a hundred at the last count, without telling the Australian Government and also going to some pains to keep the Australian Government of the day from knowing. Another very contentious question concerns how it was that we got into the Vietnam War. Clearly, the whole question of the documentation-what contact there was with the United States Government and with the Government of the Republic of Vietnam-is of the greatest importance. And so it ought to be of the greatest importance. We have a right to know as citizens.

TALK.START.PARA: —Menzies lied.

—Well, of course, that is clear. The exemptions in the Australian Bill are far too wide. The onus of proof for the right to exempt-that is to exclude certain classes of documents from access-should be placed squarely on those seeking the exemption. But the certificate of the Minister is to be conclusive. Schedule 2 provides a list of exempt agencies and a further list of agencies which are exempt in respect of certain functions. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard Schedule 2 of the Government's own Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. In the list of exempt agencies about which no information can be provided are the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories Commission, the Health Insurance Commission, the Office of National Assessments, the Pipeline Authority and, as I said earlier, ASIS and ASIO. We have to ask why it is possible for the United States to grant access under freedom of information legislation to documents of the FBI and the CIA when it is impossible for us to have the same right. Why is the whole issue of security so much more sensitive in Australia than it is in the United States?

SPEECH.PARA: Agencies are also to be exempt in respect of particular documents. For example, we will not be able to ask for information about the Australian Broadcasting Commission in relation to its program material. Can anyone advance any rational reason why that should be the case? Further, we will not be able to ask the Special Broadcasting Service about its program material. I refer to a case that has been brought to my attention. The ABC, for its own peculiar reasons, has declined to buy the British Broadcasting Corporation's recent three-part television dramatisation of Dostoevski's Crime and Punishment. I would like to know the reason. No doubt, if as a member of parliament I ask the Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair) I will get an answer sometime in the dim, distant future. If a citizen asked for this information under the freedom of information legislation, he would be told: 'We cannot give you that information. The ABC is exempt'. Why? In the United States citizens would get such information. It is quite absurd. The same situation applies to the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation in relation to documents in respect of its competitive commercial activities. Why should it be so secret? Why should citizens not know? In the United States freedom of information legislation, agencies are prima facie included. In Australia the legislation is drawn so that the more sensitive agencies are prima facie excluded.

The question of costs was raised last night by the honourable member for Chisholm, who is not with us at the moment. He argued that if we tried to draw the legislation too widely we might find that the costs would be prohibitive. I draw attention to some material that the Parliamentary Library has been able to obtain about the actual cost of running the United States freedom of information system. The original legislation was passed in 1966 in the time of President Johnson. In 1974 during the Watergate period it was very much expanded. The most recent figure for the total cost of running the freedom of information operation in the United States was cited by Allen Weinstein, a historian who would be well known to the honourable member for Wentworth (Mr Coleman). He wrote in the New York Times Magazine:

In 1978, according to the Department of Defense, its agencies processed over 56,466 requests at a cost of $6 million, and fees collected from FOIA requesters covered only a small portion of the expense.
The honourable member for Wentworth will not be surprised to learn that Professor Weinstein is an opponent of the freedom of information legislation. He continued:
This 'shortfall' affects all Government departments and agencies. In 1977, for example-
Here is the total figure-
FIOA users' fees amounted to $1.36m, less than 4 percent of the estimated $35m it cost the Federal Government to comply with the Act.

The United States has a population 14 times that of Australia. The United States Freedom of Information Act is much wider than ours. Some of the areas which have had the largest number of requests have been the Department of Defence, the CIA and the FBI. In 1977 the total cost was $US35m. It seems to me that that figure would be the equivalent in Australia of about $2.5m on a pro rata basis, taking population only into account. Considering that our legislation is so much narrower in its scope, that it does not cover sensitive areas and that it is so much easier to get an exemption than it is in the United States, one might assume that the costs would, in fact, be considerably less than $2.5m in 1977 money values. I would estimate that even on the most generous estimate freedom of information would cost about $3m or perhaps a little more here. Another factor that has to be taken into account is that Australians are far less aggressive than Americans and far less likely to want to find out the truth. They do not show any passionate curiosity. That is obvious when we look at honourable members on the other side of the House. They have no very passionate concern or great zeal to find out the truth. The total outlays in this year's Budget, including permanent and special appropriations, are just over $40,000m. Even if the cost of operating under the freedom of information legislation were as high as $4m-I do not think it would be; it would be considerably less-it would represent only 0.001 per cent of the total Budget allocation. We have to ask ourselves whether that is too much for finding out what is going on in government and to have the right to be fully informed. Clearly, this Government does not like that idea and has done the absolute bare minimum in this legislation.

There are some major deficiencies in the legislation, some of which we will raise by way of amendments. We are also told that after 12 months or so there will be a review of the legislation. Two points need to be made in addition to our amendments. They are two fundamental issues of principle which will have to be looked at in the future and which make the United States Act worthwhile. Firstly, we have to be able to impose penalties directed at specific offices and officers. The real problem that often occurs when a person comes up against the bureaucratic maze is that he is not given a flat refusal. The officers do not say: 'No, you cannot have the file'. They say: 'Look, we had the file a few days ago but somebody else is using it. Come back next week'. When the person comes back the next week they say: 'We are terribly sorry. It had to go somewhere else. Perhaps if you come back next week you will get it'. A person is often not refused absolutely; he is just fooled around with.

The United States legislation provides that it is possible to go to a court and request it to impose a monetary penalty on an officer or a section of the access office which is procrastinating in a way that is unreasonable. Of course, an applicant has the onus of proof to prove that the officer is unreasonable in his procrastination, but it is an effective deterrent. The other factor is the provision of indices. The provision of a fine grained index is extremely important. Let me read what the legislation says. I do not regard this as adequate. Clause 8 states:
(1) The responsible Minister of an agency shall-

(a) cause to be published, as soon as practicable . . . a statement setting out particulars of the organization . . . particulars of any arrangements that exist for bodies or persons outside the Commonwealth administration to participate . . . a statement of the categories of documents that are maintained in the possession of the agency . . .

It seems to me that the sheer setting out of a bland statement of heads of categories does not tell us enough. If a layman or an organisation which is not particularly skilled is trying to look for particular information, it is very easy to be snowed. There may be very valuable information in a document but the document may be of such imposing length and complexity that one does not know where to look. It is a matter of absolute necessity that there be an adequate fine grained index. Of course, with the computerised facilities available to the Government it should be possible for that to be provided very easily.

I do not doubt that the whole democratic system is under very serious challenge. We have an enormously powerful Public Service in Australia and the Parliament, relatively speaking, is losing its place in the sun under this Government. I think freedom of information is a very powerful instrument that can strengthen the hand of the Australian voter, and if we have a more informed electorate we should have a better Parliament. I vividly recall, as you do, Mr Deputy Speaker, the Berthelsen case when we sat on the Privileges Committee of this House. It became patently clear that many senior public servants despised their Ministers. They downgrade and disregard the Parliament, members of which they outrank and outearn, and they feel that the electorate should be left in the dark. The attitude expressed so vividly in the British Broadcasting Corporation's television series Yes, Minister in which a hapless Minister has rings run round him by his wily permanent head is as accurate for the Australian scene as it is a faithful representation of what happens in Great Britain. I conclude as I began by re-reading those words of Madison which are the whole justification, the whole rationale:
A popular Government, without popular information, or the means of acquiring it, is but a prologue to a farce or a tragedy or perhaps both. Knowledge will forever govern ignorance--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to speak on the Freedom of Information Bill. The Bill is an important initiative of the Government of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). I wish strongly to applaud the fact that after a long period of gestation since the proposal for freedom of information was first advanced by spokesmen for the Australian Labor Party when it was in Opposition prior to its last being in government, the first Freedom of Information Bill introduced to any Parliament in Australia was a Bill introduced by the Government of Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser. It ought to be applauded because it was a very fine initiative and a very worthwhile reform of which Australians have every right to be proud. I admit that there might well be scope for argument about the clauses of the Bill. One might want to discuss the extent to which the Act, when it is in operation, ought to apply to particular departments and particular statutory authorities, and the manner in which we ought to apply the legislation to those authorities. But the fact is that this is a unique and admirable initiative of the Government of today.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation was first proposed by the Labor Party when it was in Opposition. When it came to power in 1972 it did not come into the Parliament with a Bill of its own ready to proceed. It referred the matter first to an interdepartmental committee. We saw its first report in 1974. After the change of government in 1975 there was a further report from the interdepartmental committee and later we saw legislation in a draft form introduced into the Senate. It was the subject of consideration by a standing committee of the Senate. The Bill was the subject of reconsideration by the Government and the present Bill, in another form, was introduced into the Senate, was amended and has now reached this chamber. It comes here after contributions from the Opposition as well as from the Government.

I made those comments because I regard this Bill as a very worthwhile reform which one might hope would be discussed in this place in a bipartisan spirit. I was, therefore, exceedingly disappointed to hear the speech of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen) when he spoke on behalf of the Opposition on this matter. He was most grudging in whatever praise he had to offer in relation to the Bill and had some most uncomplimentary remarks to make about the Fraser Government. I must say that I could not let the moment pass without having a look at the Labor Party's record, which I propose to do. I think its record gives its members every reason to hang their heads in shame. I would not have done this except for the sorts of comments made by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. I quote from the House of Representatives Hansard of 18 August, page 44. He said:

However, the Attorney-General was overridden by a very dominant Cabinet with a most dominant Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) who appears to be obsessed with secrecy. We will deal with some of these matters as we go through some of the amendments later in the week.
We have seen the Government somewhat obsessed with secrecy.

I would suggest that members of the Labor Party hang their heads in shame when they listen to their Government's record on these matters, notwithstanding their rhetoric before 1972. On page 45 Mr Bowen was reported to have said:
There is also no doubt that many Ministers, including the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) are very wary of allowing the public to know much at all.

He says that is so notwithstanding the fact that the only Bill introduced into an Australian Parliament to give freedom of information was introduced by this Government, and notwithstanding that the Labor Party had three years in office after having promised in its policy speech to introduce legislation to give effect to freedom of information. I must say that I was somewhat alert to the fact that members of the Labor Party had an interest in this matter. There was a book written by a gentleman by the name of Spigelman. An Inside Dopester's Index of 100 Examples of Secrecy was included in that book by Mr Spigelman, his book being entitled Secrecy-Political Censorship in Australia. In relation to those 100 examples of secrecy I sought information from the then Prime Minister, Mr Whitlam. I asked him to specify which of those 100 items were not publicly disclosed up until 1972, how many of those items had been made publicly available since he took office and, if all of them were not readily available, what the reason was for the continuing secrecy in each case. I think that was a fair question to ask. There were 100 examples and I expected him to do a little work in relation to those matters which he had spoken of and which his private secretary had written so much of when the Labor Party was in Opposition. The then Prime Minister had the following remarks to make when he answered my question. They were published in the House of Representatives Hansard of 15 December 1974. He said:
I am, of course, aware of the book to which the honourable member refers. The author is now my Principal Private Secretary and I did most of the research for the book.

With respect to the items listed in this index and the many other examples of secrecy of which my Government became aware on assuming office, the honourable member would be aware that most are of historical interest only.
What an excuse to offer. He continued:

On 2 April 1973, I wrote to all Ministers suggesting that they exercise their discretion on items of current interest and in cases of doubt should await the criteria for release of documents in the proposed Freedom of Information Act.
How convenient! He never introduced it. He continued:
I believe a number of documents were released in 1973. If the honourable member is interested in any of the particular documents, I suggest he ask the Minister responsible.

That prompted my asking 100 questions of each of the Ministers in relation to each of the documents. Honourable members may be interested to know the results of those inquiries because they involve some prominent front benchers of the Opposition today and many prominent Ministers in the Labor Party at the time. I will take honourable members through a few of them. Mr Barnard, as Deputy Prime Minister, refused to make available the report of an independent firm of consultants on community attitudes to Service careers. Mr Barnard refused to make available a report on tests of anti-corrosive coatings carried out by the Central Testing and Research Laboratories. Mr Barnard refused to make available an interdepartmental study of housing problems of the Services. Mr Barnard refused to make public a report on the Defence Services Flying Training Program. Mr Barnard refused to make public the Morshead report on Army structure. Mr Barnard refused to make public the Hasett committee report on Army reorganisation. Mr Barnard refused to make public the reports on the proposed tri-Service academy. Mr Barnard refused to make public the report of the Commonwealth Paint Committee's tests on household paints. Mr Barnard refused to make public the submissions on the proposed Army base in Western Australia. Mr Barnard refused to make public the report of the court of inquiry on RAAF Laverton. Mr Barnard refused to make public the administrative directive on the responsibilities of the Department of Defence. Mr Barnard refused to make public details of the Defence Standards Laboratories consumer tests. Mr Barnard refused to make public the review of civilian substitution in the armed services. He refused to make public advice and analysis concerning the reintroduction of conscription.

Mr Whitlam also was involved in some refusals. Mr Whitlam refused to make public the statistics on Public Service applicants rejected on security grounds. Mr Whitlam refused to make public records of the Commonwealth-State Ministers' official meetings. One could go on. Mr Hayden refused to make public the interdepartmental report on the state of the economy, also referred to by Mr Spigelman. Mr Charles Jones refused to make public the report of the Department of Civil Aviation on Electra aircraft noise levels on the ground that specific noise considerations were not mentioned in the report and were not in a suitable form for public release. Mr Charles Jones refused to make public the report on Sydney's second airport. Mr Connor refused to make public the blueprint for national resources. I could go on. There were others by Mr Enderby, some by Dr Cass and some by Dr Patterson, all of whom were Ministers in the previous Labor Administration.

I regard those refusals as very important examples of the way in which members of the Labor Party when in office dealt with these important items of secrecy upon which they base their campaign. I suggest to honourable members that their campaign was based upon a deceit, because they were not prepared, when they had to look at these matters coolly, as one might have expected from them when they were in office, to publish them. If they were not prepared to publish those items, what justification did Mr Spigelman have for his Inside Dopesters Guide for which Mr Whitlam did most of the research? Quite frankly, if we look at the comments of some honourable members of the Opposition and previous members of the Opposition we find that there were good reasons for the decisions that they took when they were in government. Perhaps those decisions were justified, but I believe that it would be fair to say that the Government that in the first place withheld those documents which were identified by the Opposition was also justified in withholding them in the manner in which it did if the Labor Party was not prepared to release them itself when it came to office and had the opportunity to do so.

Senator Peter Rae asked a similar question to mine in the Senate. He asked all Ministers what reports and documents the then Labor Government had prepared but had not publicly released. I think that was a pertinent question for a member of the Senate, who was interested in the Labor Party's record on freedom of information when it was in office, to ask. I believe that Mr Whitlam's answer, given through Senator Wriedt in the other place, was interesting. Members of the Opposition might well be interested in the answer he gave. He said:

It would be clearly impractical to identify every unpublished document produced by or for the Government and I am not prepared to authorise the expenditure, time and effort which would be involved in attempting to do so.
He went on to say:
In my answer on 13 May 1975, (House of Representatives Hansard, page 2198)-
That was in answer to the question that I had asked-

I pointed out that my Government's record in relation to the release of information, in contrast to that of its predecessors, has been outstanding. I draw honourable senator's attention to illustrations I give in that answer of the Government's performance in this area.

I come to the answer that the then Prime Minister, Mr Whitlam, gave me. It is most illuminating to learn what Mr Whitlam, when he was in office, thought that the public was entitled to know. I will paraphrase to a degree but I do not think it will destroy the content of the answer that was given. I shall quote from page 2198 of House of Representatives Hansard of 13 May 1975. Mr Whitlam said:
The Government is committed to the principle of open government and will continue to honour that commitment.
Nobody could object to that. He went on to say:
My Government has made public details of its decisions; . . .
Well, fancy that! I would be most surprised if any government refused, on the basis of secrecy, to announce its decisions. He went on to say:

it has set up a large number of Committees, Commissions, etc. of inquiry before which interested members of the public have been able to put their views-and the reports of which are being progressively released; I have provided the Parliament each half-year with a detailed account of the Government's activities; . . .
Having sat in this place and listened to the way in which he harangued us about the Government's performance and its record, I know exactly what he meant when he said that. He continued:

the Australian Government Liaison Service has been instituted to provide ready access to official government information and an abstract of government decision, legislation and Ministerial statements and speeches is regularly published in the Australian Government Weekly Digest.

That was the Government propaganda arm with which we were all so familiar. The foregoing was Mr Whitlam's idea of freedom of information. It was to set up a mechanism by which the Government could propogate those decisions about which it wanted the public to know and to enable it to do so in the most efficient way with the taxpayers' support. As I have said, I did not want to be political in this debate. I decided to introduce this material only in a straightforward--

TALK.START.PARA: —In a statesmanlike way.

—I accept the accolade from the Minister-in a statesmanlike way because of the comments of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in his speech yesterday, in which he impugned the motives of this Government in introducing legislation in this important area. I am not prepared to have our motives impugned because this is a most worthwhile reform of which this Government is proud and of which the people of Australia should be proud. I am disappointed that honourable members in this place would not accept it in the same way that it has been accepted in the Senate and contribute in the same positive way to improving the Bill, as members of the Senate did. The sort of remarks that were offered by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition were totally uncalled for and totally unwarranted.

SPEECH.PARA: I shall finish on the following note: I have followed these matters because I have had a long standing interest in questions on freedom of information. The Treasurer in 1975, was the honourable member for Oxley (Mr Hayden), now Leader of the Opposition. One would think that he would also have an interest in freedom of information, perhaps the same sort of interest that Mr Whitlam, the then Prime Minister, had demonstrated. One would have thought that, having been so critical of the then McMahon Government and its predecessor governments, when he was in Opposition, he would have been quite prepared to unlock all those secrets which his party had condemned the former governments for failing to disclose. But the fact of the matter is that Mr Hayden, then the Treasurer, was no different from the rest. He thanked me for my letter of 4 June which I had addressed to the Australian Loan Council concerning the confidentiality of the proceedings of the Council. That was one of the items that Mr Spigelman had so carefully selected. Mr Hayden's reply stated:
I have noted that in the first paragraph of your letter you draw on a reply dated 13 May 1975 given to you by my predecessor, in response to your question upon notice No. 2253.

Regarding the question of the confidentiality of Loan Council proceedings the facts are as stated in the answer to that question.
