The Loan Council, as constituted under the Financial Agreement, comprises members of all State Governments as well as the Australian Government, and all decisions taken by the Council, including those regarding the confidentiality of its proceedings and records are binding on all members.

Well, fancy that! They were binding on Mr Hayden as well, even though he suggested, I assume along with his colleagues who were so committed to freedom of information, that they should be published. He went on to say:

It is not open to the Australian Government member or the Secretary to provide information in regard to them. It would therefore be inappropriate for me to provide further information except to say that all decisions on these aspects have been carefully observed during the period that members of the present Government have participated in proceedings of the Council.

I think it has to be observed that oppositions seem to have one standard when they are in Opposition and one standard when they are in government. I would say that that was very plainly demonstrated by the Labor Party's performance. I hope that some honourable members opposite will have regard to the comments of their colleagues in considering these matters and recognise that perhaps there are cases which, if they were faced with the facts and the information, were in office and had to make decisions, they would wish to consider very carefully before they made them public. I hope that they will settle down to review this legislation essentially in a bipartisan way, looking at what might properly be made available, whichever party is in office. I believe that then we will have much better legislation, legislation which is worthy of support. I can assure honourable members opposite that I am prepared to examine such legislation and to look at their proposals in that way. I hope that they will stop the acrimony that was evidenced by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in relation to this matter and debate it in good faith.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a matter of great regret that on this occasion the Parliament is considering legislation which is so clearly deficient in terms of the objectives that it purports to have. The concern about this legislation is not exclusively with the Opposition. In fact, the Opposition finds itself in a position where it shares this concern with very wide sections of the Australian community whose objectivity, fairness and concern could not be impugned. It is surprising to hear statements of the kind that have just been made by the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock). His honesty in connection with this question will be determined when this House considers the amendments that will be moved and which have been foreshadowed by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen). At this time it will not be sufficient for the honourable member for Dundas to claim that the Opposition took a political stand on this because the amendments will commend themselves. At the time we will see the way in which the honourable member for Dundas, with all of his high sounding concern about this issue, responds to sensible and desirable amendments which will be moved by the Opposition. The Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner) in his second reading speech said:

SPEECH.PARA: The crucial element in drafting the Freedom of Information Bill has been to strike the appropriate balance between openness and confidentiality.

The Opposition does not quibble with a statement of that kind. Despite the fact that such a significant proportion of the total time of the honourable member for Dundas was used in listing examples of Labor Ministers who, for very legitimate reasons, chose not to make public some documents, I am firmly convinced that the question of adequate balance between those two conflicting objectives in relation to legislation of this kind and to which the Minister made reference has, to a disproportionate degree, come down in favour of confidentiality. I am not surprised that the list that the honourable member for Dundas read out contained a greater number of reports that were not made public by Mr Barnard when he was Minister for Defence. That is the situation we would expect to find. It is certainly not the claim of the Opposition, any other section of the Australian community or any individual that the issues of government can be carried out in a goldfish bowl. No such claim has been made and no such claim is being made in connection with our consideration of this legislation.

The omissions of this legislation indicate quite clearly that the Government, which has been responsible for formulating it, is suspicious of the Australian people. It is suspicious of the Australian electors, fearful of open Government and feels threatened by public access to information. If it were possible for us to have full community participation in democratic decision-making that would probably be the most desirable form of democracy we could have. The practical difficulties of that, of course, preclude it. We have settled for an alternative which involves representatives of the community taking the responsibility for making those decisions. There is no concern on our part that legislation of this kind would or could in any way damage the essential nature of that decision-making process. The contrary applies. If details of the legislation were more effective, legislation of this kind would strengthen the operation of democratic government.

I emphasise, particularly to Government members, that they, like Opposition members, should realise that the question of freedom of information in connection with government operations-the operation of departments, bureaucrats and public authorities-is not a question for debate between the Opposition and the Government. In fact, it is a question of whether the Parliament will assert its authority over the bureaucracy and over the Executive and whether the Parliament-Opposition and Government-will ensure that people within the Australian community will have reasonable, ready and simple access to documents which are not matters of vital national security.

The Deputy Leader of the Opposition emphasised our concern about the exclusions in this legislation and the wording of some of the provisions of this legislation. He has already foreshadowed the fact that the Opposition will be moving amendments. If there are any Liberal democrats or any democratic Liberals on the Government side someone from the Government side will need to support the amendments that will be moved. If, in fact, no member on the Government side chooses to support those amendments, the political nature of this debate and the political nature of the decision which will follow it will not be of the making of the Opposition.

It is probably as well, because reference was made to the role of the Australian Labor Party when it was in government in relation to this legislation and in consideration of this particular issue, to have a look at the background to the situation that we now find ourselves in. Certainly before the election in 1972 the then Leader of the Opposition who became Prime Minister, Gough Whitlam, promised open government. In 1974 while the Australian Labor Party was in government the first interdepartmental committee, which was appointed to investigate the provisions which could be involved in freedom of information legislation, delivered its first report. A subsequent report was delivered by the second interdepartmental investigation in 1976. In 1978 the first legislation was introduced. Certainly the Government and honourable members speaking for the Goverment have attempted to claim some credit for that legislation. It was suggested that members of the Opposition should hang their heads in shame. The same thing could be said about the Government in relation to the 1978 legislation. The attitude towards that legislation was reflected by all responsible thinking persons in Australia. It was a shameful piece of legislation. It was an apology for freedom of information and, in fact, it was referred to as a Bill which was designed to ensure freedom from information. That legislation, on the motion of an Opposition senator, Senator John Button, was referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. That Committee produced a unanimous report recommending major changes in the Bill. The total number of recommendations made by that Committee was 93. This legislation we are considering now in no way accommodates all of the major matters of concern that were raised and decided unanimously by that Committee.

In a ministerial statement in 1980 Senator Durack rejected most of the recommendations despite the fact that senators on his side of the Parliament were parties to the unanimous decision that was made and the unanimous recommendations which that report brought forward. From 1972 until now-and probably into the future-the parallel furrows that have been made by the dragging heels of those reluctant bureaucrats can be traced from one stage of the development in connection with this legislation to the next. The people who have resisted freedom of information have been the bureaucrats. The results of the two interdepartmental inquiries reflected very unfavourably on the extent to which the bureaucracy will go to ensure that the community does not have access to information which is vital to it.

For all the high sounding platitudes of the honourable member for Dundas, the simple fact remains that some of the most significant and valuable features of this legislation would not be here had it not been for the fact that Government senators crossed the floor in relation to some amendments and threatened to do so in relation to other proposals had the legislation not been changed. Those senators were Senator Alan Missen, Senator Kathy Martin, Senator Chris Puplick, Senator Neville Bonner and Senator David Hamer. They joined the Australian Democrats and the Opposition in voting for the amendments. The result was, of course, that, even after the legislation had been introduced in the Senate, it was withdrawn and redrafted. No claim can be made that the Government has been enthusiastic about ensuring that adequate safeguards and adequate provisions would be included in this legislation. In fact the contrary has been the case.

Ministers have, in consort with the bureaucracy, attempted at all stages to make sure that this legislation will be less effective than it should be and less effective than it might otherwise have been. That is the reason why the Parliament must assert its authority not only over the bureaucracy but also over the Executive and the Executive arm of Government. I include as the major component of the Executive arm of Government Ministers of the Government. One of the most important changes which resulted from that revolt in the Senate was the establishment of the Document Review Tribunal to review the conclusive certificates given to exempt documents. Of course the provisions in that respect certainly do not go far enough. But, of those changes that were introduced, certainly that was the most important and did overcome some of the reservations that existed in relation to the original legislation. The provisions for the correction of personal records that go back five years was another very important change introduced into the legislation. The Opposition certainly supports not only those changes but also others which have a less significant character. Changes were introduced also to ensure improvements in the mechanical means by which accessibility to documents would be facilitated. For example the indexing of documents was another desirable change and there were some relatively minor changes in the exemptions. One of the most disturbing aspects was that when the legislation was reintroduced in the Senate not only had there been some improvements built into it but also were additional exemptions for documents written into the legislation, which had not been considered in the 1978 legislation, and which had proved to be so insufficient that it was thrown out and reconsidered completely.

The Government resisted other well founded and desirable changes that were proposed by the Opposition in relation to such matters as the jurisdiction of the Ombudsman, the time limitation, prior documents, personal records and the exemption list. In relation to this legislation, I emphasise the fact that the Opposition, as I have said, does not find itself alone in its concern. For example, the Sydney Morning Herald in an editorial on 1 June this year in relation to this legislation stated:

On the whole, the Federal Government's Freedom of Information Bill, in the amended form in which it will go through the Senate this week, is probably better than nothing-but not much better. It cannot be greeted with enthusiasm, in spite of the many concessions-some of them fairly important, most of them minor-made by the Government in response to sustained pressure from critical senators, especially five dissatisfied Liberals. These five, in the words of Labor and Australian Democrat spokesmen, now seem to have capitulated to counterpressure from the Government, or to have done a deal with it.

They are not my words; they are the words of a responsible, national newspaper. Certainly that newspaper does not act as a spokesman for the Labor Party. If anyone is going to suggest that the Labor Party is conjuring up concern about the deficiencies in this legislation he needs only to refer to editorials of that kind and other types of comments that have been made by other individuals and interest groups within the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which one was that?
—It was the Sydney Morning Herald of 1 June.
—It gives the Labor Party a very good run.

—I could not have written a better editorial myself. There is one example that I will make particular reference to because it indicates better than any other example with which I am familiar the excessive secrecy, the obsession with secrecy, the fear of freedom of information which has accompanied decisions of this Government. I refer to the attempt by the Government to ensure that the book Documents on Australian Defence and Foreign Policy 1968-1975 would not be published, would not be distributed, would not be sold or be made available to the Australian people. That attempt on the part of the Government was defeated as it should have been defeated, but it was not defeated until the matter went before the court. Mr Justice Mason described the contents of that book, about which the Government had been so obsessive and so determined in its attempt to prevent publication, in these terms:

SPEECH.PARA: The book sets out a large number of Government documents. The book does not contain technical information of military significance; it does not deal with weaponry, armaments, military technology, logistical information or dispositions of forces. It is not affected by the 'D' Notice procedures. Even the two documents referred to in the ex parte injunction contain no material of value to a hostile power.The appreciations made of Australia's strategic situation and the outlook in South-East Asia are based on information which is generally known. The judgments made are fairly elementary and they are now quite out of date.

Will we ever forget the attempt that was made by the Government on that occasion to frustrate the endeavour on the part of the publishers of that book to publish it and make it available to the Australian people? If that is not obsession with secrecy, I would need to be shown a better example.
I also quote a statement from the evidence of Mr Henderson, the Secretary of the Department of Foreign Affairs, in that case. He said:
. . . it is much more likely to facilitate our future relations if the Government has been seen to try its utmost to prevent that (disclosure) happening.

In fact it appears that the attempt was made to frustrate the publication of that book because of the Government's concern about its relationship with its powerful friends. The Sydney Morning Herald states:

This led to a suggestion, as Mr Justice Mason noted, that the Government acted as it did merely to demonstrate its bona fides to foreign Governments. If that is well founded-and Mr Henderson's evidence seems to bear no other construction-then the Government's philosophy would seem to be: Keep our foreign friends happy-even if this can be done only by taking away Australian freedoms. Popularity at any price.

I will quote from another editorial of the Sydney Morning Herald because I find the writer of these editorials a very comfortable bedmate in relation to this question. I refer to an editorial of 3 December 1980 which relates to an attempt by the Government to prevent publication of the book Documents on Australian Defence and Foreign Policy 1968-75. It stated:

The Government acted in haste, if not panic, with a demonstrable lack of political nous. It acted to preserve not security but face and the convenience of ministers and public servants. And in acting it ignored from habit, if not arrogance, the principle affirmed by Mr Justice Mason, that against one kind of public interest, the confidentiality of government processes, there has to be weighed another, the need for the public to be fully informed of the actions of those who govern them.

The whole purpose of having effective freedom of information legislation is to ensure that the processes of democratic government are strengthened, that the decisions mady by the bureaucracy which impinge so much on the lives of ordinary Australian people will be open to public scrutiny and that the electorate will have the opportunity to determine the nature of the evidence upon which decisions are made and the nature of the decisions that are made and then make some sensible and balanced judgment about the adequacy of those decisions and the purposes that those decisions are designed to fulfil.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been some years since the introduction of freedom of information legislation was proposed and there is no escaping the fact that the Government has taken a long time to present legislation which seems to find acceptance in both chambers of the Parliament. I suppose that if one looked back upon the years that the matter has been before the House, one could count on one hand the number of letters that one has received demanding that this legislation be implemented. The public interest would probably be best typified by saying that there are only three people in the Speaker's Gallery of this chamber tonight. When one looks at the Press gallery one sees that there is one lone reporter there who is probably wondering what she has done wrong to be sentenced to cover the debate on the Freedom of Information Bill. It is a matter which is of limited interest. I compliment the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Robert Brown) for having such deep compassion on a subject which seems to pass unnoticed by the vast majority of the community. I know, of course, that some people in some areas have had a vital interest in this subject, but there is no escaping the fact that they have been in a teeny-weeny minority overall. As a member of the Government side, I suppose it would be expected that I would be here this evening supporting the Bill in toto.
—You are too honest to do that.

—I appreciate that compliment. Perhaps during the next election campaign the honourable member might care to stand on my platform and tell the people of my electorate just that. I am quite sure that with the earthiness of the honourable member for Hunter, at the next election I would sweep home with a larger majority than even I would have predicted. Whilst this Bill may be seen to have some shortcomings and indeed whilst some senators of the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Country Party may have some difficulty in accepting the legislation in its final form, I ask whether all members of the Parliament recognise that at least we have made steps forward. As far back as the early 1970s, while I was an external student of the University of Queensland and a member of Parliament, I was doing an assignment for the University on this very subject of freedom of information as it existed in the United States. I remember my heart beating fast and thinking how wonderful it would be. That was a decade ago. Those feelings in terms of reasonable access to reasonable information have not abated. However, I believe that honourable members on both sides of the chamber should concede that there is some information which is of a very vital nature and which, if the Government were to believe that it was to become public property the day after, would result in the functions of government suffering. We should be prepared to accept that this legislation goes a long way further than anything we have had before. We should also accept that in the years ahead after the nation has had an opportunity to assess the legislation there will be further chances to amend the legislation if it is found to be necessary and if it is found to have the shortcomings that honourable members on the other side of the chamber are predicting. Indeed, they share a view which is shared even by some members of my own party in the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to make some criticism of the Bill in terms of the various schedules where exemptions exist. I refer particularly to Part 1 of Schedule 2, which classifies exempt agencies. As all honourable members know, Schedule 1 sets out the courts and tribunals which are exempt in respect of non-administrative matters. In Schedule 2 there is a Part I and a Part II, and Part II classifies the agencies exempt in respect of particular documents. It is my view that the Government has been over sensitive in terms of classifying some agencies in Part 1 of Schedule 2. In regard to the Australian Secret Intelligence Service and, indeed, the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation, I have absolutely no argument with the need for the operations of those two organisations to remain private and confidential. The responsible Minister is fully aware of what is going on, and indeed the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) at times is consulted and informed as to the events and happenings in those organisations. But I turn to some other agencies which have been given total exemption. When we give an agency total exemption we are saying that its operations are so vital to the security of the nation that we must expose nothing and that it must all be kept secret. Alternatively, what the Government might be saying when we consider some of the other organisations is that it has forebodings in terms of some of the activities of these organisations becoming known publicly.

I have already said that I completely accept that some agencies deserve exemption in terms of certain aspects of their operations, but let me read through this list of organisations which fall within the same classification as ASIO and the Australian Secret Intelligence Service. I shall refer to them alphabetically. They are: The Aboriginal Lands Councils and Lands Trusts; the Auditor-General; the Australian Industry Development Corporation; the Australian National Airlines Commission; the Australian National Railways Commission; the Australian Overseas Projects Corporation; and the Australian Shipping Commission. The next is the Canberra Commercial Development Authority. We must be careful there! The next ones are the Commonwealth Banking Corporation-it is perhaps a legitimate item in terms of the commercial operations of these entities-the Commonwealth Trading Bank; the Commonwealth Savings Bank; and the Commonwealth Development Bank. The next one is the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories Commission. Nothing of its activities must be known by anybody.

In Schedule 2, Part I, listed just under ASIO, are the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation and the Health Insurance Commission. What a wonderful opportunity that presents to me! I did not even realise that it was in it. During the recess I had the audacity to make criticisms of the Health Insurance Commission over its operations in the financial year 1979-80 which were nearly a bomber. It lost millions of dollars in Queensland and millions of dollars in New South Wales. In Tasmania it lost $600,000-odd. All that saved the Commission in Australia was a profit of $8m in Victoria where it is probably ripping off the people.

I had a solicitor's telegram stating that if I did not withdraw my observations I would be subjected to legal threat. Now, a grievance debate is on tomorrow. I had intended to keep this matter for tomorrow. This is only phase one of what I have in store for tomorrow. That weenie, measly organisation threatened me in a telegram. To defend myself, to prove that I was right, would have eaten up a thousand times my salary increase that was recently granted. Yet, we give the Health Insurance Commission total exemption. I did not realise that I was to be given the opportunity to become so emotionally involved in this argument tonight.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would not test the Chair too far.

—No, Sir, I will not. As I see it the Federal Government has allowed the membership of three private health funds to go to the wall. As those private health funds went to the wall I believe that I have a right, as a member of this Parliament, to question the activities of the Health Insurance Commission.
—They should not intimidate you, either, as a member of Parliament.

—Well, they intimidated me. We will hear more about that in the grievance debate tomorrow when I will have a time to grieve. The Government has given this organisation an exemption. I wonder how many thousands of dollars that organisation spends in legal fees every time somebody has a poke at it or questions its activities. But the organisation is to be written into Schedule 2, Part I of the Freedom of Information Bill. I go on to the rest of the exempt agencies: The Housing Loans Insurance Corporation, the National Debt Commission, the National Labour Consultative Council, the Office of National Assessments, the Pipeline Authority, the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation and the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust. All those organisations I have just alluded to are in the same classification as the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation and the Australian Secret Intelligence Service. How reactionary can we be? Whilst I concede that there may be aspects of the operations of those organisations which because of various reasons should not be open to public scrutiny as closely as this Bill makes so many other areas of Government, I believe that they should be in the second part of Schedule 2.

SPEECH.PARA: Lest it be said that this is the first occasion on which I have expressed that view I say that I expressed it in the Party room when this matter was before the combined joint parties some months ago. I wish that I had realised prior to my rising to speak tonight that the Health Insurance Commission had been included in Schedule 2. I might have made my speech even more powerful than the one I have delivered. Nevertheless, all that aside, I believe that this Bill is a new concept in this country. Australia has not exactly been fast at gripping the nettle. At long last we have something with which to experiment and something to observe. I earnestly hope that if this Bill has the shortcomings that honourable members on both sides of the chamber have predicted as possible, the Government will at least make amendments in line with the changes which can safely be brought about.

Finally, I make this plea concerning the Health Insurance Commission. Indeed, I might even go away and word an amendment to this Bill to delete that organisation from the special section of the schedule. When an organisation resorts to intimidation and threats to a member, I wonder what it has to hide. I wonder whether its activities are as inefficient as I believe. I conclude by drawing to the attention of the House the fact that the cost of administering the Government's health insurance scheme is double or even three times more than that of the private health schemes. It is quite fair to observe that there is a grave possibility that the Health Insurance Commission is bedridden with inefficiency.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was interesting to hear the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) in his tirade against the previous Australian Labour Party Government. It seems to be the stock in trade of Government members to do this sort of thing when they have nothing very much to say.
—He was brought up in a very bigoted fashion indeed.

—Yes, I agree, That is the point. I think he really had nothing to say about the Freedom of Information Bill because, in fact, he is very worried about it. One of the problems with conservative governments is the fact that basically they do not believe in divulging information. The present Government, without doubt the most conservative Federal Government since Federation, is no exception. Because members of this Government do not really believe in freedom of information they have produced a Bill which is full of exemptions and obstacles designed to block the attempts of persons wishing to investigate the activities of government. What is more, despite protests from Opposition members in the Senate, the Government pushed the concluding stages of the debate through on the last day of sitting of the autumn session because it knew that this most unsatisfactory piece of legislation would not be approved by the Senate after 1 July.

SPEECH.PARA: I find it particularly objectionable that the Bill lists in two schedules a number of agencies and documents which are exempt from the requirements of the Bill. I note that the honourable member for Chisholm (Mr Harris) in his speech yesterday also indicated his concern about certain organisations that were exempt. The honourable member for Fadden (Mr Donald Cameron) also in a very brilliant speech which he gave a little while ago referred to certain organisations. I believe he also mentioned some writings that he made as a university student but unfortunately he did not tell us whether he happened to pass that particular exercise.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have a guess.

—I have given the right answer, I think. What justification can there be, for example, for a cloak of secrecy over the activities of the Aboriginal Land Councils and Land Trusts or the National Labour Consultative Council? They are two of the agencies listed in Part 1. No doubt the two classes of people against whom this Government appears to harbour its greatest hostility, namely, the Aboriginals and trade unionists would also like to have that question answered. There are also a number of other bodies included in Part 1. This makes a mockery of the contention by government members that people have the right to know what is being done by government. Whilst it can be argued that there is a need to avoid the disclosure of military information it is of great concern to me and should be a great worry to all freedom loving Australians that the Australian Secret Intelligence Service and the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation are granted complete exemption. The activities of these organisations have frequently been the subject of complaint by many individuals, occasionally even members of this House.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to note the report in the Age newspaper today which refers to an allegation by a member of the New South Wales Parliament that the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation planted the bomb which caused the death of three people outside the Hilton Hotel in Sydney in 1978. The allegation was accompanied by a request for an inquiry on the incident, particularly in view of the fact that no inquest had been held on the three deaths. It should be possible for a serious allegation of this nature to be investigated so that members of the public can feel satisfied that our security agencies are working in the best interests of Australians. It should also be possible in the case of the Hilton bombing to examine the substance of the documents which led to ASIO being granted far greater investigatory powers only three weeks after the bombing incident.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because they planted the bomb.

—Of course, what the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Kent) says is quite right. Such an examination might allay the suspicions of those people who believe that persons acting for ASIO had, in fact, planted the bomb to support the claim that ASIO needed greater investigatory powers and that the bomb had subsequently exploded inadvertently.
—It was so inept that it points to ASIO.

—That is why the matter needs to be cleared up. There can be no justification for such secrecy. I submit that exempting these bodies in such a blanket way means that innocent people can be harassed, browbeaten or even lose their lives as a result of the ignorant and bigoted activities of officials without redress for the individuals concerned or for their families. Another matter which concerns me is the fact that clause 24 of the Bill gives the agency concerned, or the relevant Minister, the power to refuse to grant access to documents on the grounds that the resources of the agency are insufficient to deal with the request without interfering with its normal work. In effect, almost any request for substantial information could be refused on those grounds. It would appear that this clause has been inserted to ensure that any such request which may prove embarrassing to an agency or a Minister can be denied for seemingly innocuous administrative and financial reasons.

SPEECH.PARA: As has been indicated by other critics of this Bill, the Government is not really interested in open government. On the contrary it has shown itself to be obsessed with secrecy. I call on the Government to withdraw this most dishonest piece of legislation and to give honourable members on this side of the House the opportunity to incorporate amendments which will make this Bill a real vehicle for freedom of information. I repeat what was said in the Sun Herald on 12 April 1981 by Peter Robinson:

A much dirtier trick has been the so-called freedom of information bill which, like so much legislation in South Africa, has a practical effect diametrically opposed to what is suggested by its title.
At present the title is a mockery and the provisions will permanently enshrine the present lack of access of the public to the operations of government departments and public authorities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The speech made by the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Donald Cameron) following earlier in the evening the speech made by the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) was, by comparison, a breath of fresh air. The honourable member for Dundas seemed to have the view that it was not possible for a member of Parliament to be pleased that a certain advance be made in a piece of legislation like this without, at the same time, being obliged to form, with his colleagues, some sort of Greek chorus to chant approval of it in every detail or have some set of Barnum and Bailey claqueurs to dance at the back of the show to make sure that the general approval, in all circumstances, was expressed. He was also extremely churlish in his treatment of the record of the Whitlam Government and of the Australian Labor Party on freedom of information questions, this particular legislation and the general question of open government. I do not think there could be any doubt at all that the argument could be sustained that the Whitlam Government's record in office was a dramatic advance in openness on anything that had preceded it since 1949. It is a dramatic improvement and the honourable member's treatment of that was quite churlish.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Dundas then proceeded to go through a list of documents allegedly withheld from the public by the Whitlam Government. I listened fairly carefully to that list but I very much doubt whether one of the items on it would be permitted unfettered disclosure under the terms of the Feedom of Information Bill. If he really is that enthusiastic about the particular items covered in that list and the fact that they ought to be readily available to the public, I look forward to his appearance on this side of the House when we move amendments to that effect later this week. He was quite churlish about the record of the Whitlam Government and its association with this Freedom of Information Bill.

I will not go into it in detail but I refer honourable members to the report on freedom of information by the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. At pages 5 and 6 of the report, the Committee points out quite emphatically that the Labor Party was the first major political party in Australia to commit itself to freedom of information legislation. The Labor Party set up an interdepartmental committee. It needs to be remembered that a majority of Government senators are members of this committee. It was conceded by that majority of Government senators that that committee laid the foundations for the initial efforts of this Government in the freedom of information legislation in 1978. It must also be said that the Whitlam Government was only three years in office. This Government has been in office for six years, and it has had all the advantages of having the groundwork laid by the Labor Government, but it has taken it six years to bring this legislation before the House. I submit that the Labor Party's record on this amply stands in comparison with the record of the Government. It stands particularly in comparison as we look at particular aspects of the legislation.

This is a Bill with many unsatisfactory features, some of which we shall attempt to deal with at the Committee stage. When it was initially presented to the Senate earlier this year the Bill entailed only 20 of the 71 recommendations for a freedom of information Bill that would be compatible with Australia's procedures, Constitution and tradition, made by the Senate Standing Committee which examined the matter in 1978-79. It was a Senate Standing Committee with a Government majority. The Senate amendments have picked up only a few omissions. Many omissions which continue to be ignored are quite critical to the Bill's effectiveness. Most of these omissions appear to be at their most glaring in Part IV of the Bill. I intend to deal with that later.

I now wish to address myself to the matters of principle which the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner) considered in his speech yesterday. As this debate proceeded over a number of years, a line of argument has been produced by Ministers, by sections of the Public Service and by the Queensland Government, in particular, in submissions to the Standing Committee, that this legislation is incompatible with the Westminster system by which we are governed. I still think that some of the trepidation on the other side of the House in supporting the amendments that we will put forward at a later stage is based on similar misconceptions about the operations of the Westminster system as expressed by the Minister. In the course of the debate what is essentially a vague set of governing principles, when compared at least with those based on written constitutions extensively separating executive, legislative and judicial functions, has in this debate assumed a positively mystical aspect. It has inspired definitions of processes which those of us who are supposed to be at the core of the Westminster system in Parliament would find unrecognisable when applied to practice. The Minister has taken the trouble to define the Westminster process in such a manner. He has done so implicitly to excuse the Government's failures to implement substantially some very well thought out recommendations by the Senate Committee and by a number of public interest groups and to justify a vague promise to review the operation of the Act some years in the future.

The Minister's speech, as a lesson in primary school civics, has its merits. Here it is laughable. The Minister invites us to consider the relationship of Ministers to Parliament as an example of information dissemination-he went on about this at some length-which obviates the need for more stringent open government legislation. He said:

In this regard it is significant that Ministers are subject to questioning in Parliament on matters within their ministerial responsibility both without notice and upon notice by members of the Parliament. By second reading speeches on Bills, by their participation in debates, and by making of ministerial statements Ministers also give much information about government activity directly to Parliament.

He could have fooled me. This is a fine statement of theory. It does not take very long in this chamber to recognise that what takes place in this chamber during the processes that the Minister describes, except on the least controversial of matters, is a vigorous stoking of the boilers to lay the thickest possible smokescreen over most aspects of government decision-making. The evasive answer is admired by government supporters. Frankness provokes dismay. Paroxysms of delight ripple through Government ranks when a pointed, information-seeking opposition question draws a raving irrelevant ministerial counter-attack chock full of appropriate ideological red meat. Standing Orders enshrine a Minister's right not to answer questions.

The whole process of a lack of information reminds me of what happened to an old friend of mine, Tom Hartrey, who was a former member for the State seat of Kalgoorlie in Western Australia. He was deputed by the citizens of Kalgoorlie who were then boycotting the pubs in Kalgoorlie to investigate reasons for a beer price rise in Perth. Tom Hartrey went down to investigate the reasons for a beer price rise and subsequently reported back to his thirsty constituents. He said to them on that occasion: 'Ladies and gentlemen, I have been to the Premier to find an answer to the problem that we confront. I have been to the Government to find an answer to the problem that we confront. I have been to the breweries to find an answer to the problem that we confront. I have even been to the Opposition to find an answer to the problem that we confront. I have been everywhere but never has alcohol been so anonymous'. I would suggest that this is precisely the sort of problem that we find ourselves confronted with at Question Time. Never is any aspect of government activity more anonymous than it is when it finally hits this House in the processes so beloved of the Minister in justifying his position on what is supposed to be open government.

The basis of democracy is not responsible government, separation of powers or any other constitutional formula or legislative administrative process. They are tools to create the possibility of an orderly life and the advancement of democratic principles. The basis of democracy is that each individual in society has a right to determine how he or she is collectively governed. Implicit in this is a right of access to information on how decisions are made that directly and indirectly affect our lives. Proper freedom of information legislation would address those questions effectively.

The Westminster system of government as a model is not only vague but also fluid. It changes through time. It exists and its institutions exist in a dialectical relationship with society and are modified in their practice by social change. This process is usually cumulative and imperceptible so that Ministers who rely on textbook formulas may indeed not perceive changes though they are in fact obliged to act on them.

Let us take the question of ministerial responsibility. Westminster theory suggests a process of decision-making which moves from Public Service to Minister to Cabinet and then of explanation from Cabinet to Minister to Parliament to public. The Minister is responsible for his Department to the Cabinet, Parliament and the public. It is many years since this paradigm actually reflected reality. Ministers will not and cannot accept responsibility for all aspects of their Department's operations. How often have honourable members heard Ministers qualify answers to questions posed by the public or in this House with a statement that to the Minister's knowledge, such and such an answer is correct. How often in recent times have Ministers resigned when their inability to exercise fully control of their departments has been exposed? Indeed, in the area of national security policy, largely excluded from this legislation, Ministers have positively wallowed-historically anyway in Australia-in their irresponsibility.
One former Liberal Prime Minister and Minister for Defence was pleased to say about one of the joint US-Australian installations under his direct jurisdiction:
I don't even know what Pine Gap is all about. I didn't then-
That was in 1969-
I could have asked but it didn't arise. I didn't ask about it.

More recently, the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen), who is an ornament to this House and one of the last vocal defenders of the doctrine of ministerial responsibility, was compelled to reveal considerable ignorance of the operations of his Department several years ago when he discovered from a reading of the Press, a significant upgrading of the North West Cape facility. Ministers cannot be expected to be so fully in command of the departments because the areas of government responsibility have expanded so massively since the nineteenth century when most contemporary definitions of the doctrine of ministerial responsibility were devised.

That is not a plea for small government. It is a vital argument for effective freedom of information type legislation as an aid to continued application of democratic principles in a modern industrial society. It is ironic that it is the democratic socialists in this House who are obliged on this legislation, as they are in so many other cases, to carry the liberal case for the rest of the Parliament, as I suggest we did strongly in the senate and as we are doing in this debate in this chamber.

I turn now to one part of the Bill which I think is most unsatisfactory and that is Part IV dealing with exempt documents in particular areas of government responsibility. Almost all the 15 exemptions leave unclear the criteria on which documents will be available to the public. The lack of clarity foreshadows heavy usage of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and the Document Review Tribunal. In particular, I would like to discuss clause 33 dealing with questions affecting national security, defence, international relations and relations between the States. In the first place, it is positively ludicrous that communications between State and Commonwealth governments should be given the same exemption as documents involving national security. I do realise that conservative parties thrive on the prospect of a return to pre-1901 constitutional arrangements. But it would be nice if they kept that strictly to statements of principle rather than incorporating it in their legislation. State conservative governments in particular are obsessive about secrecy and that is one of the major reasons why I suggest that they had this particular section added to clause 33.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you referring to the New South Wales Labor Government?

—I will come to it in a minute. The Queensland Government, for example, has already said that it will not abide by the decisions of the Freedom of Information Act and that it will do everything in its power to preclude correspondence it has from the Federal Government on it. Recently, in Western Australia, some of us were involved in an exercise to try to screw out of the Western Australian Government some information on the materials it had put before the Grants Commission when presenting the Western Australian case. Since the honourable member for Wentworth (Mr Coleman) is so interested in the New South Wales Government and its relationship with its public, I point out that the New South Wales public had a chance 12 months previously to look at their Government's submission to the Grants Commission. The New South Wales Government did not make it a closed document. But the Western Australian Government obsessively gripped the document to its heart and would not reveal a single detail of it to the public. So we were obliged to read through the Grants Commission report and make some sort of assessment of the type of case that the Western Australian Government put to the Commission. One can only say from the results that the case that the Western Australian Government put was extremely weak. So it is no wonder--
—No wonder.

—So it is no wonder at all that that document has not appeared before us. Evidently also there would be bits and pieces of it that would be extremely embarrassing to the Western Australian Government. For example, for the last two or three weeks or a month or so those of us who are active in politics in Western Australia have been obliged to watch the dancing across the screen of the Western Australian Minister for Education as he attempts to conceal various aspects of his Department's operations and the reasons for his making heavy cut-backs in that Department. He has gone to the public and said that we can afford these cuts because we have one of the best student-teacher ratios in Australia. Yet when we go to the Grants Commission documents we discover that a case was made two or three months previously by the Western Australian Government in which it pleaded for extra funds because it said that Western Australians had one of the worst student-teacher ratios in Australia. It is no wonder, therefore, that the Western Australian Government does not want these documents revealed. What a sorry contrast the Western Australian Government is with the Government of New South Wales which includes its people on matters vital to them. And how necessary it is that the Western Australian Government is compelled to face the light of public scrutiny with the sorts of cases it puts forward to the Grants Commission. How sad it is that this Government will not acquiesce to decent amendments to make sure that the Western Australian Government will have to do so in the future.

SPEECH.PARA: I am concerned about the possibilities of a continuation of excessive secrecy in the foreign affairs and defence field. The Opposition is concerned not because it does not agree that a wide variety of intergovernmental communications, technical defence aspects and Public Service assessments ought not to be placed before the public view. Clearly they must not. We had an appalling case last year when a diplomat serving in India had his position compromised by the premature revelation of quite appropriately frank assessments to his Department of the Indian Government. We are concerned, however, because in this area gross abuses have occurred where secrecy has not been based on national security but on naked political advantage. Recently I was privileged to accompany the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence around the various joint United States-Australian installations. I was interested to see a film which is regularly shown to tourists in Western Australia which connects quite directly the operations of the North West Cape installation with United States submarines. Yet, when the legislation to create the North West Cape installation was introduced in this Parliament in 1963, what any old tourist visiting the North West Cape installation now knows was not given to the Parliament or to the public at that time. A piece of information which was vital to an important foreign affairs debate and which was clearly not a matter of national security was concealed for deliberate political purposes.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the commandant says himself that it was never classified.

—That is right. It was an Australian decision, not an American one. This secrecy, particularly when applied to key aspects of the United States alliance, has massively hindered effective public debate on the American alliance and foreign policy and defence issues related to it. This has been despite the fact, or probably because of the fact, that governments have sought to win elections on the issue. We have the ludicrous situation in which any Soviet foreign affairs or defence official or United States congressman is far more likely to know details of many aspects of our relationship with the United States than are Australian parliamentarians and citizens.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation will not make a great deal of difference to this situation. Where the Minister declares under clause 33 that the revelation of a document is not in the public interest there is no provision for overruling his decision. There is a provision whereby documents may be reviewed by a Document Review Tribunal but acceptance of the decisions of the tribunal on the classification placed on particular documents will not be binding on Ministers. We would much prefer a situation such as that which obtains in the United States whereby judicial review can overturn the security classification given to a particular document. The operation of the United States Act in this area provides us with a very useful insight into what the operation of such a system would be here. About 40,000 documents annually are sought from the United States Department of Defense by interested parties. Most of those documents are released. As to those which the Department wishes not to be released, the courts have been very restrained in compelling it to do so. They are loath, as they should be, to overturn a decision which the Department strongly supports. But as the moment of court action nears in the United States, the Department tends to review its classifications and release very substantial amounts of the material without a fight in court, revealing that the material to that point has been overclassified.

As the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones) pointed out, this occurs not only in the Department of Defense and the Department of State but also in much more security conscious departments, such as the Central Intelligence Agency. We ask for nothing more in this legislation than the same rights as are enjoyed by United States citizens, a nation so rightly beloved of honourable members opposite. We invite them to give the Australian public those rights. We will invite them to do that through the legislation we will put forward. We invite them to act like liberals and not people solely devoted to the possession of power, recognising that information is part of power, and wishing to preclude not only us but also the general Australian public from it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hyde Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Freedom of Information Bill is significant for two reasons. First of all, the Bill is significant in its own right. It is also significant because the debate on it has been one of those occasions-regrettably they are rare occasions-when the Parliament has exercised its powers and authority to bring about significant improvement in legislation before it. During the last session of Parliament we debated this Bill, the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Bill and the Airlines Agreement Bills. On those three occasions the Parliament exercised more influence than it has been wont to do for many years. That is significant in itself.

SPEECH.PARA: I come to the Bill. It is useless for the Opposition to decry the Bill and say that it has no significance because it does not do everything that it wishes. The point is that it will improve the democratic processes of this country. For that reason, it is to be supported. Perhaps in time in the light of experience we will make further amendments. Perhaps the government of the day will do so. But let us support this Bill for the time being. Let us use it for the time being. I will endeavour to demonstrate to the House that it will make a significant contribution. Perhaps this Bill would be less necessary if we did not have so much public sector intervention in private lives. In fact if we had less to be informed about maybe we would need the access to information less. It is government's capacity to interfere in the life and freedom of each citizen that makes this sort of democratic process necessary. We ought to think also about curtailing the over-interference of government in the first place.
I would like to quote briefly from the second reading speech of the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner). He said:

This Bill will establish for members of the public legally enforceable rights of access to information in documentary form held by Ministers and government agencies except where an overriding interest may require confidentiality to be maintained.

The basic principles of the Freedom of Information Bill are simple. Firstly, government departments and authorities should make their structures and functions known to the public and publish the rules and guidelines they apply in making decisions affecting members of the public.
Secondly, members of the public are entitled to access to documents held by government departments and authorities unless there are special reasons for not making those documents public.

That is a very good sentiment and I support it. Just to indicate to the House that my support has not come lately, because I wish to use the Bill and the freedom it will give me, I will quote again quite briefly from one of my speeches. On an earlier occasion I said:

And when the Government assumes it is a better judge of individual welfare than are the consumer and producer working it out between them-consider taxi regulations, airlines, shopping hours-then it ought to say how that it is so, which is a reason why most free marketeers favour open government.

I just quote that to establish my credibility in this matter. I invite the House to consider a case study which will demonstrate that this Bill has relevance to the process of government and will in fact be useful. It will be known to honourable members that the jet trunk air routes in Australia are in the hands of two companies-Ansett Airlines of Australia and Trans Australia Airlines-and that these companies operate a duopoly that is to all intents and purposes a monopoly. They are protected from competition and are denied the opportunity to compete with each other except in respect of such relatively unimportant matters as hostesses' uniforms and meals. They are not able to compete with each other on any of the important things such as the price of travel and capacity loading of the aircraft. Even the aircraft they buy have to be approved by the Minister for Transport. There is no reasonable market to discipline these two bodies that provide so much service and disservice to the Australian people. There is no market that will work. The report of the Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Airfares-the Holcroft report-made it quite clear that there was unlikely to be a functional market. In a letter to the Minister for Transport the Holcroft committee said:
. . . Ansett however proved far more spontaneous and the delay in settling the basis of agreement to supply information hampered the Inquiries' operations.
It went on to say:

As the Department of Transport is the regulatory authority for domestic airfares determination in Australia we also found it quite unhelpful that its submission was not received until 10 December, that is, some two weeks after the government had already moved to curtail the Inquiry. This made it impracticable to examine the Department in public hearing. Nor was any written submission received from the Bureau of Transport Economics.

It seems that the people who regulated this section of Australian economic life were less than forthcoming even when there was a government inquiry charged with the job of finding out what they were up to. The Holcroft inquiry at paragraph 1.56 of its report, said:
The Inquiry feels that progressive deregulation of all but safety requirements is the preferred solution.

The point is that the Holcroft inquiry did not believe, whatever happened, that the regulated environment could be made to work properly. It did not believe that a proper market discipline could be applied to these two airlines. The relevance of that point is that in the absence of a market discipline, the only other discipline available is the democratic discipline of complete disclosure. When the Holcroft inquiry reported the Government was not happy with the findings and it appointed Price Waterhouse to make a further inquiry. Price Waterhouse recently reported and came down with a quite radically different formula, but it also agreed that the regulated environment was not likely to work very well. I quote again, this time from the Price Waterhouse report:
A formula which provides a reasonable return to one airline could provide the other with an inadequate profit.

I remind honourable members that in a 12 month period air fares on these routes have risen by 16.7 per cent, a great deal more than the inflation rate, and that those fare increases have been justified from cost. There may be little doubt that the costs were actually incurred, but the relevant questions are whether the costs should have been incurred and whether there was waste and unnecessary featherbedding. However, there is a difference. Price Waterhouse reported its formula and sent it to the Government under separate cover in secret. Unlike the Holcroft formula, the Price Waterhouse formula is secret. Those of us who have been interested in this issue and who have called for deregulation are prepared to accept any reasonable formula. We want an unfettered and free environment, but if we are going to have a regulated environment and we cannot achieve a free environment we will accept a reasonable formula. However, it is necessary that all those calculations be made public or no member of the public should be expected to accept them, particularly when there is such prima facie evidence that it is all inefficient. An increase of 16.7 per cent is a very big increase for one 12-month period. The freedom of information legislation will enable me, other members of this House and all other members of the public to gain access to that fodemocratic discipline where this 'free enterprise' Government has not applied a market discipline. I intend to demonstrate that not from the Bill but from the explanatory memorandum because I believe that is easier to follow, at least for non-lawyers. I read from the explanatory memorandum:
Clause 51 places the onus of establishing that a decision given in respect of a request was justified on the agency or Minister to whom the request was made.

In other words, the onus is on the Minister if he refuses to provide documented evidence. If he does not co-operate, he must then demonstrate that he had a reason not to. I will read again from the explanatory memorandum:

Sub-clause 22(1) accordingly provides that where it is possible and reasonably practicable to prepare a copy of the document with the exempt matter deleted, and the copy document so prepared is not thereby rendered misleading, the applicant shall be given access to such a copy . . .

In other words, if the Minister is able to delete sufficient material from the document so that it does not disclose the information that he is entitled to hold back, he is obliged to provide the rest. The onus is on the Minister to provide the document in as full a form as he can but there are certain areas in relation to which he can hold back information. The explanatory memorandum states:

Sub-clause 43 (1) provides that a document is exempt if its disclosure would disclose trade secrets or other information having a commercial value where the commercial value of that information would be diminished or destroyed by that disclosure. The sub-clause would also make exempt a document which contains information concerning the business or professional affairs of a person or the business, commercial or financial affairs of an organisation or undertaking where the disclosure of that information would unreasonably affect adversely the person, organisation or undertaking in respect of the lawful conduct of his or its business etc.
Sub-clause 43 (3) makes it clear that the protection of commercial privacy given by the clause extends to commercial undertakings carried on by the Commonwealth, a State or the Northern Territory.

However, as it is a regulated duopoly and as the profits of the organisation are guaranteed I do not believe that any information that could be disclosed could possibly be claimed to prejudice the organisation. The Minister must provide a document on request for information. Should he not do so the onus is on him to demonstrate that he is entitled under some clause of the Bill to withhold that information. The Government has commissioned a submission to be presented to it. Price Waterhouse has submitted in secret and yet, as I read the terms of this legislation, once the Bill becomes law the Government will not have the power to withhold the secret formula that has been put forward by Price Waterhouse. I believe that will make it easier for all those members of this House and those members of the public who have a genuine interest in this issue to argue their case, to look at the relevant information and, if necessary, to apply the proper democratic disciplines to the Government.

I understood originally that when Price Waterhouse was to report it was to report publicly. In fact, I understood that all information was to be made public and that the democratic disciplines were to be applied in the absence of the market disciplines. This piece of legislation gives the Parliament and the public the opportunity to ensure that that does, in fact, happen. Mr Deputy Speaker, I have merely taken you and the House through a case study but I believe I have demonstrated that this is useful legislation, that it will contribute to the democratic processes in Australia and that it should be supported.
