DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Interest Rates-Industrial Relations: Trucking Industry-Retirement of Mr F. W. Temperly-Department of Social Security-Poland-Pensions-Community Youth Support Scheme

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Viner) proposed:
That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent Mr L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, before the parliamentary recess I received a letter from one of my constituents and as I think it is of great interest to this House and to the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner) who is at the table I propose to read it. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Mr Kent,
I write to seek your help and assistance if possible in obtaining some form of relief from the situation my wife and myself find ourselves in.

On 28 November 1979 we purchased our first home in Noble Park. The home we bought cost $52,000 of which we had saved a deposit of $14,000 leaving a balance of $38,000. We borrowed the $38,000 from the Commonwealth Savings Bank at 9.5 per cent interest at a repayment of $340 per month which we could just manage. The following details outline the incredible turn of events since that time:
17.2.80 Initial repayment $340 per month for only four months 9.5 per cent
Then to $354 per month for only 3 months 10 per cent
Then to $366 per month for only 5 months 10.5 per cent
17.2.81 Then to $393 per month-current rate 11.5 per cent

Obviously an increase of $53 per month is way beyond our wildest expectations and has us wondering where it will end. The disturbing thing is that all these increases took place in the period of 12 months. We now have to consider whether it is worth staying in our own home or selling up and moving back into a flat or some other rented accommodation. What has happened in the first 12 months of our loan's term has horrified us.
We now ask you the following questions:
1. Is there any form of lower interest loan available to us?
2. Is there any chance of consideration being given to granting us a home savings grant? (The maximum value of the house being purchased was lifted after we bought our home).
3. Is it likely that interest rates will continue to rise and force people out of their homes?

After making 12 payments for a total of $4,252.00 we have just received a letter from the Commonwealth Bank telling us we now owe only $37,916.57 out of the original amount of $38,000 i.e. we have paid off the princely sum of $83.43 in 12 months-what an achievement!!

I am a clerk Class 5 with Australia Post, my wife has not been employed until 2 weeks ago when she commenced work on a temporary basis as a typist because of necessity. We have an 11 year old daughter who is going to high school and now comes home to an empty home which is the one thing we did not want.

We would appreciate any advice you can offer or help you can give to overcome our problem. We really feel strongly that we are entitled to a home savings grant and hope you can arrange for us to receive same. If there is no form of low interest loan available (surely there is some form of Government finance loan at a reasonable rate-even if it covered only a portion of our total loan) maybe there are some Liberal MPs who can make a donation to us to alleviate our desperate situation.
Hoping to hear some good news from you soon.
Yours faithfully,
The letter is signed. It then states:
P.S. We are hoping the worry of this matter will not affect our health as we were forced to cancel our Medibank health insurance on 30.7.80 because the contribution had risen to $27.91 per fortnight.

In view of repeated answers to questions in this House by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr McVeigh) stating that higher interest rates are helping Australians to buy their homes, will they get up in this place and answer the questions of my constituent? For their benefit I repeat the questions asked in the letter:
1. Is there any form of lower interest loan available to us?
2. Is it likely that interest rates will continue to rise and force people out of their homes?

I will be eagerly awaiting the Ministers' answers, especially in view of the fact that since this letter was written interest rates have risen to 12.5 per cent. The family in question now has to pay approximately $420 a months and its plight is even more desperate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —During my maiden speech to this House on 26 February 1981 I made reference to sweetheart deals in industrial relations. In fact, I said:

SPEECH.PARA: These same competitors achieve industrial harmony through sweetheart deals registered through a tame arbitration system. This allows those wage increases to be included in their rise and fall clause of work contracts and so flow on to suffering clients.

I choose to remind the House of that statement tonight in the light of the present Australian Road Transport Federation-Transport Workers Union dispute. The road transport industry has been under severe pressure from industrial action. That is bad for business. The owners want to get off the hook. The simple and time honoured solution is for them to buy their way out of the situation. Consequently, before and during the recent strike the industry continuously stated its desire and intention to pay its workers $20 a week and to provide some other benefits. However, the Federation also said that it required the increase to be approved by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. It has inferred that it takes this action in support of the arbitration system and the notion of the rule of the umpire. It has further inferred that as it is prepared to pay the court is being obstructive in continuing to refuse to rubber stamp the proposal. It encourages the public to see the Arbitration Commission and the Government as the villains of the piece who are unnecessarily obstructing the worker from being granted a legitimate wage claim. This is hypocrisy in the extreme.

The facts are that the trucking industry does not want to pay its workers an extra $20 a week plus benefits and, further, it is probably reasonable to say it cannot afford to do so. The trucking industry is trying to get its customers to pay the increase. In many cases this would follow the traditional and meekly accepted policy of announcing a price increase. The dilemma facing the truck owners is that a large amount of their business is conducted under contracts. These contracts have rise and fall clauses which, in the case of wages, are tied to decisions of the arbitration system. If there is no Arbitration Commission approval there is no increase in contract payments. The change that has occurred since I made my statement in February is that the Arbitration Commission apparently has recognised the grave injustice it does the Australian consumer when it rubber stamps sweetheart deals. I congratulate it for its courage and new-found determination. The Australian consumer is where the buck stops being passed.

Many would argue that the companies that have these large contracts with the trucking firms make large profits and could afford to pay. Unfortunately, their customers, as users of truck freight services, generally deal in consumer goods. They do not have contracts with their clients and can pass on the increased costs at any time. They do so, just as the bread and milk industries, which are direct employers of TWU members, will do so now that they have agreed to pay the increase to TWU members. To overcome the court's resistance, the employer and employee representatives are both now arguing that there has been an increase in work value. To me, an increase in work value infers an increase in productivity. If the productivity increase is equal to the increase in wages there will be no need to pass on cost increases to anyone and the consumer will not suffer. If this is the case, why are the trucking companies so determined to ensure that they can pass on the cost? Irrespective of the evidence now being presented to the Arbitration Commission, the total cost of the wage increase will be passed on. This proves to me that the productivity argument is equally fallacious. The trucking companies are not restricted from paying the wage increase provided they take it from their profits.

I close by saying to the arbitrators: Please continue to remember your responsibility under section 40 of your Act, the Conciliation and Arbitration Act, which says, in part 'the Commission shall act according to equity, good conscience and the substantial merits of the case'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Tuesday the House paid tribute to a very personal friend, Fred Temperly. We reached agreement on both sides of the house that there would be only two speakers, and I honoured that. I would like to place on record my personal and sincere thanks to a very kind friend. I have known Fred since I became a member of this Parliament 12 years ago. He has had something like 26 years service in Hansard. He had a lengthy service inside this Parliament and a splendid military record. He has helped not only me personally as a new member but also many members both in this chamber and in the Senate for a variety of reasons and on a variety of problems which all new members face. I sincerely regret the reasons for his resignation. I think they were unfortunate and unnecessary and if appropriate action had been taken I think his resignation could have been avoided.

SPEECH.PARA: Fred joined the Department of the Interior in 1939 and was promoted to the Parliamentary Reporting Staff as Clerk and Accountant in April 1955. He was promoted to Assistant Reporter, a designation which changed to Administrative Officer in 1968. He held that position until he retired in July of this year. Fred was an extremely dedicated and diligent officer. He helped everybody who went to him for advice and help with courtesy and kindness. This Parliament has lost a very good officer. The members have lost a very good officer. I speak with a great deal of sadness and regret. I conclude by saying that honourable members, honourable senators and officers of the Parliament who worked with Fred and knew him, as I did personally, found him to be a very courteous, helpful and dedicated officer to the Parliament, the reporting staff and the people with whom he worked. I regret to say that unfortunately he was not appreciated at the level he ought to have been. This Parliament has lost a dedicated officer but fortunately I have not lost a friend. I wish Fred and his wife good health and a long and happy retirement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Mr M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I want to talk about the functions of the Commonwealth Employment Service and the Department of Social Security in Kiama which is in my electorate. The reason I draw these matters to the attention of the House is that the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr West) whose electorate adjoins mine has done me the courtesy of discussing them in the local media with his usual incapacity to report accurately the facts. I advised the honourable member for Cunningham that I would be replying to his comments tonight. I regret that he is not in the House. I note that he is now entering the chamber. I welcome him. It is extraordinary that the honourable member should have found himself capable of discussing the closure of the CES office in Kiama without being able to bring himself to concede the fact that the Department of Social Security had opened an office in Kiama to deal with the very issues and the very subjects that he complained would no longer be dealt with because the CES office had been closed.

SPEECH.PARA: For the benefit of the honourable member for Cunningham, who may well have been outside both his and my electorate examining matters in the remoter parts of Australia which appear to interest him more than the realities in both our electorates, I advise him that the Commonwealth Employment Service has given up the functions about which he complained. In fact, they are now performed by the Department of Social Security. This is why there is no longer a CES office in Kiama and why the Department of Social Security has opened an office in Kiama to deal with the very problems that, in fact, the honourable member for Cunningham apparently is unaware have been transferred from one department to the other. It may well be that the honourable member for Cunningham simply did not know that, or it could be that he chose to ignore it when making his statements to the local media.

I draw to the attention of the honourable member for Cunningham the fact that on the first and third Wednesdays of each month the Department of Social Security has a presence in its temporary premises in Kiama-I regret that they are temporary and I think the Department should do something about them-to handle matters relating to unemployment benefits, among other matters, raised by the people of that town. I am advised by the manager of the local social security office that despite the fact there is a big placard outside and despite the publicity generated by the honourable member for Cunningham in my local media during the week, 12 people attended that office today. There is obviously a massive demand for the services of the local social security office. I hope that what the honourable member for Cunningham has done, by his mis-statements, may bring to the attention of many people the fact that this facility is available, rather than the contrary, which is the mistaken public view of the honourable member for Cunningham.

There is no doubt that there is a need for a greater and a more regular presence of the Department of Social Security in Kiama. However, I would point out to the honourable member one simple thing: When the Commonwealth Employment Service was in Kiama it was housed in the only available space, which was up a very sharp flight of stairs. After some discussion with me the Department of Social Security agreed that it would be unreasonable to require pensioners, who use the services of the Department, to walk up those stairs. Ground floor facilities have been established. I hope that those facilities will be more frequently available. It is possible to send matters to the Department of Social Security and CES offices by post. In fact the Department can back-date claims received by post for seven days. So there is no disadvantage to the residents of my electorate by this change of function. The fact that only 12 people managed to turn up to the Department of Social Security clearly indicates--

TALK.START.PARA: —You are more worried about paying the dole than finding jobs.
—Order! The honourable member for Cunningham will resume his seat.
—He is maintaining his usual level of high competence. I suggest we need better services but we have some now.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise in the House tonight the situation in Poland and the need, as I believe it, for the Government to offer substantial assistance at this time to the Polish people. I think there can be no question that the substantial democratic gains made by the Polish people over the last 12 months, largely through industrial activity, are being placed in jeopardy by Poland's economic state. The Polish Government has had considerable trouble in convincing Western banks to re-schedule its debts. Poland has had considerable trouble in securing the amounts it needs from the most immediate Western nations in immediate assistance to feed its people. The problem of the shortage of food is a particular crisis.

SPEECH.PARA: Since World War II the Polish regime has been faced with popular revolt when food supplies are short or when prices substantially increase. In the past this has posed problems of survival for rigid communist regimes. It now poses a problem of survival for the liberalised Polish regime and for the general reforms that have been achieved, largely in an orderly fashion. As it happens, the principal need of the Polish people in foodstuffs is meat and sugar. Meat and sugar are staples of the Polish diet. In this, Poland is different from other nations in central and eastern Europe, where cereals form the basis of the diet. In the Polish case, meat and sugar are the staple diet. As I have said, it is no accident that when there have been shortages of meat or meat prices have risen that has been the point at which the Polish people have found the Government or the system in which they are operating least sustainable. It is no accident therefore that, at this point, the Polish people should be in a state of revolt.

I am reliably informed that at this time we have in this country reasonable stocks of meat and sugar. We are in a position to offer immediate and substantial aid to the Polish people. The Opposition has raised the Polish question in this House on a number of occasions. The Government has expressed sympathy for the plight of the Polish people. The time has come for people to put their money where their mouths are. In the developments in Poland, we have rightly seen a major advance in democratic principle, a major advance in the rights of people to organise industrially, the right of people to have a say in their own affairs-rights it must be said in regard to which members on the other side of the House do not necessarily offer the same degree of sympathy when they are sought in this country. Nevertheless, members on both sides of the House have welcomed those developments in Poland. Those developments need to be sustained. They can only be sustained if the population is secure in the belief that the governing processes that they have recently established for themselves are capable of delivering to them their basic needs. We all understand that in a period of chaos there will be many areas of dislocation. These areas may continue for some considerable time. We need to be sympathetic to that and to adopt a generous attitude towards it.

We have made available to the Polish people about $40m in credit for wool sales. In fact that is not a particularly generous offer and I understand it has not yet been taken up, although negotiations are proceeding. We can do a lot better than simply offer the Polish people a guarantee which they will in large measure wish to meet and repay themselves. We can do better than that. I think we need to make an outright grant, not a grant of credits, from our substantial stocks of meat and sugar.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak tonight about the Government's policy of taxing means tested pensions. Pensions in this country are without doubt only paid to those who are judged poor enough by a means test to qualify them.
—That was Gough Whitlam's policy. You introduced it.
—A heavy burden of the Government's taxation policy on pensioners falls on lone parents who choose to work at casual or part time rates.
—Absolute nonsense.

—I am very glad that the Treasurer (Mr Howard) is here tonight to hear what I have to say. The present policy in fact acts as a disincentive for lone parents to join the work force and re-establish themselves as effective contributors to their family's well being. I wish to describe briefly the situations of two of my constituents who have called on me for help. These two women are both supporting parents with two and three children respectively. To augment their widows' pensions, they have obtained employment with a catering firm on a casual basis. This employment requires them to accept particular assignments at very short notice. By dint of accepting any work offered to them, both women have established regular work on a part time basis with this catering firm. This has enabled them to maintain a home and provide some of the requirements of their growing children. However, such employment by its very nature is casual. When the firm has a job, the employee is contacted and expected to take the work. Under these circumstances it is very difficult to average out a weekly income.
—Impossible.

—Some time may pass with no income at all. As the honourable member for Lilley says, it is impossible. At other times there is a lot of work. The arrival of the annual group certificate then becomes an object of dread for these women. If they are over the acceptable amount, they lose their fringe benefits-a vital security for all pensioners. The fringe benefits scheme, which undoubtedly can be calculated to an amount each week in money, is far more than this to a lone parent. It is security for health care for their children and themselves, their travel and communication and in fact any disaster, which intrudes on their lives, which must be severe because of their lone status.

SPEECH.PARA: Of necessity, these women must have a telephone so that they may be informed of jobs. They must have a car to travel to these jobs, which frequently involve late night bookings. Under the circumstances of their employment, they are in such a bind that they cannot refuse work or the employment itself will be threatened. But if they do not refuse it they are likely each year to be a few dollars over the allowable income level and thus forfeit their fringe benefits.

Lone parents such as these are already economically disadvantaged. They still have to pay the same amount for most services and facilities that are available to two-parent families, and are usually more in need of such services as child care, home services and maintenance costs. I suggest that in these circumstances the Government's policy of taxing income which augments a pension is too inflexible. These women are in a situation in which they are virtually forced to refuse work offered by their employer and run the risk of losing their jobs, or must give up the struggle and become totally unemployed.

Individual millionaires and large companies are able to record massive profits year after year without any additional taxation being paid. Tax avoidance on a grand scale as we know it exists in this country, is out of the question for the recipient of a social service pension, who must face deductions from the pension for every dollar earned over the acceptable limit. I suggest that when a pensioner who brings home $106 a week thereby loses the vital security of fringe benefits our society has lost all compassion.

As Government members have been quoted in this House as saying, the concept of fairness also implies that tax should be levied according to capacity to pay. I suggest that a single parent with a combined pension-employment income of $106 a week has no capacity to pay income tax, and that the ever impinging threat of loss of fringe benefits is an emotional problem of great intensity for those single parents who are fortunate enough to be able to find some outside, paying employment. I urge the Government to lift the levels of allowable income which may be earned by pensioners without loss of fringe benefits.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to protest on behalf of that most abused and neglected section of our society today, our unemployed teenagers. At the moment these poor kids do not have much with which to make life comfortable or happy, but what they have had has been taken away from them. I refer, of course, to the termination of the Community Youth Support Scheme. Government money should be spent on the creation of jobs for young people, but in the absence of such action, there was one area which was assisting a number of young people who, psychologically, were falling apart--
—An extra $24m is to be provided for that purpose.
—An extra 22 per cent is to be provided. Don't you read?
—What an absolute liar the Treasurer is.
—Order! The honourable member for Lilley will resume her seat. The honourable member for Fremantle will withdraw.
—Withdraw what?
—The honourable member will withdraw his interjection. The Chair does not propose to repeat it.
—In deference to the Chair, I withdraw.

—The one area in which some funding was going to the support of kids who psychologically were falling apart because they could not obtain work-and I am talking about reality, about people whom I know in my electorate and like people in many other electorates--
—What are their parents doing?

—Quite often, as the privileged may not realise, there are parents who have turned their children away, or children who have come to live in the city and are without parental support. In my area they are spending the night at hostels which are run by the Roman Catholic church, and during the day they are wandering around. They are street kids and no doubt Government members wish that they would simply disappear, just as many Government members wish that the Aborigines would disappear when they call for land rights; but they will not disappear. They exist and they are a problem of which all social workers and concerned persons are aware. To date they have been turning to the Community Youth Support Scheme. In my electorate there are projects at Deagon and Windsor. I have been in touch with project officers there today. They are as appalled as I am that the support has now been withdrawn. Hundreds of young people have been gaining some sort of support. They get some training. Some go to jobs from that training. The terrible cycle of desperation which grasps people when they cannot get a job has been broken by the work of these CYSS projects. Those who do not go on to other work can learn leather tooling and different arts and crafts. There is companionship and an awareness that other people are in the same boat as they are. It sustains them until such time as we can offer these young people full employment.

SPEECH.PARA: Those under 16 years of age get only $36 a week. These young people are living below the poverty line. They will become the street kids of Brisbane. I am not drawing a fanciful picture; it is a real problem. I am sorry if I am not coherent, but it upsets me that this has happened. I condemn the Government for what it has done. I do not know what is up with Government supporters and how they can face each other. I call on them to reverse this decision until such time as these young people are able to gain employment instead of putting them on the scrap heap of the unemployed and placing them in this circle of desperation. Government supporters should be ashamed of themselves. These people are only young; they are not adults yet. It is a shame that I am saying this to a handful of grinning people who think 'Ha, ha, how funny'. I will fight for these people in the area, and they will not give up on stirring up public opinion until all people in the Government know that they are not bludgers and that they are not to be scorned. These young people are the greatest resource of this nation and they should be supported.

(4) 'Grievance' Debate Standing Order 106 to be amended to read-

106. Notwithstanding the preceding standing order, the first order of the day, government business, on each alternate sitting Thursday commencing with the first sitting Thursday after the Address in Reply to the Governor-General's Speech has been adopted shall be a question to be proposed by the Speaker ''That grievances be noted'' to which question any Member may address the House or move any amendment. If consideration of this question has not been concluded at 12.15 p.m., the debate thereon shall be interrupted and the Speaker shall put the question.
Mr Sinclair to move-
That, unless otherwise ordered, the following sessional orders to provide for the operation of estimates committees be adopted:

Committal and consideration in estimates committee: (1) After the speech of the Leader of the Opposition, or a Member deputed by him, on the motion for the second reading of the main Appropriation Bill for a year, the proposed expenditures for the Departments and services contained in the Schedule to that Bill may be referred to an estimates committee. Such referral shall be on motion, moved by a Minister, of which notice has been given. A committee may be ordered to report by a specified date.

(2) There shall be 6 Estimates Committees to be known as Estimates Committees, A, B, C, D, E and F, which shall not vote on, but shall examine and report upon proposed expenditure for the Parliament, Advance to the Minister for Finance and each Department of State; such report may contain a resolution or expression of opinion of the committee but shall not vary the amount of a proposed expenditure.

Members: (3) Each estimates committee, to consider each proposed expenditure, shall consist of the Minister responsible in the House of Representatives for the proposed expenditure under consideration, together with 10 Members, excluding the Chairman.

(4) Members of an estimates committee shall be nominated by either the Prime Minister, the Leader of the House the Government Whip or the deputy Whip and either the Leader of the Opposition, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the Opposition Whip or the deputy Whip and every nomination of a member of the committee shall be forthwith notified in writing to the Speaker.

(5) In nominating Members to an estimates committee to consider each proposed expenditure regard shall be had to the qualifications and interest of those Members nominated and to the composition of the House. Either the Prime Minister, the Leader of the House, the Government Whip or the deputy Whip and either the Leader of the Opposition, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the Opposition Whip or the deputy Whip, shall have power to discharge from time to time any of those Members nominated by them and to nominate others in substitution for those discharged. The responsible Minister may nominate another Minister to act for him as required.

(6) The nomination of Members to consider the proposed expenditure of each department or service shall be announced to the House as soon as practicable after the proposed expenditures have been referred to a committee.
Chairman: (7) The Chairman of an estimates committee shall be- (a) the Chairman of Committees; or
(b) a Deputy Chairman of Committees to be appointed by the Chairman of Committees.

(8) The Chairman of Committees, a Deputy Chairman of Committees of any member of the committee shall take the Chair temporarily whenever requested so to do by the Chairman of the Committee during a sitting of that comittee.

Quorum: (9) The quorum of an estimates committee shall be 5, excluding the Chairman, and, if at any time a quorum be not present, the Chairman shall suspend the proceedings of the committee until a quorum be present, or adjourn the committee.

Participation by other Members: (10) Members of the House, not being members of the committee, may participate, at the discretion of the Chairman, in the proceedings of the committee, but shall not vote, move any motion or be counted for the purpose of a quorum.

Minutes of Proceedings: (11) All proceedings of a committee shall be recorded by the Clerk to the Committee, and such records shall constitute the Minutes of Proceedings of the committee, and shall be signed by the Clerk to the Committee.

Proceedings in estimates committee: (12) Consideration of proposed expenditures in an estimates committee shall follow, as far as possible, the procedures observed in a committee of the whole with the following exceptions:
(a) Speech time limits and the restriction on the number of times a Member may speak to each question (S.O. 91) shall not apply.
(b) Voting shall be taken by a show of hands; tellers shall not be appointed.
Time limits on Report: (13) During consideration in the House of the reports from estimates committees, the maximum period for which a Member may speak shall be-
Each question before the Chair-
Ministers-Periods not specified
Any other Member-10 minutes.

Report from estimates committee and further consideration: (14) A report of an estimates committee shall be presented by the Chairman of that committee or a member of the committee deputed by him and shall contain any resolutions or expressions of opinion of the committee.
(15) On a report from a committee being presented, a future day shall be appointed for taking the report into consideration.
(16) On the calling on of the order of the day for the consideration of a report from an estimates committee, the following question shall be proposed in respect of each proposed expenditure:
'That the proposed expenditure be agreed to (and that the resolution(s) or expression(s) of opinion agreed to by the committee in relation thereto, be noted)'.
(17) Upon the completion of consideration of the reports of estimates committees, the question shall be proposed forthwith-'That the remainder of the Bill be agreed to'.
(18) When an Appropriation Bill which has been referred to an estimates committee is finally agreed to by the House, a future day shall be fixed, on motion, for the third reading.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: German Age Pensions

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs upon notice, on 4 December 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the claim in the periodical Die Woche of 23 September 1980 that the Constitutional Court of Karlsruhe has ruled that Australian citizens of German origin are entitled to German old-age pensions.
(2) Is there any substance to this claim.
(3) If so, will he make appropriate representations to the Government of the Federal Republic of Germany to ensure prompt payments.

(4) If not, will he make representations to the Government of the Federal Republic of Germany that contributory pension entitlements should not be lost when the eligible person becomes an Australian citizen.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answers to the honourable member's questions are as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) Yes. On 23 March 1979, the Federal Republic of Germany's Constitutional Court in Karlsruhe ruled that the present situation whereby people who renounce their German nationality and live abroad lose their entitlement to a German pension is not in accordance with the basic law of the Federal Republic of Germany.

The Constitutional Court has now asked the Federal Pensions Office in Berlin to work out a system enabling pensions to be paid to former German citizens abroad. The Pensions Office is at present working on this but cannot say when the system will be in place. It has stated that the proposed system would probably take the form of a pension based on contributions paid within the present borders of the Federal Republic of Germany since 1945, thus not including contributions paid before 1945 in the former German Reich or after 1945 in parts of the Reich not now part of the Federal Republic of Germany for example the German Democratic Republic. Applications for payment of such pensions cannot yet be approved since enabling legislation has not yet been drafted.
(3) and (4) See (2). Under the circumstances representations would not be appropriate at this time.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Recruitment of Skilled Labour from Overseas

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hawke Mr R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 4 December 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: Further to the commitments he gave in a speech to the Oil and Gas Conference on 1 December 1980 in Perth, Western Australia, what procedures or regulating machinery does he maintain to ensure that recruitment of skilled labour from overseas is restricted to those employers who maintain maximum apprenticeship levels and training effort.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Approval of applications for immigration, including employment nominations, is the responsibility of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. The Department of Employment and Youth Affairs assists in the provision of occupational information and is consulted, where appropriate, on matters relating to worker entry.

Overseas recruitment by Australian employers is dependent upon a prior canvass by them of the Australian labour market, together with clear evidence that they have a satisfactory training record. Where employers are not considered to have a satisfactory training record, approval to recruit overseas would not normally be given.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Rural Finance

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kerin Mr J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 4 December 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the total avenues of finance available to the rural sector.
(2) What are the interest rates and terms of the loans or facilities available from the instrumentalities referred to in part (1).
(3) What has been the increase in rates of interest and terms of loans over each of the last 10 years.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There is a wide range of sources from which finance is made available to rural producers in Australia. Rural producers have access to certain institutions and facilities designed explicitly to provide finance for the rural sector, as well as to sources of finance available to the community more generally.

For more detail I refer the honourable member to the Bureau of Agricultural Economics (BAE) publication 'A Review of Credit in the Australian Rural Sector (1977)' which gives a comprehensive list of these sources to that time. (See in particular Chapter 4 and Attachment E.) Since that BAE study another institution-the Primary Industry Bank of Australia Limited-has been established to refinance loans made to primary producers by banks and other lenders. Another relevant summary reference is the occasional table 'Estimated Rural Debt to Specified Lenders' published most recently on page 331 of the Reserve Bank Statistical Bulletin for December 1980.

(2) and (3) Historical data of interest rates charged on term loans, farm development loans and overdrafts by major trading banks and on rural loans by the Commonwealth Development Bank of Australia are produced in Tables EIV and EX on pages 154 and 162 respectively of the BAE publication. The following figures provided by the Reserve Bank of Australia update these records. Loans refinanced by the Primary Industry Bank of Australia Limited currently carry maximum interest rates of 12.0 per cent per annum for loans of less than $100,000 and 13.75 per cent per annum for loans of $100,000 and above.
INTEREST RATES CHARGED ON OUTSTANDING TERM LOANS, FARM DEVELOPMENT LOANS AND OVERDRAFTS BY MAJOR TRADING BANKS
(a) Includes both large and small loans (the threshold was $50,000 from 4 February 1972 and $100,000 from 1 February 1976).
(b) Overdrafts drawn under limits of $50,000 and over from 4 February 1972 and $100,000 and over from 1 February 1976 are specifically exempted from the prescribed maximum interest rate requirement.
(c) Since January 1980, all banks have submitted returns as at the second Wednesday of July and January.

(d) The maximum overdraft rate was raised to 12.5 per cent on 3 December 1980. Banks currently charge a range of rates within that maximum and interest rate concessions are being granted to certain primary producers adversely affected by drought.
COMMONWEALTH DEVELOPMENT BANK OF AUSTRALIA INTEREST RATES ON NEW RURAL LOANS
(a) Basic rate for rural loans (the Development Bank also makes 'farm build-up' loans which have generally carried a rate 0.5 percentage points lower than the basic rate).
(b) The rates quoted are flat rates.
(c) These rates were increased in December 1980 to 11.50 per cent and in April 1981 to 12.0 per cent.
(d) These rates were increased in December 1980 to 8.75 per cent flat and in April 1981 to 9.0 per cent flat.

The terms of loans available vary between institutions and types of finance and depend on a number of factors, including, for example, the purpose and size of the loan and the borrower's circumstances. Terms may also be renegotiated in the light of special factors such as drought.
The Term Loan Fund, established in 1962, initially provided loans for fixed periods varying from 3 to 8 years; this was changed to 3 to 10 years in 1978.

The Farm Development Loan Fund was establshed in 1966 with a view to facilitating access to medium to long term finance for periods generally ranging from 8 to 12 years. Finance from the Commonwealth Development Bank of Australia is usually made available by way of medium to long term loans repayable over a period suited to the circumstances of each individual borrower; equipment finance is generally for terms of 3 to 4 years. Loans refinanced by the Primary Industry Bank of Australia Ltd are for terms of between 8 to 30 years (currently averaging about 16 years). Loans from other sources would generally be for shorter terms than those provided by the abovementioned institutions.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Importation of Communications Equipment

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Innes Mr U.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 24 February 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: What factors prevent the application of a general prohibition on the importation of those types of communications equipment, the use of which is illegal.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: There are no factors preventing the introduction of import controls on specific communications equipment which cannot be used legally in Australia. ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Transport: Special Arrangements for Disabled Persons

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 24 February 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In view of the fact that 1981 is designated as the International Year of Disabled Persons, what special arrangements has his Department made to assist disabled persons.

(2) Do any special arrangements made include (a) increased employment of disabled persons and (b) improved access for disabled persons to any building or other facility occupied by his Department; if so, what are the details.
(3) What budgetary allocations were made in 1980-81 to facilitate any special arrangements for disabled persons in his Department.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The special arrangements made to assist disabled persons can be seperated into two areas. First, programs specifically introduced because of the International Year of Disabled Persons (IYDP) and second, programs focusing on the needs of the disabled but not specifically initiated for IYDP.
(i) Programs specifically introduced because of IYDP:

The Department of Transport convened a workshop on transport planning and research and the handicapped in March 1981. The workshop enabled the transport planners who attended from all States and Territories to discuss Australian and overseas developments and generally review developments in making land transport services more accessible to the disabled. The workshop will report to the July 1981 meeting of Australian Transport Advisory council (ATAC), and will advise on the need for a common code of practise to meet the transport needs of the disabled.

The Commonwealth undertook to disseminate to all State and Territory Governments results of current initiatives in this area ranging from staff awareness programs, paratransit trials, vehicle restraint research, parking provisions, and low-cost modifications to fixed route systems. As a result of the workshop, the Commonwealth will look at possible ways to encourage greater utilisation of existing fleets of specialised vehicles for the disabled, as well as the possibility of reducing the costs of audio-tactile aids through bulk ordering.

In February I held a meeting with members of the Australian Council for rehabilitation of the Disabled (ACROD) to discuss problems associated with the use by the disabled of airports and airline services. The agenda covered among other issues, classification of people with disabilities, certificate of fitness for regular air travellers, use of personal wheelchairs on aircraft, use of Row Number One seats in aircraft, adequacy of airport wheelchairs, modification of new aircraft, staff training for the disabled, and responsibility for terminal facilities. As a consequence of the meeting Departmental officers will act as liaison officers between the airlines and ACROD to discuss the issues raised.
The Department is also preparing a brochure to inform the disabled of facilities and services available to them at all major airports.

The Office of Road Safety is undertaking a research project on the restraint of the disabled in motor vehicles; the aim of the project being to increase the use of suitable occupant restraints by disabled persons through simple design improvements and propagation of information on 'best practise'. A guidelines booklet may be produced for circulation to hospitals, organisations for the disabled, and parents.
(ii) Programs focusing on the needs of the disabled but not specifically initiated for IYDP:

Under the Transport Planning and Research program, the Commonwealth has provided financial support to the States for a number of projects related to transport and the disabled. Between 1975 and 1981, Commonwealth support to the States for such projects, which is provided on a dollar for dollar basis, has amounted to almost $100,000.
New airport design and construction incorporates the requirements of the Australian Standard 1428 of 1977, 'Design Rules for Access by the Disabled'.
The Office of Road Safety has a continuing responsibility in accident and disability prevention and maintains a public awareness and education program.
There have been no special arrangements made to assist disabled persons employed in the Department.
(2) (a) Special arrangements made to increase employment of disabled persons in the Department:

The Department co-operates with the Public Service Board through its Special Placements Scheme. In 1980, six officers-three permanent and three temporary-were placed in Central Office, Canberra, under the program and a further three are employed in the New South Wales Regional Office.

Victoria/Tasmania Regional Office is participating in a survey initiated by the Regional Director's Office of the Public Service Board, to identify base grade clerical/administrative and keyboard positions which could be suitably staffed by the disabled.

Since August 1980 a permanent officer, Clerk Class 8, has been given duties covering the Equal Employment Opportunity (EEO) area. It is foreshadowed that policy recommendations espousing the EEO philosophy will emanate from this area and have a significant input in to recruitment, selection and personnel development procedures. The employment of the disabled and their needs as employees will come into this area.

An ancillary function of the Departmental EEO officer has been to co-ordinate activities relating to IYDP. One significant project being planned is an education program directed at staff with the purpose of sensitising staff to an awareness of the disabled, their rights as individuals and citizens, and the causes and prevention of disablement.

The Department is aware of the needs of the disabled in their use of facilities for which it is responsible. The example given of Departmental adherence to the Australian Standard 1428 of 1977, 'Design Rules for Access by the Disabled', in the construction of airports has in recent years increased access for the disabled in their use of air transport.

The Department has notified airlines that certain procedures and training in respect to the carriage of handicapped persons are to be adopted. The procedures were introduced from 30 September 1979 and Air Navigation Orders, Sections 20.11 and 20.16 are being amended accordingly.
(3) No budgetary allocations were made in 1980-81 to facilitate any special arrangements for disabled persons working in the Department.

All projects and programs undertaken either specifically for IYDP, or in consideration to the general needs of the disabled, have been funded within the normal budgetary allocations of the particular Division or Region involved.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Viner The Hon R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The Government having reviewed the Industrial Relations Bureau's functions decided that the Bureau should be maintained.
The Government believes that the Bureau is operating with increasing effectiveness.
For the nine months to 31 March 1981 the Bureau had completed 20,400 award inspections, detected 13,400 breaches and recovered $977,000 for employees.
Since its inception the Bureau has received more than 1,000 inquiries concerning the Act and the Regulations of which over 450 related to the rights of individuals as members of organisations.

Moreover, the Bureau's capacity to carry out its functions has been strengthened by decisions of the High Court affirming the validity of legislation designed to protect the rights of individuals as members of organisations.
The Bureau has taken a number of recent initiatives, including recourse to the courts to safeguard and to protect the rights of individuals including self-employed persons.
Furthermore, it is evident that as the work of the Bureau becomes better known and understood, more individuals and organisations are taking advantage of its existence and its powers.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Human Rights

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 4 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was it stated in a speech delivered on his behalf in December 1980 that political self-interest requires developed countries to work energetically to solve the problems of north-south relations and that the humanitarian case based on terrible suffering and degradation in the Third World is unanswerable.

(2) Is it a fact that (a) Australia's import controls are growing and (b) there has been a declining proportion of gross domestic product (GDP) allocated by his Government to foreign aid for Third World suffering; if so, does this accord with his expressed view.
(3) Can he say whether Aboriginal communities in Australia are suffering degradation comparable to those of the Third World.

(4) Has there been a decline in real value and a decline in the share in total or per capita of GDP allocated to Aborigines and other Australians living below various poverty lines; if so, has this added to the suffering and degradation of Aboriginal communities in Australia.
(5) Is an increasing share of GDP being taken by large undertakings along with increased government allowances, exemptions and other financial incentives to them.
(6) Are levels of tax avoidance and evasion growing.

(7) Is a record proportion of Australia's GDP being expatriated to service capital investment and to cover transfer pricing arrangements and invisible imports such as freight and insurance paid to associates of foreign-controlled companies in Australia.
(8) Are Aborigines in Queensland and Western Australia suffering increasing encroachments in their land and are they unable to achieve equal pay or voting rights through legal action.
(9) If the position is as stated in part (5) to (8), have his Government's policies contributed to this position.
(10) Did the speech referred to in part (1) recognise the foreign trade benefits to Australia and the impetus to productivity gains which accompany increased aid and less restrictive trade policies.

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes, in the address I gave to the Commonwealth Club in Adelaide on 9 February 1981.

(2) (a) Industries Assistance Commission figures show that the average effective rate of assistance in aggregate of Australian manufacturing industry has fallen from 36 per cent in 1968-69 to an estimated 26 per cent in 1978-79 and has not risen in recent years.
(2) (b) Yes. The Government's policy is to make best efforts to achieve an aid volume of 0.7 per cent of GDP.
(3) No meaningful comparison can be made.
(4) Insufficient information is available to make the necessary calculation.
(5) No official information is available on the share of GDP accruing to 'large undertakings'.

(6) The Budget Papers estimated identified revenue short-falls for 1978-79 and 1979-80 due to tax avoidance activity at $230m and $280m respectively. An allowance of $300m for reduction in, or deferment of, collections attributable to the use of tax avoidance schemes was included in the 1980-81 Budget estimates. Available statistics do not permit the amount of tax being evaded to be estimated with any degree of accuracy.

(7) Information in the degree of detail required is not available. Balance of payments statistics indicate that Australia's net deficit on invisible transactions has been a fairly steady proportion of GDP since the late 1960's.
(8) The Government's record in respect of land rights and other support for Aboriginal people is well known.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Conservation of Endangered Species on Christmas Island

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Mr B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 5 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: What action has the Government taken on each of the 23 recommendations contained in the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation on the conservation of endangered species on Christmas Island presented to the House on 24 October 1974 (Hansard, page 2838).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: My Department has provided the following information in consulation with the Department of Administrative Services and the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service, on the position as at June 1981.

(1) Fields 22A and 22B remain untouched and the sensitive areas of Field 22B and parts of Murray Hill have been included in a National Park which was declared in 1980. The remainder of Field 22B is not planned for clearing.

Any clearing in Field 22A is still subject to the outcome of any decisions which may flow from a detailed expert panel appraisal of a survey (1979-80) of Abbotts Booby. Decisions on the expert panel's recommendations are expected before a moratorium which has been placed on the clearing of Field 22A and certain other fields expires on 31 August 1981.

Sections of Fields 22C, 23A and 23B were selectively cleared between November 1976 and September 1978 in line with plans and procedures agreed between representatives of Government and the British Phosphate Commissioners (BPC) at the time. Fields 22C and 23B are now part of computer block area 22C with respect to which the expert panel has made recommendations.

(2) This suggested procedure was generally instituted and sections of Fields 26 and 27 were selectively cleared in accordance with plans mutually approved by the parties (on the advice on the Government Conservator and BPC Conservation Officer) commencing July 1977. These areas are quite large, and judicious and approved clearing in sections of these fields has continued from time to time except during relevant moratoriums. The recent expert panel report has confirmed and recommended that clearing in these two fields should be permitted to proceed according to agreed plans.
(3) Clearing is undertaken between late November and early March to the extent that this is practicable.

(4) An inquiry into the long-term future of the Island is currently being undertaken, on behalf of the Government, by Mr W. W. Sweetland. The inquiry will, inter alia, examine and report on the resources of Christmas Island and on appropriate machinery for the planning and control of the use of resources, particularly land.

(5) and (6) Mining guidelines have now been in use for a number of years. An Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service (ANPWS) officer has been appointed to manage the National Park on the Island. He has also been appointed Conservator to advise and assist the Administrator, and indirectly the BPC, on conservation matters and in the consideration of mining proposals. BPC also employs a Conservation officer. An Island Conservation Committee consisting of the Administrator, the BPC Island Manager, the BPC Conservation Officer, the Conservator and other senior BPC and Administration officers meet regularly to consider all conservation and environment issues.

A selective jungle clearing procedure was adopted by BPC around the time of the 1974 report and has been in operation ever since. It involves the submission of detailed plans for areas to be cleared for mining together with a plot of Abbott's Booby sites. The areas proposed for clearing are walked and traversed to confirm the presence of Booby sites before the submitted plans are approved.
The approval process involves amongst others the Administrator, Island Manager, BPC Conservation Officer and the Government Conservator on Christmas Island.
The detailed plan for each field is approved and signed before clearing operations commence in the area under consideration.

The Christmas Island National Park, covering the south-west portion of the Island, was proclaimed under the National Parks and Wildlife Act 1975 by the Governor-General on 19 February 1980 and gazetted on 21 February 1980.
(7) There is a ban on the use of firearms and poaching is policed by the authorities. Successful prosecutions have been made against poachers.

(8) The Conservator referred to in (5) and (6) above has, as part of his functions, the role of disseminating information and increasing the awareness of Island residents on conservation issues. A series of posters depicting the fauna and flora of Christmas Island has been prepared and given wide distribution.
(9) BPC's policy of clearing for these purposes observes this recommendation.

(11) and (12) Backfilling and replanting are being undertaken by BPC, under the supervision of BPC's Conservation Officer. Tree nurseries have been expanded and planting of some mined-out areas has taken place.
(14) Turtle poachers have been prosecuted but the isolated beach areas make policing difficult.
(15) Not applicable. The Radio Australia proposal was not pursued.
(16) Few fires occur. BPC has a fire station at Drumsite and trained fire officers.

(17) The Prohobited Imports Ordinance 1977 was made to prohibit the entry into the Territory of, inter alia, animals, including birds, unless the Administrator has granted permission for their entry. The Administrator is empowered to specify conditions to be complied with by the applicant.
The Importation of Dogs and Cats Ordinance 1973 was also amended in 1977 to prohibit the entry by air of those animals.

The Endangered Species Ordinance 1980 has the effect, inter alia, or prohibiting the entry of any specimen of an endangered species likely to affect adversely the survival of any of the Island's endangered species.

(18) The Christmas Island Administration is extremely conscious of the need to protect native fauna. In 1975 an expert from the CSIRO Division of Wildlife Research was engaged to remove the threat of abandoned domestic dogs running wild. His advice has formed the basis for subsequent programs to eradicate semi-wild dogs and cats. Procedures have been laid down for strict control of stray dogs and cats.
(19) Powerlines are kept to a minimum over open expanses of water.
(20) Except in a few instances where tracks have been kept open for conservation and similar purposes the jungle has been allowed to overgrow the transect and survey lines.
(21) An incinerator has been erected and provision has been made for the burying of solid waste in safe mined-out areas.

(22) Some progress has been made. A number of scientific experts have made visits to the Island in recent years to study the Abbott's Booby, the Imperial Pigeon, plant fauna, fish fauna, land crustacea including the Robber Crab, and introduced ant species.

(23) Apart from the educational activities referred to at (8), the Conservator has assisted in the setting up of a Natural History Society to serve as a focus for community concern for the conservation of endemic wildlife species. Close involvement with the local school on environmental education has been developed and student excursions to the park and other natural areas of the Island are undertaken as part of the environmental education program.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Canadian Pacific Airlines Ltd: Advertising in Australia

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morris Mr P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 12 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say whether (a) Canadian Pacific Airlines Ltd arranged for advertising in Australia between 1965 and 1979, the payment for which was made by way of contra account credit notes and (b) these contra account credit notes were issued under agreements made between Canadian Pacific Airlines Ltd and media organisations which provided that the airline would honour the contra account credit notes and permit travel as arranged by the media organisations up to the value of the credit notes.
(2) If so, were these arrangements approved by his Department under the appropriate Air Navigation Regulations.
(3) If the arrangements were approved by his Department, what were the circumstances of this approval.
(4) If the arrangements were not approved by his Department, why were they not approved.

(5) Is he also able to say whether persons have travelled on tickets in the manner referred to in part (1) who have no connection with Canadian Pacific Airlines Ltd or the relevant media organisations, by exchanging cash payments or goods and services for the tickets obtained by the use of contra account credit notes; if so, is this practice proscribed by the Air Navigation Regulations.

(6) Has his attention been drawn to allegations concerning this practice and that some media organisations still hold contra account credit notes issued by Canadian Pacific Airlines Ltd; if so, has he taken action in relation to this matter; if he has taken action, what action has he taken.
(7) Has he refused to instruct his Department to investigate the actions of Canadian Pacific Airlines Ltd in these matters.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) and (b) My Department commenced recording contra arrangements, entered into by licensed carriers, on 3 June 1977. The first contra lodged by Canadian Pacific Airlines Ltd involving a media organisation, of which I am advised, was dated 13 October 1977. Further contra arrangements involving a media organisation were lodged by the same company on 31 January 1978 and 17 October 1979.
(2) Formal approvals are not given in individual instances.
(4) The contras were lodged with the Department and processed in accordance with procedures set down by the Department on 2 June 1977 and 3 January 1978 and notified to all international carriers.
(5) I am not able to say whether such travel has taken place.

(6) and (7) Certain allegations were made in representations received by myself and my Department. I am advised there is no basis for action under the Air Navigation Regulations, as the statutory time period within which action could be initiated had expired before the matters were brought to attention.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Cost of Unemployment

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Willis Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 26 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: What is the estimated cost to the Treasury in 1981 of an increase of 10,000 in the number of persons out of work, taking account of revenue lost, benefits paid and administrative costs.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: It is not possible to assess with any precision the net effect on Commonwealth outlays and receipts of a hypothetical increase of 10,000 in the number of persons looking for work. Any such calculation would require a large number of assumptions to be made, the nature of which would bear heavily on the figuring.

On the receipts side, the outcome would be influenced by the causes that brought about the rise in the number looking for work. If, for example, more people were entering the labour force and were looking for work because employment was expanding strongly (as it now is) then a rise in unemployment could occur without any adverse effect on taxation receipts. On the other hand, a rise in unemployment occasioned by a downturn in particular sectors of the economy could be associated with lower budget receipts.

The effect on expenditures also would be uncertain and dependent on underlying assumptions. To illustrate, most married women looking for work, and people looking for part time work, are not eligible for unemployment benefits, and the payments received by beneficiaries are related to their age, the number of dependants and the extent of other income. Moreover, some unemployed persons eligible for benefits do not apply. Without knowing the characteristics of the unemployed in question, it would not be possible to estimate the benefits that might be paid. An indication of the average annual cost per unemployment benefit recipient can be gained from the 1980-81 Budget estimates, which provided for total unemployment benefit payments of $959 million on the basis of an average number of beneficiaries of 300,000 (that is, an average annual cost of about $3,200).

The number of unemployment benefit recipients varies considerably over the year and a small change in the number of recipients during the year would be unlikely to have a major impact on administrative costs.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Training of Tradesmen

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hawke Mr R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 31 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the current numbers of tradesmen being trained by major resource developers in those States where the Government has entered into agreements with State Governments to urge project developers to undertake substantial training efforts.
(2) In what (a) States, (b) regions and (c) trades is the training taking place.
(3) What assistance (a) has been afforded or (b) is planned, through Commonwealth and State manpower programs.
(4) What is the level of demand for tradesmen likely to be generated in the next 2 to 3 years on the basis of the early assessments of manpower requirements by project developers.
(5) Is there any intention to involve relevant trade unions as well as the resource companies in the liaison and co-operation process with the State and Commonwealth Governments.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) It is not possible to provide the level of detail sought. However, preliminary data provided by State and Territory apprenticeship authorities indicates that the level of training in the key metal, electrical and building trades is increasing significantly in those States most directly affected by major development projects. In New South Wales, Queensland and Western Australia total apprentice intakes in those trades in the period 1 July 1980-31 March 1981, were up 20 per cent, 35 per cent and 26 per cent respectively on the corresponding period a year earlier.

(3) It is estimated that $65m will be spent in 1980-81 under the Commonwealth Rebate for Apprentice Full-Time (CRAFT) scheme. In addition, special assistance has been extended to support the Commonwealth/State trade training scheme in Western Australia and for the training of apprentice draughtsmen in New South Wales. Offers of special assistance have been extended to all States for the development of trade training programs directed at accelerated training for skills in short supply.

(4) Information on the likely level of demand for tradesmen generated by major development projects was detailed in the report of the DOLAC Working Party, 'Prospective Demand for and Supply of Skilled Labour 1980-83 with Particular Reference to Major Development Projects' published by my Department last September. The main conclusion drawn at that time was that major developments would add an annual demand for a further 7,000 metal, electrical and building tradesmen over each of the three years examined.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Special Youth Employment Training Program

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hawke Mr R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 31 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) On the basis of evaluative data available within his Department what proportion of Special Youth Employment Training Program (SYETP) trainees are retained by their SYETP employers.
(2) What proportion of SYETP trainees have obtained alternative stable employment after completing their SYETP training.
(3) What is the incidence of job substitution between SYETP trainees and other potential employees.
(4) What is the rate of dropout from the SYETP scheme, and what are the main reasons involved.
(5) What is the degree of improved employability as the result of SYETP training.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The latest evaluation report of SYETP trainees is dated June 1980. The survey results in this report show that 50.7 per cent of trainees were still employed with the employer providing training some 4-5 months after the end of the subsidy period.
(2) The same report shows that 17.8 per cent of trainees found full-time employment elsewhere, and 2 per cent found part-time employment.
(3) One third of placements were assessed as net additional positions.

(4) The data shows that 33.9 per cent of trainees do not complete training. Most of these were dismissed but others left of their own accord, either because of dissatisfaction with the job, or to go to another job.

(5) The same study included employer assessments of trainees at the beginning and at the end of the 17 week period. These two separate assessments related to job skills, the need for supervision, and the willingness to help. When compared the assessments indicated 63.5 per cent improved in job skills; 51.3 per cent improved in the need for supervision and 18.5 per cent improved in willingness to help. Those still with the training employer or employed elsewhere included 62.7 per cent of trainees who had been assessed as less than satisfactory on commencement.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Aluminium Processing

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Howe Mr B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for National Development and Energy, upon notice, on 31 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is an expansion proposed of the aluminium industry in Australia from current levels of production of 283 000 tonnes per annum to 1.2 million tonnes by 1985.
(2) If so, what investigations have been carried out to assess the appropriateness of the conventional Hall/Heroult process to Australian circumstances.
(3) Has this process been in use since the 1880s without substantial modification.
(4) Does the process require the consumption of up to 17 000 kilowatt hours of electricity per tonne of aluminium.
(5) Are there serious pollution problems associated with the Hall/Heroult process, particularly with the production of gaseous flourides.

(6) Has the Minister or the Department of National Development and Energy investigated alternative processes involving direct ore reduction, e.g. the production of A1 alloy with 13 per cent Si which is apparently used for industrial production in the United States of America.

(7) Is the Minister able to say whether Alcoa was granted, by the American Research and Development Administration, a credit for the manufacture of AlSi master alloys by oxygen blast furnace without electrical heating.

(8) Has the Minister or the Department of National Development and Energy investigated other new processes such as (a) the condensation of aluminium vapour, (b) carbothermic reduction of aluminium and (c) electrolysis of aluminium chloride.

(9) Has the minister or the Department of National Development and Energy investigated possible improvements in the Hall/Heroult process which might result in a substantial reduction in energy use or the emission of flourides.

(10) In view of the dramatic increase in aluminium production in Australia, has the Minister taken any steps to ensure that Australia has access to the latest technology and the technology which is most appropriate to Australia's circumstances.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for National Development and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Expansion of the Australian aluminium industry of that order is proposed. It is expected that existing annual production capacity of around 280 000 tonnes will rise to around 1.4 million tonnes by 1986.

(2) The adoption of a particular production process by a company remains, in Australia, the outcome of normal commercial considerations. Of course, Governments-Commonwealth, State and local-affect such considerations; for example, through their setting of environmental standards.

(3) It is true that the Hall/Heroult process was first developed in the 1880s. It was the development of this process which facilitated the commerical production of aluminium. The process has, of course, been developed and refined over the last 90 odd years. The smelters it is proposed to construct in Australia will take advantage of recently developed technology relating to pot design, anode manufacture, control of airborne emissions from the potline, and reduced electricity consumption in the smelting process.

(4) The potlines in older smelters do use about 17 000 kilowatt hours of electricity per tonne of primary aluminium produced. However, as indicated in (3) above, the smelters it is proposed to construct in Australia will be taking advantage of the latest commercially available technology. Accordingly, it is estimated that the electricity requirement for the proposed smelters will be between 14-15 000 kWh per tonne.

(5) As is the case with many industrial processes, there are environmental side effects associated with the smelting of aluminium using the Hall/Heroult process. Advances in smelter design and technology have generally reduced such side effects, including the emission of gaseous flourides, to acceptable levels. Nevertheless, before proceeding, each project is required to satisfy the provisions of environment protection legislation of the particular State in which it is to be located. Aluminium smelter proposals requiring Commonwealth decisions are also assessed in accordance with the provisions of the Environment (Impact of Proposals) Act.

(6) and (8) The Department of National Development and Energy is aware of reserach being undertaken into alternative processes to the Hall/Heroult process. The alternative processes referred to are still all in their developmental stages and it will be some time before any of these alternative processes attain commerical viability if, indeed, any do prove to be suitable for application on a large-scale.

(7) In 1977, Alcoa (US) entered a contract with the United States Department of Energy to investigate the technical feasibility of reduction of alumina-silica ores, based on combustion heating. Again, the success or otherwise of this long-term project remains to be determined.
(9) As indicated in (3), (4) and (5) above, the smelters to be built in Australia will be utlising the most advanced commercially available technology.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Air Navigation Charges

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morris Mr P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 1 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Has his attention been drawn to repeated claims by operators that air navigation charges for international flights in and out of Australian airports are the most expensive in the world; if so, is he able to furnish details of the airport charges on international flights including all landing fees, customs charges, holding room charges, passenger head charges, airport staff overtime charges, etc. on (a) DC8, (b) DC10, (c) Boeing 747, (d) Boeing 747 SP, (e) Airbus A300, (f) Boeing 737 and (g) Boeing 727-200 series aircraft, at (i) Heathrow and (ii) Gatwick Airports, United Kingdom, (iii) Frankfurt and (iv) Munich Airports, Federal Republic of Germany, (v) Orly Airport, France, (vi) Tokyo Airport, Japan, (vii) Nadi Airport, Fiji, (viii) Auckland and (ix) Christchurch Airports, New Zealand; (x) Los Angeles, (xi) San Francisco, (xii) New York and (xiii) Honolulu Airports, United States of America and (xiv) Ontario and (xv) Vancouver Airports, Canada.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

ANSWER.PARA: My attention has been drawn to these claims. However such claims are normally based on the erroneous assumption that the landing charges imposed overseas equate with the Australian air navigation charge.

Australian air navigation charges, unlike most overseas countries, are a composite fee covering landing fees, parking fees, terminal air traffic control and en-route aids and services. New Zealand has a similar single charge to Australia.
In overseas countries an aircraft normally pays:

terminal area control fees which are sometimes included under airport charges
an en-route navigational aids and service fees.

It compares charges for operations out of Sydney and Australian en-route facilities to charges for en-route facilities for a similar distance from Heathrow (ie, approximately 3750 kms including charges for en-route facilities of Syria, Cyprus, Greece, Euro-Control, and Yugoslavia) and Heathrow airport charges.
