QUESTION.SPEAKER: Howe Mr B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 1 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the research carried out by Dr Peter Hall and Dr Ben Selinger of the Department of Chemistry at the Australian National University on the chemical 2,4,5-T.
(2) What is his assessment of the researchers' hypothesis that substantial amounts of 2,4,5-T, imported in 1969-70 may have been purchased cheaply in Singapore and come from Vietnam.

(3) Will he assess the researchers' claim that there may be a correlation between an increase in deaths of young babies from certain types of congenital abnormalities and low level exposure of large populations to herbicides with high TCDD (dioxin) levels.
(4) What are the implications of these findings for the study of Agent Orange being carried out by the Commonwealth Institute of Health.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) My Department has no knowledge that 'Agent Orange' or 2,4,5-T from Vietnam has ever been imported into Australia through Singapore or elsewhere. According to a report of the Tariff Board of 12 April 1973, imports of material used in herbicide manufacture, namely free 2,4,5-trichlorophenoxyacetic acid, 2,4,5-trichlorophenol and its potassium salt (KTCP) occurred in the late 1960's and early 1970's. These materials appeared to have originated in Singapore, the United States of America, Japan and Britain.

(3) Dr Hall and Dr Selinger have claimed that there has been an increase in congenital abnormalities of the central nervous system in the years 1968-77 but the statistical significance of their claim is debatable. At the same time, they have also recognised that there is no clear evidence to link this alleged increase with the use of phenoxyacetic acid herbicides.
I am not aware of evidence indicating that low level exposure of large populations to herbicides containing high TCDD (dioxin) levels has ever occurred in Australia.
(4) The Commonwealth Institute of Health is investigating the possibility that the health of Vietnam veterans has been adversely affected by those chemicals used in Vietnam, including 'Agent Orange'.

It has always been recognised by the investigators at the Institute that in their studies the possible effects of exposure to agricultural chemicals will need to be assessed and evaluated in relation to the control group as well as the veterans to ensure that a meaningful comparison of exposed and unexposed persons is made.
Officers involved in the Commonwealth Institute of Health study are aware of the Hall-Selinger results.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Groom The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 2 April 1981:

(3) If he cannot provide the precise number of medical practitioners referred to in part (2) will he give an estimate of the number of medical practitioners involved.

(5) What is the longest period that records or material have been held without formal charges being laid.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Aircraft Noise

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 2 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to question No. 1029 asked by the Member for St George in the Notice Paper of Wednesday, 1 April 1981, (a) on which runways at the Eagle Farm Airport, Brisbane, Queensland, is an instrument landing system operative, (b) what is the glide slope on each runway served by the ILS and (c) what procedures have been introduced to ensure that the angle of the glide path is observed by pilots (i) when using the ILS and (ii) when using a visual approach.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) The instrument landing system operates on runway 22 for landings over Moreton Bay.
(c) There is no external monitoring of the actual glide path flown.

Pilot training in aircraft and aircraft simulators stresses the need to maintain stabilised approach on the electronic glide path of the ILS and on the T-Visual Approach Slope Indicator when making a visual approach. Indeed the whole landing procedure is based on the pilot consistently following this slope to the runway aiming point. A system of cockpit drills specifically alerts the pilot operating the controls if he allows the aircraft to deviate more than a stipulated tolerance below the glide path.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Depo-Provera

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 2 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is there evidence of the widespread prescription of the contraceptive drug, Depo-Provera, for Aboriginals and other groups of deprived women; if so, has the drug been approved limited use.
(2) If this drug has been approved for limited use, what is meant by this term.
(3) Is he satisfied that there are sufficient guarantees of the drug being absolutely safe.

(4) Does the approval for its limited use make adequate provision for ensuring the informed consent of patients using this drug and, in particular, the informed consent of the many Aboriginal women for whom it is at present being prescribed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) My Department only has access to prescribing data in relation to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (see (2) below). Data on use in hospitals and private prescribing data would only be available from the manufacturer. It should be noted that it is incorrect to refer to Depo-Provera as a contraceptive drug in the Australian situation where it has not been approved for this indication.

(2) Depo-Provera is available for use in Australia in the treatment of a number of indications including malignant neoplasia and precocious puberty and its availability as a Pharmaceutical Benefit is limited to these latter two indications. The use of Depo-Provera for contraceptive purposes would be limited to clinical investigational use only. To date, no application has been received by my Department in this regard. An application for its use as a contraceptive was rejected by the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee (ADEC) as there were unresolved questions relating to its safety for this indication.
(3) No potent therapeutic agent, such as Depo-Provera can be guaranteed as being absolutely safe. The product information for Depo-Provera distributed by the company contains the following statement:
''The use of Depo-Provera for contraception is not an approved indication and such use is investigational since there are unresolved questions relating to its safety for this indication''.

(4) The ADEC supports the concept of properly controlled clinical trials using Depo-Provera as a contraceptive provided they are designed to help resolve some of the questions raised and provided adequate measures are incorporated in the trial protocol to satisfactorily protect the participants. As with any drug which is marketed in Australia a doctor may decide that special circumstances warrant the use of the product for conditions other than those for which it has been accepted. In such cases the responsibility for adequately informing the patient or guardian and for any adverse consequences of the therapy must rest with the practitioner concerned.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Road Construction

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morris Mr P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 7 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What studies have been undertaken or are proposed to be undertaken by the Bureau of Transport Economics or his Department into the comparative costs of road construction by private contractors and by Commonwealth, State and local government day labour.
(2) What are substantial quantitative comparisons of private and public road construction, over similar roads in Australian conditions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) No studies have been undertaken which would enable firm conclusions to be drawn about the comparative costs of the two methods of constructing roads in Australian conditions. Because of the difficulties involved in attempting an objective assessment, there are no proposals at present by the Bureau of Transport Economics or by my Department to undertake a specific study to obtain comparative cost data.

However, the relative cost efficiency of these methods of undertaking roadworks would be established on a project by project basis where day labour and private contractors are free to compete by tender for the work. The Government's decision to make grants to the States and the Northern Territory for National Roads construction in the Road Grants Bill 1981 conditional upon the application of tender arrangements will enable cost comparisons to be obtained for particular works on these roads. I intend to report the details to the Parliament when sufficient information becomes available.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Freight Payable on Shipping of Australian Exports

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morris Mr P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 8 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say what was the annual freight cost payable on shipping of (a) Australian bulk mineral exports and (b) total Australian bulk exports for each year from 1972-73 to 1979-80 and for the period 1 July 1980 to 7 April 1981.
(2) What percentage of these payments was payable to operators of Australian flag vessels for the same years and period.
(3) What estimates can he provide on the future shipping costs of exporting (a) Australian bulk mineral exports and (b) total bulk exports, for (i) 1985 (ii) 1990 (iii) 1995, and (iv) 2000.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1 and 2) The Department of Transport does not compile the statistics needed to answer the honourable member's question. The Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) does compile some relevant statistics and it has provided the following information in regard to parts (1) and (2) of the question:
(1) (a) The ABS does not compile statistics on the freight cost payable on shipping of Australian bulk mineral exports separately from other bulk exports.

(1) (b) Figures on the freight cost payable on the shipping of Australian bulk exports before 1974-75 are not available from the ABS. The available figures since then are shown in the accompanying table.

(2) The ABS does not compile statistics on the freight payable to operators of Australian flag vessels, but details are available on the freight paid on bulk exports to Australian operators of any vessels. This means that the freight earnings accruing to an Australian operator from the carriage of bulk exports on a foreign vessel chartered by that operator would be included with any of his earnings from the operation of Australian flag vessels.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Export of Minerals Sands

QUESTION.SPEAKER: West Mr S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 8 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has Moreton Island, Queensland, been placed on the Register of the National Estate; if so, when was this done.
(2) Is he obliged under section 30 of the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975 to refuse all applications for exports of mineral sands from areas listed on the National Estate.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —THe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows;

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Moreton Island was proposed for listing in the Register of the National Estate in the Commonwealth Gazette G2 of 17 January 1978. Objections were received to this listing and following evaluation of these objections the Commission has made a decision to enter on the Register the whole of Moreton Island with the exception of the gazetted townships of Bulwer, Cowan Cowan, Tangalooma and Kooringal.
Moreton Island with the exception of these gazetted townships will be officially advertised for entry in the Register in the early part of the 1981-82 financial year.
By virtue of section 31 of the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975, the place, having been listed, has the same protection as it would have if it was on the Register.
(2) No. Neither I, as Minister, nor the Australian Heritage Commission, has the power to refuse any such application under Section 30 of the Australian Heritage Commission Act.

In respect of the export of mineral sands from Moreton Island Section 30 of the Act would require that Commonwealth Ministers or Authorities responsible for approving licenses for the export of mineral sands from Moreton Island shall not take any action that adversley affects the national estate value of the parts of Moreton Island proposed for the Register of the National Estate, unless they are satisfied there is no feasible or prudent alternative, unless all reasonable measures are taken to minimise the adverse effect and unbless the Australian Heritage Commission is informed of the proposed action and given time to comment.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Subsidy of Air Travel for Inland Queensland Routes

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 8 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to reports in the Press of a call by the Queensland Young Nationals for Commonwealth Government subsidy of air travel for inland Queensland routes; if so, will he introduce this direct subsidy.
(2) Did the President of the Young Nationals call for National Party Members to adopt an aggressive stance on this issue; if so, will he reply aggressively to the President of the Young Nationals.
(3) Did the President of the Young Nationals call for a subsidy to rectify the anomaly where inland travellers were paying a 45 cent loading above that charged on jet routes.

(4) Is an economy fare for air travel from Brisbane to Rockhampton, Queensland, approximately $35 less than for travel of an equivalent distance between Brisbane and Emerald, Queensland; if so, what is the reason for this apparent anomaly.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (3) The Government is aware of the keen interest of certain communities in inland Queensland air services. The new Airlines Agreement provides for an orderly withdrawal from uneconomic services it it is established that over a six month period the airline is not able to fully recover costs. In that event the airline will be able to give three months notice of termination. The new Agreement ensures stability of service by providing for notice of withdrawal and consultations on replacement operators. In circumstances where an airline serves notice that it proposes to withdraw from a route the Governments would have at least 3 months to consider whether arrangements to maintain the service, through a direct subsidy, were appropriate.

(4) The one-way economy fare between Brisbane and Emerald (653 km) is $110.30 on a BPA Metroliner aircraft. The one-way economy fare between Brisbane and Rockhampton (530 km) is $75.60 on a TAA jet aircraft. The fare differential is a consequence of different aircraft operators using different aircraft types and the distances involved.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Petrol Subsidy

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 8 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the guidelines which apply to the payment of a petrol subsidy to consumer or traders in rural areas.

(2) Has his attention been drawn to claims that some oil companies are encouraging private carriers, or jobbers, to attract this subsidy by transporting fuel beyond city limits by claiming a rural destination, then returning to sell their supplies to city service station operators at lowered prices.

(3) Is he able to say whether any of the following trucking companies operate in such a way: (a) Tartan Transport (Moorooka), (b) Petroleum Products Pty Ltd (Moorooka), (c) Centenary Fuel Supplies (Jindalee), (d) Professional Products P/L (Eight Mile Plains), (e) Independent Fuel Supplies (Rocklea), (f) Teraco (Coopers Plains), (g) South Coast Oils Pty Ltd (Labrador), (h) Gold Coast Oils Pty Ltd (South Tweed Heads) and (j) Pottsville Trucking (Pottsville).
(4) What consequences arise from this practice in relation to (a) safety standards governing the syphoning of fuel from underground tanks and (b) the purity and grade of petrol sold to consumers.
(5) Will he consult with his colleagues on the Australian Transport Advisory Council to determine a concerted approach to end this practice.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Under the provisions of the Petroleum Products Subsidy Scheme, which is administered by the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs, oil companies and fuel distributors sell fuel to consumers or traders in rural areas at a price that includes no more than 0.44 cents per litre of the delivery cost of the fuel to the customer. Where the transport costs exceed 0.44 cents per litre, the oil company or fuel distributor claims the remainder from the Government in accordance with the Scheme.

(2) and (3) My attention has recently been drawn to non-specific allegations of this nature. In relation to these the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs has advised that it has found no evidence that these practices occur. I am advised by that Department that all subsidy claims relating to Queensland are checked by the Customs officers in Brisbane. During these examinations the possibility of false invoicing is one of the factors which is checked.
(4) Regulation of fuel handling from underground tanks and fuel quality is primarily the responsibility of State and Territory Governments.
(5) As these issues are not generally the responsibility of transport authorities it is not appropriate to refer them to the Australian Transport Advisory Council.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Uranium Mining

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Trade and Resources, upon notice, on 8 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to Dr Helen Caldicott's account of her visit to Mary Kathleen Mine in 1976 in her book Nuclear madness (Jacaranda Press, 1979), in particular to claims that she found no monitoring of radiation levels between the mine face and the urine of miners despite clouds of dust enveloping workers.
(2) Can he say whether safety standards laid down before 1976 by the Department of Health were ignored by uranium mining authorities in (a) 1976 and (b) later years.
(3) Will the Minister table copies or provide displays in the Parliamentary Library of any information drawn to the attention of uranium workers in Australia in (a) 1976 and (b) 1980.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) The honourable member will no doubt recall that when he was Minister for Health in 1975, the Code of Practice on Radiation Protection in the Mining and Milling of Radioactive Ores (1975) was drawn up by his Department. The draft code was distributed to 94 relevant bodies including mining companies, the ACTU, State Trades and Labour Councils and relevant trade unions prior to finalisation. The final code was released in 1976. An improved version of the Code was approved under the Environment Protection (Nuclear Codes) Act as the Code of Practice on Radiation Protection in the Mining and Milling of Radioactive Ores (1980) on 10 September 1980 and is available for incorporation into State and Northern Territory legislation as required. The Mary Kathleen mine in Queensland was the only Australian uranium mine in operation in 1976. Responsibility for the regulation and control of all mining operations including the enforcement of radiation protection standards in Queensland, at that time and now, rests with the State Government. I understand that all uranium mines in Australia which have received Commonwealth Government development approval as well as Mary Kathleen comply with the standards set out in the Code.

(3) The Code of Practice on Radiation Protection in the Mining and Milling of Radioactive Ores (1980) was approved under the Environment Protection (Nuclear Codes) Act 1978 and laid before both Houses of Parliament. A copy is available in the Parliamentary Library. Other relevant information would be available from the responsible State or Northern Territory authority.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Industrial Action: Department of Industry and Commerce

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bungey Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many officers or employees in his Department have been (a) on strike and (b) engaged in go slow, work to regulations or other restrictive work actions, in each of the last two years.
(2) How many man-hours were involved in these actions.
(3) Were any officers or employees on strike action paid by the Commonwealth during the strike; if so, on what occasions.
(4) Were any pay reductions or disciplinary actions taken in respect of officers or employees on go slow, work to regulations or other restrictive work actions; if so, on what occasions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Lynch The Rt Hon Sir P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) In the period April 1979 to March 1980 there were 44 occurrences of strike action involving a total of 9,386 officers and employees.
In the period April 1980 to March 1981 there were 46 occurrences of strike action involving a total of 2,142 officers and employees.
(b) In the period April 1979 to March 1980 764 staff engaged in go slow, work to regulations or restrictive work actions.
In the period April 1980 to March 1981 44 staff engaged in go slow, work to regulations or restrictive work actions.
(2) In the period April 1979 to March 1980 there were 147,788 man-hours lost due to strike action. From April 1980 to March 1981 there were 30,376 man-hours lost due to strike action.

During the period April 1979 to March 1980 720 staff engaged in a work to regulations situation for one continuous period of 35.4 hours. During the period April 1979 to March 1981 44 technical staff have continued, over the full period, with a refusal to relinquish duties which management considers could be more efficiently performed by another employment category.

Note: The above information includes details in respect of the former Department of Productivity for the period April 1979 to November 1980. Information relating to the functions transferred to the Department of Industry and Commerce from the former Department of Productivity is not separately available, therefore the information provided may include details relating to staff who were transferred to other Departments upon abolition of the Department of Productivity.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Airlines' Cost Recovery

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What was the level of cost recovery for (a) general aviation, (b) domestic airlines and (c) international airlines in 1979-80.
(2) What level is expected from each sector in 1980-81.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The levels of cost recovery achieved by the various sectors of the aviation industry for 1979-80 are as follows:
$m Per cent International +26.8 159.4 Domestic Trunk Airlines -22.2 77.7 Rural Airlines -17.0 31.9 General Aviation -76.4 17.1 Total -88.8 66.1
It should be noted that the allocation principles were revised within the Aviation Industry Advisory Council and these 'revised' principles are being considered by the Government.
The cost recovery levels for both International and Domestic Trunk Airline sectors were affected by abnormal items as follows:

International-$9.5m rentals for international terminal buildings which had been held in a trust fund pending resolution of matters arising from litigation in 1975, was transferred to Consolidated Revenue and credited to the cost recovery program.
$1.5m in respect of air navigation charges payable by Qantas in 1978-79 was not credited to the cost recovery program until 1979-80.
Domestic Trunk Airlines-$3.4m in respect of air navigation charges from the two major domestic airlines for 1979-80 was not credited to the cost recovery program until 1980-81.
If abnormal items are not taken into account then the level of cost recovery for these two sectors was as follows:
$m Per cent International +15.8 135.1 Domestic Trunk Airlines -18.8 81.2

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Financial Directive to Qantas

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bungey Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was a financial directive issued to Qantas by the Government in 1947.
(2) If so, has it been kept secret and why.
(3) What commercial constraints does the directive place on Qantas.
(4) Will he release the text of the directive; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's questions is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (4) The Qantas Financial Directive has not been publicly released since it was first issued in 1947. Certain provisions in the Directive are now outmoded and it is currently being revised according to the guidelines outlined by the Prime Minister in his statement to the Parliament on 30 April. This revision is aimed at enabling Qantas to conduct its operations in a more commercially competitive manner. When this revision is completed, it is anticipated that the new Directive will be tabled in Parliament.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Quarantine: Rabies

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bungey Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a report in the Age newspaper of 24 January 1981 attributed to Mr Harry Butler that dogs with rabies were found on small boats intercepted along the northern Australian coastline.
(2) If so, will he provide details of the cases of vessels detected in this area carrying dogs with rabies.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The honourable member will know that Mr Harry Butler, C.B.E., is spearheading a major Quarantine Awareness Program launched by the Government in 1980-81 to encourage individual self regulation and responsibility among Australians on quarantine matters. I am advised that the report followed an address by Mr Butler in Darwin which he visited as part of this Program.

Mr Butler has advised that the article in the Age has misinterpreted comments made by him at this and on many other public occasions about the rabies risk from dogs carried on small boats of overseas origin in north Australian waters. Also, he was aware that dogs are known carriers of rabies and that rabies exists in countries to Australia's north. Mr Butler advises that in the light of these considerations he drew attention during his Darwin address to the simple way in which rabies could be introduced into Australia.

(2) Rabies has not been diagnosed in relation to any dog found on a vessel detected along the northern Australian coastline. However, any rabies susceptible animal, which in past months could have been in a country where rabies occurs, must be regarded as a rabies risk.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Animal Quarantine Station

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bungey Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is planned for the new animal quarantine station at Guildford, WA.
(2) What is the proposed timetable.
(3) What animals and numbers will it be able to handle.
(4) When is it anticipated that the Bicton site will no longer be required for quarantine purposes.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) A number of new sites are now being considered for the new animal quarantine station in Perth rather than the site at Guildford as originally planned. The change in site was prompted by problems associated with the effect of the noise levels at the Guildford site on both animals and staff. Arrangements to select and acquire the site are currently under way and preliminary planning of the facility has been completed.

(2) The timetable for the new facility has not yet been finalised due to the change in site. It is anticipated that following finalisation of site acquisition, a period of 15 to 20 months will be required to complete the new facility. On this basis completion date will be approximately December 1982.
(3) The station is being designed to accommodate 48 dogs and 14 cats and will include a holding facility for up to 20 horses or 25 cattle.
(4) The agreement with the Western Australian State Government is that the station at Bicton will be vacated by July 1982.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Health: Purchase of Blankets

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bungey Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Imports of 5.5 in. Artillery Ammunition

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 28 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that ammunition for Australian 5.5 in. artillery is being imported from Pakistan.
(2) Are Australian stocks of 5.5 in. ammunition sufficient to enable sustained action should the Army be called upon to perform a military task involving medium artillery.
(3) Does capacity exist for manufacture of 5.5 in. ammunition in Australia; if so, is that capacity being used.
(4) What quantity of ammunition has been imported into Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) No. Due to age and condition the 5.5 in. medium gun no longer has an operational role. The remaining serviceable weapons are used for training and stocks of ammunition are adequate for that purpose.

(3) Yes. Both the projectiles and propellant can be manufactured in Australia but because use has been limited it has not been economic to manufacture projectiles in Australia for many years. Propellant is currently being manufactured in Australia.
(4) The last import was of approximately 14,000 projectiles from the United Kingdom in 1970.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Financial Assistance to the New Zealand Dairy Industry

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 28 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the various forms of financial assistance given to the New Zealand Dairy Industry by the New Zealand Government including (a) interest rate concessions provided by the New Zealand Reserve Bank and calculated by the New Zealand Dairy Board to be worth $50 million per annum to the industry and (b)the exemption of co-operative dairy companies from the payment of income tax.

(2) Will financial concessions similar to those available to New Zealand producers be made available to Australian Dairy Producers given the present domestic shortage in butter production and the threatened flood of New Zealand dairy food imports.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Following the placing of the honourable member's question on the Notice Paper, I sought information on the matters raised in this part. The information indicates that New Zealand does provide assistance to the dairy industry in that country in a number of ways.

(2) This part seems to be based on the premise that the Australian dairy industry is not in receipt of assistance. That, of course, is far from being the case. However, because the forms of this assistance differ from those which apply in New Zealand, any attempt at a quantified comparison would raise considerable practical problems. I understand that the Australian Dairy Corporation is confident, after discussions with dairy product manufacturers, that adequate butter will be produced within Australia for domestic requirements. In the circumstances, safeguards or subventions against a hypothetical threat of imports are not necessary. The Government and the Corporation will, of course, continue to monitor closely the butter supply position.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Minister for Home Affairs and Environment: Advocacy of Income Splitting

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hurford Mr C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 28 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, since being appointed to the Ministry, been advocating income splitting for taxation purposes; if so, does this represent Government policy.

(2) Is that Minister now responsible for this sector of taxation policy, if not, has he breached a Government rule that Ministers must not offer personal views in public, particularly in areas outside their responsibility, but must put forward only the collective Government view.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, before he became a Minister, put forward views on income splitting which were widely reported. The Minister was referring to these well known views in his remarks. This was not a matter on which the Government had taken a decision, and the Minister was not therefore taking issue publicly with a Government decision. I do not regard his comments as a breach of the principles of collective government responsibility.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Film Industry

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hurford Mr C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 28 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the grave disquiet in the community that a Liberal-National Country Party Coalition Policy promise at the last election in relation to the film industry, which was said then to cost only $2 million, is now to cost $20 million.
(2) Will he now give the House an assurance that the estimated costs of all Coalition promises at election time should not be multiplied by 10 to arrive at their true cost.

(3) Is he able to say whether the $20 million being made available for the Film Industry is causing extreme concern to responsible industry leaders and others, not only because of the tax avoidance possibilities but also because of the great number of indifferent films which will now be made from resources in short supply for markets which do not exist.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1), (2) and (3) There has been a very strong response to the Government's important initiative in this matter. To the end of May applications for certification as Australian films has been made in respect of 203 films expected to cost some $145 million in all. It may be expected that this will place some strain on film production resources and some concern has been expressed as to the quality of films that may result.

Nevertheless it is clear that the industry has generally welcomed the Government's initiative. The generous taxation benefits conferred by the scheme, plus the ordinary economic incentive to obtain a maximum return on investment should result in the attraction of investment moneys to quality films having the potential for significant box-office success. This incentive to quality is in fact reinforced by the second limb of the concessions, the income exemption, which in itself is a strong incentive to investment in films with potential for success. The operation of the scheme will, however, be carefully monitored over the next six to twelve months.

In addition, the attraction of the scheme to those concerned only with its exploitation has not been overlooked. Indeed, responsible film authorities have registered their concern at the intervention of these elements. Significant safeguards have accordingly been incorporated in the legislation. In particular, the availability of deductions is to be limited to expenditure for which an investor is at a real risk of economic loss and, with effect from 28 May 1981, deductions under the scheme will become available only when a film is completed and marketed.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Identification of Beneficial Owner of Shares

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hurford Mr C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 28 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was there a recent take-over battle for Elder Smith Goldsborough Mort Ltd and were the shares of Elders, and later Henry Jones, de-listed for some time.

(2) If so, were these extraordinary happenings in the share market partly due to there being no laws in Australia to ensure the early and precise identification of the beneficial owner of shares, because of the use of the nominee companies.
(3) Are there many other examples of confusion and chaos being caused by this situation being allowed to continue.
(4) If so, will he introduce legislation to correct this situation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (4) On 26 May 1981, the South Australian Attorney-General announced the appointment of an inspector under section 17 of the South Australian Securities Industry Act, 1979-1980, to investigate and to report in writing on matters concerning dealing in the securities of Elder Smith Goldsborough Mort Limited and Petroleum Distributors Pty Ltd. The period in respect of which the investigation is to be made is the period which commenced on the first day of January 1981 and which ended on the 25th day of May 1981. In these circumstances, it would be inappropriate to comment on the particular issues raised in the question.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Trade Practices Commission: Mergers Division

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hurford Mr C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 28 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that the Trade Practices Commission no longer has a separate mergers division.
(2) Is it also a fact that the Commission has fewer than 5 project staff engaged in the investigation of merger proposals and that none of those staff are occupied full-time on this work.

(3) Is Australia currently experiencing an exceptionally high level of merger and takeover activity; if so, does much of this activity impinge on the public interest or lead to a lessening of competition.

(4) Will he give an assurance that he and his Department have sufficient resources at their disposal to assess whether individual mergers conform with the tenets of competition policy and whether the present merger and takeover laws are working effectively.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (3) Australia is at present experiencing a significant level of merger and takeover activity. In some cases this activity impinges on the public interest or may lead to a lessening of competition.

(4) It is the function of the Trade Practices Commission to consider whether individual mergers may contravene section 50 of the Trade Practices Act, and I can assure the honourable member that the Commission performs that function. My Department is continually monitoring the operation of the Trade Practices Act including its mergers provisions.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Radio Australia: Mail from the People's Republic of China

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Duffy Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 28 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Approximately how many letters to Radio Australia arrive from the People's Republic of China each month.
(2) Approximately how many of these letters are answered each month and what happens to those letters not replied to.
(3) How many staff members of his Department are employed in handling the inflow of mail from China and what are their (a) classification and (b) special qualifications in each case.
(4) Is consideration being given to increasing the staff ceilings in Radio Australia; if so, what is the proposed increase in employees and when will appointments be made.
(5) If no increase is being contemplated, will he consider raising the staff ceiling in this area.
(6) What Radio Australia offices have been established overseas and what are the (a) number of staff and (b) approximate number of letters handled in each office.
(7) Is consideration being given to the establishment of a Radio Australia office in Peking; if not, will be consider this proposal.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) On an average 10,000 letters are received each month from the People's Republic of China.

(2) Approximately 3,000 letters a month are answered, 2,000 by having their requests for musical items or questions answered in Chinese language programs broadcast by Radio Australia and 1,000 by the despatch of a program guide. The contents of the remainder are noted. Some letters do not call for a reply.

(3) No members of the Department of Communications are so employed. The Chinese Section of Radio Australia employs two Program Officers, whose duties include the handling of correspondence from the People's Republic of China and S.E. Asia.

In addition, two correspondence officers are employed on a casual basis to receive and read mail from the People's Republic of China and to sort and despatch letters to producers for inclusion in Chinese language programs. The Program Officers are required to have linguistic fluency in English and Chinese; ability to type accurately and with speed. To proceed beyond a salary barrier they are also required to be capable of presenting programs in Chinese; and of accurate and speedy translation.
(4) No increase in staff allocation to Radio Australia is contemplated within the ceiling limits currently applying to the ABC.
(5) While the Government has established a staff ceiling for the ABC it is left to the management of the Commission to allocate staff within ceiling limits.
(6) The only Radio Australia office overseas is in Jakarta. Six locally employed staff there handle approximately 10,000 letters a month.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Insurance Agents and Brokers

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 28 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will he undertake to place before Cabinet the main recommendations of the Law Reform Commission in its report entitled Insurance Agents and Brokers.

(2) Is he considering, as one of the options available to the Government, a system based only on those recommendations which were unanimous and not those like disclosure of commission, on which there was disagreement in the Commission.
(3) Can a system based on the unanimous recommendation of the Law Reform Commission be far less onerous than that originally approved by brokers and enacted in the United Kingdom.
(4) Will the main aim of such a system be to prevent and punish dishonest and reckless conduct by brokers.
(5) Will it involve minimal costs and minimal interference with the broking industry.
(6) Have losses through broker insolvency of roughly $7.5m in the last 15 months increased markedly since the data on earlier insolvencies was collected by the Commission.
(7) Are losses a cause of enormous concern, irrespective of the percentage which they form of total insurance premiums.

(8) Is he able to say whether disagreements still exist between the broker organisations; if so, in what areas; if not, do both organisations support the need for national legislation, based upon the recommendation of the Law Reform Commission.
(9) Has any organisation opposed in principle the Commission's main recommendation that premium moneys should be required to be kept separate from the broker's own funds.
(10) Is he able to say what was the general tenor of the responses of State governments and of the insurance industry to the Commission's recommendations.
(11) Were any bodies representative of the general body of policy holders asked for their views when the Government sought the views of the industry.
(12) Has he noted the introduction of similar legislation by the Western Australian State Government.
(13) Will other States be obliged to follow this lead if he fails to act.
(14) If so, will this be disruptive to the industry, wasteful of resources and give rise to a plethora of red tape for the industry throughout Australia.

(15) If the Government fails to act in this matter, will it be subject to the charge of inconsistency in seeking to control dishonesty in the social welfare field but not dishonesty in business practices.

(16) Has his attention been drawn to recent press reports in the Business Review, of 4-10 April 1981, which indicate that Australia's troubled insurance broking industry expects more broking companies to collapse in the coming months.

(17) If both industry and policy holders are to be given the protection they deserve, must Commonwealth legislation based upon the recommendations of the Law Reform Commission be introduced as quickly as possible; if so, will he give an assurance that the necessary legislation will be introduced soon.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (17) The honourable member has raised a number of issues of relevance to the Report of the Law Reform Commission on Insurance Agents and Brokers (tabled in Parliament on 16 September 1980) and to the question of regulation of insurance brokers. After careful study of the Commission's Report and the views put forward by many interested parties the Government has decided not to introduce legislation to regulate the activities of insurance brokers operating in Australia. The factors involved in the Government's decision were outlined in the statement I made on this matter in the House on 10 June 1981.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Commonwealth Grants Commission

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McLean Mr R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 28 April 1981:

While the associate members were nominated by particular States, they were neither required nor expected to 'represent' those States.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Kidney Dialysis Machines

QUESTION.SPEAKER: O'Keefe Mr F.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 29 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is there a shortage of kidney dialysis machines in Australia.
(2) Is this shortage causing considerable concern to kidney sufferers, hospitals and the medical profession.
(3) Will he investigate this situation with a view to giving assistance to eliminate the shortage.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian Kidney Foundation has advised that there is an adequate supply of haemodialysis machines in Australia.

(2) and (3) Under the current hospital cost-sharing arrangements between the Commonwealth and State Governments, the Commonwealth Government has undertaken to meet 50 per cent of the agreed net operating costs of each State's recognised (that is, public) hospital system. The States for their part have undertaken to ensure, to the best of their ability, that the accommodation, facilities, staff and services needed for the care and treatment of all eligible persons are provided by recognised hospitals. It is a matter for the hospital authority in each State to determine expenditure programs within the hospital cost-sharing arrangements.

Under the new health funding arrangements announced recently, the Commonwealth Government will provide funding to the States for public hospitals, the Community Health Program and the School Dental Scheme through general revenue grants at the level of funding provided in 1980-81 plus 10 per cent, less a share of the revenue that the States could reasonably be expected to raise by the introduction of appropriate inpatient and outpatient charges in 1981-82.

There will be no requirements laid down as to the services to which the funds should be allocated. The States should have at their disposal increased resources under the new arrangements. The future provision of dialysis machines through the public hospitals is a matter for consideration by the States in accordance with their priorities.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Trans Australia Airlines: Superannuation Scheme

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Howe Mr B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 29 April 1981:

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Statistician has advised that, partly because details of trade between Australian companies and their overseas branches and subsidiaries are not available to the ABS, it is not possible fully to answer this question.

However, information is available on trade by Australian subsidiaries and branches of foreign companies with their foreign parents and other related companies abroad; it suggests that about 40 per cent of imports to Australia and about 20 per cent of exports from Australia come into this category.

(2) Has the investigating authority made copies of the Swedish report available to Vietnam veterans' representatives; if so, when.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Solar-powered Heating Systems, Commonwealth Buildings

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Housing and Construction, upon notice, on 5 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a report in the Daily Telegraph of 7 April 1981 in which the New South Wales Minister for Education was quoted as saying that he anticipated that Australia's first solar-powered school will save up to $5,000 a year in fuel bills.
(2) Is this figure an accurate indicator of the savings on fuel bills for the average school.
(3) How many new Commonwealth buildings have had solar-powered heating systems installed since 1975.
(4) In how many existing Commonwealth buildings have solar-powered heating systems replaced oil-powered heating systems.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The Department of Housing and Construction is aware of the proposal by the New South Wales Government for the solar-powered Bangor public school at Menai.

(2) Fuel bills for space heating are largely determined by the climate, and in Canberra vary from $3,000 per year for primary schools to $14,000 per year for large high schools and colleges. A solar assisted heating system could be expected to contribute approximately 50 per cent of a school's heating requirements, giving potential annual savings of between $1,500 and $7,000 but at considerable additional capital cost.

A recent national study by the Schools Commission found that the major factor influencing energy consumption in existing schools, is the users. Annual savings of $10m in expenditure on energy for all purposes including heating were predicted if this problem of poor operational practice was addressed on a national level.
(3) No new Commonwealth buildings have been equipped with solar-powered space heating systems since 1975.
(4) No existing oil powered systems have been replaced or supplemented with solar systems.

The CSIRO Division of Building Research experimental building at Highett in Victoria is equipped with a solar assisted heating system. The Department of Housing and Construction office building in Townsville is fitted with a solar assisted air-conditioning system (without heating). Both installations are of a developmental nature and were not intended to be cost effective.

Active solar space heating systems are not yet proven to be commercially viable in Australia because the energy savings are not sufficient to recoup the additional capital expenditure over the life of the equipment. The capital costs of such a system are appreciably higher than conventional systems because of the relatively high cost of the solar component and the need to install alternative back-up equipment using conventional energy sources.
Attention to passive solar heating techniques in the design and siting of buildings is considered to be a worthwhile method of using solar energy to assist with space heating.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Exports to Thailand

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 5 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Do many companies involved in the scientific industry which attempt to export their products to Thailand face a 30 per cent duty on the products.
(2) If so, can he say whether this is a result of the Australian Government's attitude to UNESCO and the Thai customs issue.

(3) Will he provide a clear statement of Australia's attitude to UNESCO and the Thai customs issue, together with some positive plans within a set time frame for a resolution of the problems involved for potential exports to Thailand.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There are two Australian companies which are known to have an interest in exporting scientific equipment to Thailand. Broadly speaking scientific equipment entering Thailand faces a 30 per cent import duty.

(2) Thailand is a signatory to the UNESCO Florence Agreement and goods covered by the Agreement may be imported free of duty provided they are for use in Government research related activities and are sourced from countries signatory to the Agreement. Australia has not signed the Agreement and Thailand applies the normal duties to such goods imported from Australia.

(3) The Florence Agreement was adopted by the General Conference of UNESCO in 1950. Australia has not signed the Agreement because of continuing industry assistance and tariff policy problems of a fundamental nature.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: 1981 Proof Coin Sets

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 6 May 1981:

(2) How many orders for the 1981 Proof Coin sets have been received from private collectors.
(3) How many sets of 1981 Proof Coin sets have been allocated to private coin collectors.

(7) Was a quota of 1981 Proof Coin sets allocated to each coin dealer; if so, what constituted a quota.
(8) Were orders for 1981 Proof Coin sets received from foreign or overseas collectors or dealers; if so, were these orders given equal treatment to Australian orders.
(9) How many 1981 Proof Coin sets were allocated to foreign or overseas coin collectors or dealers.
(10) What proportion of 1981 Proof Coin sets distributed were allocated to foreign or overseas collectors or dealers.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Controller of the Mint has advised me as follows:
(1) The number of 1981 Australian proof coin sets minted as at 28 May 1981 was 29,751, against a planned total of around 83,000 sets.

(2) to (7) A total of 35,120 orders for 99,216 sets of coins were received for 1981 Australian proof coin sets up to 28 May 1981. The offer of these sets has been closed for some time. Orders from whatever source are being met in the order of receipt of remittances, subject to a limit of 100 per order from private collectors and, in the case of dealers ordering more than 100 coins, a level held at or below the level of the previous year. Comprehensive statistics are not maintained separately for private collectors and dealers. However, of the 18,362 sets despatched to Australian customers up to 28 May 1981 3,300 sets have been despatched to dealers ordering more than 100 coins.

(8) to (10) Orders received from overseas were given equal treatment to Australian orders. As of 28 May 1981 7,000 sets have been despatched to the Mint's overseas sales agent for distribution to customers in North America and areas of Europe including the United Kingdom. This will account for the bulk of orders accepted for overseas sales.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Import of Fire-damaged KTCP

* For import statistics the 'Country of Origin' is defined as the 'Country of Production', that is, in respect of refined petroleum products, the country responsible for the last phase of the substantial manufacturing operation before the goods take their final form. This is normally the country in which the goods were loaded for export to Australia. Imports of petroleum products, however, present a special case because trans-shipment of these goods occurs at Singapore en route to Australia. ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Reserve Bank Credit Finance to Public

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 13 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to The Story of the Commonwealth Bank by D. J. Amos, FAIS, which suggests at page 7 that Sir Denison Miller's 1920 issue of #23 million of bank credit caused private banks to abandon in Australia their world deflationary policy.

(2) Did the issue of Reserve Bank credit to finance public works, for which resources are idle and in ample supply, occupy profitably for the community persons who would otherwise have been a financial charge and emotional debit to the community.

(3) Did the issue of money to subsidize costs of essential Consumer Price Index items, for which demand was inelastic and productive capacity was in excess of demand, create or decrease cost and wage inflation in 1943-45.

(4) Is the money supply inflationary if (a) selectively spent to avoid demand-pull inflation to stimulate production in slack economic sectors and demand by the poor and (b) restricted in volume to final prices of goods and services produced by the community using that money and Reserve Bank issues of interest free capital for profitable public works and enterprises which do not compete for resources and which take up idle resources and productive capacity.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) and (3) I do not think any good purpose would be served by attempting to make judgements called for in parts (2) and (3) of the question, which involve events of up to sixty years ago.

In relation to part (3), however, I would point out that from 1942 until the end of the war there were extensive wage and price controls. There was also extensive rationing. In the short term, therefore, the subsidies for Consumer Price Index items (principally clothing, some food and other commodities in short supply to the civilian economy) would have had little effect upon recorded prices. These subsidies, together with other measures of wartime government finance, did however add to the amount of money held as idle bank deposits. The activation of these deposits, in conjunction with post-war shortages, helped to raise the price level some 30 per cent between 1945-46 and 1948-49.

(4) Excessive increases in the money supply would be inflationary in the circumstances postulated, even assuming that slack areas of the economy could be pinpointed in the manner proposed. The economy is an inter-related whole, and action taken in one area inevitably has consequences for others. For example, the resulting increases in personal incomes would give rise to demand for a wide spectrum of goods and services, including those in short supply. In addition, some of the measures referred to (selective spending in slack economic sectors, issues of interest free capital) would inhibit the capacity of the economy to adjust to changing circumstances, and thus reduce its efficiency and increase its susceptibility to inflation.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Exports of Bauxite and Alumina

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 13 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Further to his answer to question No. 176 (Hansard, 24 February 1981, page 72) can he say (a) for what reason is information on exports of bauxite and details of exports of alumina by country of consignment subject to secrecy, (b) under what provision of the law is this secrecy prescribed and enforced and (c) which departments or authorities have access to this information.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) The information referred to is not made available by the Australian Statistician because to do so would reveal the transactions of individual exporters.
(b) Section 24 of the Census and Statistics Act 1905.

(c) The Australian Bureau of Statistics compiles export statistics from export entries and periodic returns submitted to the Bureau of Customs. The Bureau of Customs also provides copies of all entries and returns to the Reserve Bank, solely in connection with its responsibilities for supervising the receipt of export proceeds under the Banking (Foreign Exchange) Regulations. In addition, it provides to the Department of Trade and Resources copies of relevant entries and returns for the purpose of monitoring exports of commodities, including bauxite and alumina, which are subject to export control pursuant to Regulation 9 of the Customs (Prohibited Exports) Regulations. I am advised that the Department also receives information on exports of these commodities direct from exporters. Consistent with undertakings given by successive governments, information obtained through the exercise of export controls, including export statistics, is treated as strictly confidential by the Department of Trade and Resources.

With the above exceptions other departments and authorities do not have access to those returns or entries showing exports of bauxite or country of consignment details of alumina exports. Moreover, no departments or authorities have access to the relevant aggregate export statistics compiled by the Statistician. I am not in a position to say what information is supplied directly to State governments by exporters.

PUK is a privately owned company and TOTAL is 35 per cent Government-owned.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: United States and Japan Alliance

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Fry Mr K.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 26 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the recently announced alliance between the United States of America and Japan have any impact on Australian foreign policy and defence planning.
(2) If the alliance leads to a re-arming of Japan, what implications will this have for Australia and what would be the effect on Australian foreign affairs and defence policy.
(3) Did the United States Government consult with the Australian Government before announcing this alliance.
(4) Has the USA any obligation, either legal or moral, to consult with Australia on such a matter.
(5) If the Australian Government was consulted, what response did it give.

(6) If the Australian Government was not consulted on this matter, (a) is this a cause of concern for the Australian Government and (b) what guarantee is there that the USA will consult Australia on any future foreign policy initiative involving countries in the area.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) An alliance between the United States and Japan has not been announced recently. In the joint communique issued by Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki and President Ronald Reagan on 8 May, it was stated that ''the Prime Minister and the President, recognising that the alliance between Japan and the United States is built upon their shared values of democracy and liberty, reaffirmed their solidarity, friendship and mutual trust''. Although there has been debate in Japan about the interpretation of the word 'alliance' in this sentence, in particular as to whether it committed Japan to a new or altered security relationship with the United States, the Government of Japan has made it clear that its relationship with the United States remains as it has been.

(2) The joint communique further states that ''the Prime Minister and the President reaffirmed their belief that the Japan-United States Treaty of Mutual Cooperation and Security is the foundation of peace and stability in the Far East and the defence of Japan. In insuring peace and stability in the region and the defence of Japan, they acknowledged the desirability of an appropriate division of roles between Japan and the United States. The Prime Minister stated that Japan, on its own initiative and in accordance with its constitution and basic defence policy, will seek to make even greater efforts for improving its defence capabilities in Japanese territories and in its surrounding sea and air space, and for further alleviating the financial burden of U.S. forces in Japan. The President expressed his understanding of the statement by the Prime Minister.''

These positions outlined in the communique do not alter our perception of Japan's defence and security policies nor of Japan's relations with the United States. The Government sees cooperation under the Japan-United States Treaty of Mutual Cooperation and Security as a vital part of the defence of the Asia/Pacific region, as are the separate arrangements under ANZUS. It is in Australia's interest that the defence relationship between Japan and the United States remain a harmonious one.

(3), (4), (5) and (6) As suggested in answer to questions (1) and (2), no event as suggested by those questions took place which required specific consultations with Australia by any other government. In both formal and informal consultations with the United States on security issues in the Pacific area, discussion would include, as appropriate from time to time, subjects related to Japan. Similarly, established patterns of consultations with Japan on matters of common international concern include subjects such as Japan's, and our own, relations with the United States.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Comprehensive Statement on Taxation

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 27 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Will value added tax or other kinds of indirect taxes instead of high income taxes enable Australian manufacturers to compete better on the export market; if so, why did he not mention this in his comprehensive statement to the House on taxation on 12 March 1981 (Hansard, pages 760-70).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Many factors have to be taken into account in any consideration of major changes to a taxation system, including the possible implications for exporters of any such changes. Not all factors would carry the same weight in such consideration.

My statement to the House on 12 March 1981 was not intended as an exhaustive primer of taxation principles and practices-nor, indeed would I seek to strain the patience of the House in that way. However, since the matter has been raised, I note that under the present sales tax (an important element in our present taxation system) exports are exempt, and similar exemption could be expected to apply with a value-added tax (VAT).

I add that, unless exemption were provided for export sales, a VAT could not, in itself, be expected to enable manufacturers to compete better on export markets. I understand that many countries that impose VAT do indeed grant exemptions of this kind. At the same time, they impose VAT on imports without granting credit for tax paid in the country of production. Where trade takes place solely between countries that impose VAT on this basis and at the same rate, the ultimate effect would be neutral on imports and exports, each country's VAT amounting to a tax on the consumption of its residents only. In the interests of fiscal harmonisation, and the avoidance of double taxation, the member countries of the EEC have moved towards a uniform practice of this kind.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Dumping of Radioactive Waste

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 27 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that from 1946 to 1970 the United States of America authorised dumping of more than 50,000 drums of radioactive waste in the Pacific Ocean, some in the Farallon Islands fishing grounds off San Francisco, where up to 8,000 times normal radioactivity from cesium and strontium isotopes and plutonium have been found from waste described by the US Environmental Protection Agency as low level, and some at sites never made public.
(2) If so, does the Government support recent USA Government estimates that Pacific radioactive waste could total up to 300,000 curies, 10 times previous estimates.

(3) Has the USA Atomic Energy Commission disclosed to Australia, that it knew 20 years ago that drums holding nuclear waste when dumped were broken open by water pressure at great depths; if so, when.

(4) Did the United States Navy recently agree that 23 nuclear submarines homeported at Pearl Harbour from 1964 to 1973 dislodged 4.8 million gallons of radioactive waste there; if so, did Hawaii recently establish State monitoring of the effects on marine life.
(5) Are any results of this monitoring available.
(6) Is he able to state whether Japan has a program to dump initially 5,000 to 10,000 drums of radioactive waste less than 600 miles north of the Marianas.
(7) What offers has Australia made to Japan to develop alternative waste disposal techniques and with what result.

(8) Will the Government promptly publish all details of any use of Australian inventions for nuclear waste disposal including dump sites and all known information on military and industrial nuclear contamination and dumping plans in the Pacific Ocean.
(9) Will Australia support moves for extension of the Antarctic nuclear-free zone; if so, in what regions; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The locations of all sites where radioactive waste has been dumped by the United States of America were made public in 1971 at which time 41 sites were identified. Subsequent searching of records has added several more sites, and all site locations have been published. About ninety per cent of all activity dumped by the US has been at four main sites:

The United States Environmental Protection Agency has advised that the number of drums of radioactive waste dumped by the United States of America from 1946-70 at the above Atlantic and Pacific Ocean sites was 76,301. The number of drums dumped in the Pacific (at the Farallon Island sites) was 47,500. No strontium release was detected by monitoring at either of the Atlantic or Farallon Island sites. Plutonium 239/240 was detected at the Farallon Island sites (not at the Atlantic sites) at concentrations 2 to 25 times greater than would be expected from background attributable to fall-out from nuclear weapons testing. Cesium was not detected at the Farallon Island sites. It was, however, detected at Atlantic sites at concentrations 3 to 70 times greater than background.
(2) According to the United States Environmental Protection Agency, present activity at the Farallon sites is estimated to amount to 14,500 curies, not 300,000 curies as suggested.

(3) The United States authorities have advised that their experience is that drums holding nuclear waste actually remain intact when dumped and that any release takes place over a long period of time. The US Atomic Energy Commission has always taken the position, however, that it needs to be assumed for the purpose of analysis that drums holding nuclear waste would fracture on impact when dumped, and that activity would be released.

(4) United States official sources have confirmed that releases of low-level radioactive liquid wastes from US nuclear submarines in Pearl Harbour from 1964-78 totalled 4,843,000 gallons, containing about 1.0 curie of activity. Most of this release (0.98 curie) occurred in 1964 in a volume of 405,000 gallons.
The State of Hawaii established an environmental monitoring program for Pearl Harbor by granting a one-year contract to the Gamma Corporation. This commenced in June 1980.

(5) The Gamma Corporation has reported that three quarterly samplings have been made in the course of the monitoring program. The first quarter sampling in September 1980 showed the highest cobalt-60 activity of about 0.25 picocurie per gram. The second quarter sampling in December 1980 showed the same general pattern of cobalt-60 activity as in the first quarter. Crab and seaweed samples showed only normal activity. Sampling of air activity showed a continuing rise in fallout activity, presumably from a recent nuclear test in the atmosphere by China. Third quarter sampling in February 1981 showed about the same distribution pattern as obtained in the previous quarter sampling, except for sample station no. 6 which recorded an activity of 0.488 picocurie per gram, about three times the average of previous activity recorded by that station.
Further sampling is required for a greater period to determine whether these samples are indicative of an increasing activity level in Pearl Harbour.

(6) Japan has announced that it is proposing to conduct a trial dumping of about 10,000 drums of cement-solidified low-level waste, comprising less than 500 curies of radioactivity in the North Pacific. The dump site, 30*N147*E, is approxi- mately 510 nautical miles (945 kilometres) south-east of Tokyo, and 290 nautical miles (540 kilometres) from the nearest island, which is a Japanese possession. The nearest island of the Mariana group is about 590 nautical miles (1,090 kilometres) from the proposed dump site.

(7) Australia and Japan participate in international studies on nuclear waste disposal in the Nuclear Energy Agency of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development and in the International Atomic Energy Agency.

Bilaterally, there has been an exchange of correspondence between scientists in the Australian Atomic Energy Commission and the Japan Atomic Energy Institute concerning papers relating to the SYNROC technique for the immobilisation of high-level nuclear waste developed at the Australian National University.

Apart from the exchanges between scientists on the SYNROC technique, Australia and Japan have not had bilateral discussions on alternative waste disposal techniques and Australia is not in a position to offer other alternative techniques on radioactive waste disposal to Japan.

(8) Details of the SYNROC research and development program have been published widely in scientific journals and elsewhere. This is the only Australian invention for handling nuclear waste disposal in the form of high-level waste.

The Government has said that there is no intention of Australia's storing other countries' nuclear wastes. Information on atomic test sites and related details of nuclear contamination within Australia has been published in reports by the Australian Ionising and Radiation Advisory Council and the Department of National Development and Energy. These reports are available to the public.

Australia has made clear its opposition to the Pacific region becoming a dumping ground for the indiscriminate and uncontrolled disposal of nuclear wastes. Consistent with that position the Government will continue to monitor closely all developments related to the dumping of nuclear waste in the Pacific.

Japan's announcement that it proposes to dump low level radioactive waste in the North Pacific is the only case known to the Government of a country which has plans to dump radioactive waste in the Pacific Ocean.

(9) Australia supports the Antarctic Treaty, Article 5 of which prohibits the nuclearisation of the whole of the area south of the 60*S parallel. The question of extending the region to cover a wider area has not been raised in the regular consultations which take place under the Treaty.

The Government does not consider that calls for nuclear-free-zones, which try to encompass the totality of nuclear issues affecting regions, are likely to be effective in meeting the security and environmental concerns of countries in the areas where such calls have been made. These concerns and interests are more likely to be taken into account if attention is focused on particular problems which are raised by particular issues.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hurford Mr C.J.
