ANSWER.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Trade Practices Commission did monitor zinc prices in Australia for several years.

(2) and (3) After making extensive enquiries the Trade Practices Commission concluded that a price agreement between zinc suppliers could not be proved. As stated in the Commission's Annual Report for 1979-80, the Commission found that price uniformity in recent years appeared to be consistent with non-collusive price leadership.
(4) The Commission has stated that it will keep the matter under general review as circumstances and any future relevant evidence may require.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Changes to Tariff Levels

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hurford Mr C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 28 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has he or his Department received complaints from State Governments or others alleging that changes are made to tariff levels without adequate consideration being given to the effect of such changes on the economies of individual States and regions.
(2) Are these criticisms justified; if not, what is the reason.

(3) What constraints will the Government's adoption of the Committee of Review of Commonwealth Functions' recommendations concerning the Industries Assistance Commission (Hansard, 30 April 1981, page 1841) have on the capacity of that body to give greater consideration to the special problems of individual regions when it is formulating proposals on industry protection.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Most industries assistance decisions necessarily involve the granting or withdrawal of some benefit to industries located in particular States or regions. Therefore representation of various points of view are expected and welcomed by Government to assist it to make a balanced decision which takes into account all relevant viewpoints.

(2) It is Government policy that tariffs and other assistance to particular industries are not changed before advice is received from either of the government's advisory bodies on industry assistance, the IAC or the TAA. The public inquiry process provides all bodies, including State Governments and regional authorities, with ample opportunity to put their point of view. The draft report procedure allows comment on the IAC's draft recommendations before a final IAC report is submitted to the Government.

Under Section 23A of the Industries Assistance Commission Act 1973, the Commission is required to report on the probable economic and social consequences of implementing its recommendations, as well as the likely employment consequences, both generally and in particular regions.

Before taking a decision on assistance levels for an industry, the Government fully considers the views of all interested parties as well as the likely implications of its decisions. In these circumstances it is not reasonable to criticise changes on the grounds cited.

(3) Following the adoption of the recommendations of the Committee of Review of Commonwealth Functions, the workload of the IAC will be examined. Any changes to the staffing levels in the IAC will only occur as a result of reductions in the general workload. There are no plans to make reductions that would limit in any way the IAC's capacity to meet its obligations to provide the Government with full and detailed information on matters pertinent to industries assistance.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Menindee Lakes Storage, New South Wales

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for National Development and Energy, upon notice, on 2 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Menindee Lakes Storage, New South Wales, controlled by the River Murray Commission or by the New South Wales Water Resources Commission.
(2) Do special arrangements exist for the allocation of water from the storage to New South Wales and to South Australia; if so, what are the details.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for National Development and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Menindee Lakes Storage was constructed and is owned by New South Wales which operates and controls this storage through the New South Wales Water Resources Commission in accordance with the terms and conditions of the Menindee Lakes Storage Agreement between the Commonwealth, New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia.

(2) The Menindee Lakes Storage Agreement lays down the arrangements for the allocation of water from the storage to the States. The River Murray Commission may not call for the release of water from the lakes over the period from when the quantity of water stored in the lakes becomes less than 480,000 megalitres until the next time the quantity of water so stored exceeds 640,000 megalitres; but during this time New South Wales may use the water stored in the lakes as it requires. At other times water stored in the lakes in excess of 480,000 megalitres is available to the River Murray Commission to allocate for sharing between New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia, in accordance with the provisions of the River Murray Waters Agreement. However, in addition to any share it may receive under that Agreement, New South Wales is entitled to use 125,000 megalitres in any year commencing on the 1st May. There are no special arrangements for the allocation of Menindee water to South Australia. South Australia's entitlement under the River Murray Waters Agreement may be provided from any of the sources of supply available to the River Murray Commission, including the Menindee Lakes.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: River Murray Waters Agreement

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

(3) Was water used by New South Wales and Victoria approximately nine-fold less polluted in the Mulwala/ Yarrawonga Canals and four-fold less polluted in the Wakool/Torrumbarry System in respect of sodium than Murray River water flowing to South Australia in 1979-80; if not, what are the figures for the relevant proportions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for National Development and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (i) Under normal flows, South Australia is entitled to 1,850,000 megalitres per annum in specified monthly quantities. Having provided South Australia's entitlement, New South Wales and Victoria are entitled to an equal share of the flow of the River Murray at Albury, plus any contribution from their own tributaries below Albury.

(ii) During periods of very low flow and after a formal period of restriction has been declared by the River Murray Commission, special arrangements apply. The balance of water available is then divided equally between New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia. In these circumstances, New South Wales and Victoria also retain their entitlement to the additional amounts of flow contributed by their respective tributaries below Albury.
(2) No; from information available in the River Murray Commission's 1980 Annual Report, the percentage was about 81 per cent.
(3) Information contained in the 1980 Annual Report of the River Murray Commission shows that the median values for sodium concentrations during the year at the following locations were:

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Taxation System

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hurford Mr C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 2 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Confederation of Australian Industry written to him expressing substantial misgivings about the Australian taxation system and calling for a Green Paper on tax.
(2) If so, was he surprised to read the comments of this industry body, in view of his statement to the Parliament on 12 March 1981 on taxation policy (Hansard pages 760-70).

(3) Has Australian industry been critical of the Government for not having made, after 5 1/2 years in power, a clearer and more definitive statement on taxation matters as they affect industry; if so, is there justification for this criticism.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Director-General of the Confederation of Australian Industry wrote to me recently, setting out, inter alia, the Confederation's views on the Australian taxation structure and suggesting that a Green Paper should be prepared to enable informed public discussion of taxation questions.

(2) and (3) Judgments about the tax system differ not only on points of emphasis and detail but also, and more importantly, concerning such weightier issues as the constraints which the effects of possible changes upon the budgetary aggregates must impose, and the relative importance attached to effects on particular sectors or on the structure of the taxation system as a whole.

It should not be surprising that different views on these matters are possible, given the different basic stances from which people start out. I do not think that the existence of such differences of view is open to the kind of black-and-white interpretation implied in the question.

In his letter, the Director-General reiterated the Confederation's request for urgent consideration of several substantial amendments of the income tax law. A point I wish to make in regard to those suggestions is that their immediate implementation would have consequences for the revenue on a scale that would put at risk the Government's budgetary strategy and jeopardise the economic progress achieved since 1976.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Economic Relations with New Zealand

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Burr Mr M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Trade and Resources, upon notice, on 2 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are negotiations under way for closer economic relations with New Zealand; if so, will he provide details.
(2) Has any agreement been reached that will allow a greater import of raw and processed vegetables from New Zealand.
(3) If so, will any protection be given to Australian producers to prevent undermining the domestic Australian market by heavily subsidised New Zealand products.
(4) Will any measures be taken to prevent a flooding of the Australian potato market.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I refer the honourable member to the statement to the Parliament by the Prime Minister on 25 March 1980 in which he outlined proposals agreed with the Prime Minister of New Zealand for a possible closer economic relationship between Australia and New Zealand.

(2) and (3) No agreement has been reached on any aspect of the proposed closer economic relationship. In his statement the Prime Minister emphasised that ''no commitment to any specific proposal has been entered into at this stage, nor will any decisions be taken until the studies have been completed and there has been full consboth countries''. However the central trade objective of the proposed closer economic relationship is the gradual and progressive elimination of all barriers to trans-Tasman trade on all goods produced in either country.

(4) There are no imports of fresh potatoes from New Zealand due to quarantine restrictions and any concerns the industry may have can only relate to processed potato products, imports of which have been minimal in recent years and well below Australian shipments to New Zealand.

Implicit in the Prime Minister's statement of 25 March 1980 is the principle that trade between Australia and New Zealand within a closer economic relationship could only take place under conditions of fair competition. This means that any movement towards trade liberalisation would only occur on the basis of fair and equitable trading opportunities. The honourable member can be assured that the concerns expressed by Australian potato growers relating to the prospect of unfair New Zealand competition in potato products are being carefully assessed in the light of the central trade objective of the proposed closer economic relationship.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Apple and Pear Promotion

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kerin Mr J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 3 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are wholesale fruit agents required to deduct a levy of 7c per bushel from growers' returns to be diverted to the Apple and Pear Corporation for promotion in Australia and overseas.
(2) If so, what regulations under the Australian Apple and Pear Corporation Act require this to be done.
(3) Are proceeds from the Apple and Pear Export Charge also diverted to promotion.
(4) What proportion of the total sum spent on promotion was spent (a) overseas and (b) in Australia from grower and government funds during (i) 1979 and (ii) 1980.
(5) What amount of grower funds earmarked for promotion and publicity in (a) 1979 and (b) 1980 was spent on general Corporation overheads.
(6) Of the amount of grower funds spent in (a) 1979 and (b) 1980 what sum was spent on promotion and publicity in (i) each State and (ii) each overseas country.
(7) Are any attempts made locally and overseas to monitor the effects of expenditure on promotion and publicity on consumption.
(8) Is detailed information available to growers and agents on local and overseas promotion campaigns.

(9) As apple and pear growing is regional, have there been any demands from the industry for promotion to emphasise district attributes, for example, the Huon Valley, Adelaide Hills, Bilpin, Orange, Stanthorpe and so on.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Sections 5 and 6 of the Apple and Pear Levy Act 1976 provide for a levy to be imposed on apples and pears produced and sold or used in Australia. The levy is payable by the grower. In respect of apples and pears which are not used for juicing or processing, sub-regulation 3(c) of the Apple and Pear Levy Regulations provides that the rate of levy shall be 5c per box. Sub-section 6 (2) of the Apple and Pear Levy Collection Act 1976 enables wholesale fruit agents to deduct the amount of the levy from the proceeds of the sale of the fruit they handle on behalf of the grower. Section 29 of the Australian Apple and Pear Corporation Act 1973 provides that all moneys received under the Apple and Pear Levy Collection Act 1976 and the Apple and Pear Export Charge Collection Act 1976 (see (3) below) shall be paid to the Corporation. Section 6 of the Australian Apple and Pear Corporation Act 1973 provides that the promotion of apples and pears in Australia and overseas is one of the functions of the Corporation. Finally, section 32 of the same Act enables the moneys of the Corporation to be applied in payment or discharge of the expenses, charges, obligations and liabilities incurred or undertaken by the Corporation in the performance of its functions under the Act.

(3) Yes, in the same manner as the payment of the levy. Pursuant to sub-section 7(1) of the Apple and Pear Export Charge Act 1976 and Regulation 3 of the Apple and Pear Export Charge Regulations the rate of charge applied is 5 cents per box of fruit exported from Australia.
(4) The amounts spent on publicity and promotion during 1979 and 1980 were:
in respect of which the Overseas Trade Publicity Committee's (OTPC) contributions in 1978-79 and 1979-80 respectively were $68,764 and $90,233.

(5) No specified amounts of the proceeds of the levy and export charge accumulations are earmarked for publicity/ promotion and general Apple and Pear Corporation overheads, but the amounts expended in 1979 and 1980 on general Corporation overheads were:
($) ($) Members of the Corporation, Fees, Allowances and Expenses 92,995 96,340 Administration-Salaries 158,869 181,005 Other 170,140 176,681
(6) The amounts spent on promotion and publicity in each State and in each overseas country were:

($) ($) Common expenses i.e. Production of posters, TV commercials, industry communications, apples for schools and public relations 82,895 70,804 New South Wales 116,233 117,575 Victoria 69,596 11,784 South Australia 18,572 24,671 Western Australia 35,382 37,515 Queensland 42,992 10,514 Tasmania 5,632 2,035
+ there is a variation between the above figures (financial years) compared with annual report figures (calendar years) due to overlap of periods of accounting.
(7) Yes. Gallup Poll research in Australia. Assessment by Corporation, Trade Commissioners and importers in overseas countries.
(8) Yes. Details of campaigns and reports are available and are published in industry magazine Apple and Pear World plus convened meetings.

(9) There have been requests from Stanthorpe and Bilpin for specific advertising and special campaigns have been conducted stressing 'early' fruit, but this is considered desirable only in eastern seaboard markets which are regarded as one market. In isolated markets, i.e. Western Australia and South Australia, a regional aspect arises but material used e.g. TV and posters, recipes, et cetera, promotes 'apples' and 'pears' and does not specify State or region. There is consultation all along the line at State grower organisation level.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Wool Testing Authority: Sale

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kerin Mr J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 9 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have Hill-Samuel Australia Limited undertaken a study of the various options available to the Government with regard to the sale of the Australian Wool Testing Authority; if so, do the results of this study indicate that whatever option is adopted will result in an increase in charges to growers by between 10 per cent and 20 per cent.
(2) How will he reconcile this finding with an undertaking given by the Prime Minister to Mr Ian McLachlan, President of the Wool Council of Australia, that charges would not increase.

(3) Did he state in a Primary Industry Media Release on 15 May 1981, that the fundamental aim is to ensure that the AWTA continues to operate in precisely the same way as it does today; if so, does this mean that the only result of the sale of the AWTA will be that growers will have to pay more for the same service.
(4) What will be the anticipated reduction in Government spending resulting from the sale of the AWTA to private enterprise.

(5) Will the Government make the Hill-Samuel Australia Limited study public so that all sections of the wool industry can examine its findings and consider the full implications of any change; if not, why not.
(6) What are the requirements of the International Wool Testing Organisations with regard to the operation of wool testing houses.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian Wool Corporation has informed me that Hill-Samuel Ltd undertook two feasibility studies during May 1981 at the request of the Australian Wool Corporation to canvass possible options for the sale of AWTA to the private sector. I have been informed that Hill-Samuel forecast various levels of costs from no significant increase up to a 25 per cent increase but could not be definite because the levels of some critical parameters were not known at the time of those studies. A third and more detailed study commissioned by the Wool Corporation is at present in train.

(2) The Prime Minister gave an undertaking to the Chairmen of the Wool Council of Australia and the International Wool Textile Organisation that the AWTA would not be sold until the Minister for Primary Industry is satisfied that the terms and conditions surrounding such a sale are satisfactory to the Industry. The Government has charged the Corporation to recommend suggested terms and conditions for the sale of AWTA and the preferred form of the commercial entity to continue its wool testing activities. No final recommendations have been formulated, and consequently the future cost structure cannot be accurately assessed at this time.

(3) The Government's decision to sell the AWTA is based on the belief that activities of a commercial kind are generally better performed in the private sector. AWTA in recent years has been operating as a commercial entity.
(4) There should be no increase or decrease in Government spending as a result of the sale of the AWTA.

(5) The Government did not commission the Hill-Samuel reports; in the circumstances outlined above, they are commercially confidential to the Wool Corporation. However, in due course a synopsis of the reports, or at least their main thrust, will no doubt be communicated by the Corporation to industry representatives to permit the development of a consensus recommendation on the sale arrangements for AWTA.
(6) In accordance with IWTO requirements the operations of a test house must be independent of the sales transactions in connection with which certificates will be issued or used.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Sydney Airport

(2) Do any plans exist for a new mint to be built at Mitchell, ACT; if so, what are the details.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) As a consequence of the interruption to the Mint's production of circulating currency due to the Australian Society of Engineers dispute, the Government has contracted for the supply of 220 million pieces of Australian circulating currency (approximately 15 weeks' production of the Mint) from overseas sources. Information regarding those sources has not been released.

(2) A proposal to build a coin blanking annex at Mitchell, ACT, was considered some years ago as one option for a possible expansion of the facilities of the Royal Australian Mint. However the option was not pursued.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Grain Storages: Sri Lanka

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Fisher Mr P.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 3 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did Australia supply 32 horizontal grain storages to Sri Lanka through the Australian Development Assistance Bureau in 1979; if so, have the storages been erected and completed under the terms of the agreement.
(2) Have the completed storages been inspected by Bureau officers.
(3) Who received the tender to construct the storages and what was the cost of the program.
(4) Are further storages to be supplied to the Paddy Marketing Board of Sri Lanka under similar arrangements.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In 1979 the Sri Lankan Government called public tenders in Australia for the supply of 32 prefabricated grain storage sheds and subsequently entered into a contract with the successful tenderer for their supply and shipment to Sri Lanka. Funds for the purchase of these sheds were made available by the Australian Government as part of its development assistance program to Sri Lanka. The agreement between the two governments related to the provision of funds. Erection and inspection of the sheds was the responsibility of the Sri Lankan Government.

(2) The storage sheds have not been inspected by Bureau officers. Consultations between the Australian and recipient governments are held from time to time to ensure effective implementation of particular projects but it is neither feasible, and nor would it be appropriate, for Bureau officers to inspect all aspects of all projects.
(3) The successful tenderer was Osborne Metal Industries Pty Ltd, Osborne Park, Western Australia. The cost of the sheds including freight was $753,784.
(4) I am unaware of any further requirement for grain storage sheds to be provided as part of Australia's aid program to Sri Lanka.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: National Representative Basins Program

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for National Development and Energy, upon notice, on 3 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was the National Representative Basins Program established as part of Australia's contribution to the International Hydrological Decade.
(2) If so, what State and Commonwealth Departments were involved in the program.
(3) Did this program involve the hydrological investigation of approximately 100 medium to small river basins throughout Australia.
(4) What was the aim of the program and when was it commenced.

(5) Was it anticipated that if the program was successful the data collected from the catchments referred to in part (3) could be used to solve water problems arising with the many other catchments where either no data exists or cannot be quickly collected.

(6) Can the Minister say whether the Bureau of Meteorology consistently failed to undertake its commitment to rainfall collection data; if so, was this because the Bureau was never funded or manned at the appropriate level by the Commonwealth Government, in spite of repeated calls by the Australian Water Resources Council.

(7) Can the Minister also say whether the CSIRO spent much effort in setting up a mathematical hydrological model of the catchment processes, which could not be effectively directed or improved because of the lack of sufficient co-ordinated rainfall and stream flow data.
(8) What is to be the fate of the program.
(9) What sum has been spent on the program and has this money been well spent.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for National Development and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Although the Australian Representative Basins Program (ARBP) was not part of Australia's formal contribution to the program of the International Hydrological Decade, it was established in the spirit of the objectives of that international endeavour in 1965.

(2) The Department of National Development and Energy (as well as earlier departments with responsibility for the interests of the Commonwealth in water resource matters), CSIRO, the Bureau of Meteorology and all State government water agencies have been involved in the ARBP.

(4) The primary objective of the ARBP was to improve understanding of the relationships between catchment characteristcs, climate and run-off by studying data obtained from matching meteorological and hydrological installations in catchments representative, in the main, of all Australian environments.
(5) Yes, but mainly in respect of run-off management requirements including regulatory structures, culverts, bridges, etc.

(6) Within the general resources available to the Bureau of Meteorology, considerable progress was made in meteorological instrumentation early in the program. Twenty-nine of the eighty-five basins established have been fully instrumented with the minimum meteorological instruments, and forty-eight basins are partially instrumented (of which about half have sufficient data for analytical purposes). Most of the data in the ARBP data bank have been provided by the Bureau, involving approximately 1050 station years of average basin rainfall, 950 years of pluviograph data and 400 years of evaporation data. The remainder of the basins/sites require automatic equipment which has development, manpower and funding problems not yet fully resolved.

(7) CSIRO has devoted considerable resources to the development of the Australian Representative Basins model, partly using data obtained from the ARBP. Sufficient co-ordinated data has been available for the CSIRO research program to proceed, but not within the broader scope of the program as originally envisaged.
(8) The future of the ARBP is at present under consideration in the Australian Water Resources Council.

(9) A reliable estimate of the cost of the program to date cannot be provided owing to problems in identifying costs incremental to the normal expenditures of the numerous agencies involved. However, the success of the program will depend on the extent to which analyses of data from the selected gauged catchments meet the objectives of the program, as indicated in (4) and (5) above. It will be some time before this becomes clear.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Interference by Soviet Radar

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 3 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: What steps has the Government taken to reduce interference by Soviet Union over-the-horizon radar to short wave bands vital for emergency communications in Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Those authorities responsible for safety communications in Australia have not observed any circumstances of significant interference on any of the internationally recognised radio distress channels. However, there has been some observation recently of over-the-horizon radar signals occurring on the Australian safety frequency 27.880 MHz, though the extent has not been serious. On the basis of these observations, my Department has initiated communication with the USSR seeking their co-operation in avoiding interference to the 27.880 MHz safety channel.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Control of Seabed Resources

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 3 June 1981:

(2) Is he able to say whether the USA legislated unilaterally to allow seabed mining.
(3) Is he also able to say whether the rule of law between nations will be disregarded to the disadvantage of developing nations if the USA policy is implemented.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government's position on this matter has been explained to Parliament on several recent occasions. I refer the honourable member to my reply to a question without notice on 30 April 1981, to my statement to the House on 26 May 1981, to the answer to Senate Question No. 579 (Hansard, 27 May 1981, pages 2224-2225) and to my reply to a question without notice on 5 June 1981.

(2) The United States 'Deep Seabed Hard Minerals Act' (Public Law 96-283) entered into force on 28 June 1980. The Act is expressly interim in nature. It places a moratorium on commercial recovery of seabed minerals until 1 January 1988. ANSWER.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. Staff and employees were advised of the principal decisions affecting the Department of Housing and Construction, taken by the Government following the Review of Commonwealth Functions. That advice included the decision to reduce by around 50 per cent the Department's present in-house activities on repairs and maintenance and minor new works.

(2) No specific time-frame has been determined for achieving this reduction. ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Heart Disease

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 4 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Have any studies been undertaken between the relationship of miles driven in a motor vehicle to the incidence of heart disease; if so, what are the details; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Papers on this subject have been published by Mr Athol A. Robinson of 16 Quayle Street, Sandy Bay, Hobart, Tasmania, viz:
A. A. Robinson and W. F. Navin, 'Your Heart and the Motor Vehicle, December 1974'.
A. A. Robinson, 'Heart Disease, Cancer and Vehicle Travel', in Medical Hypotheses, 5, 3, 1979, pages 323-8.
A. A. Robinson, 'Male, Female Heart Disease-Relationship with Vehicle Travel', in Medical Hypotheses, 5, 12, 1979, pages 1337-1346.

Mr Robinson's conclusions that there is a relationship between miles driven and incidence of heart disease are based on the observation that these have increased concurrently. Analyses of this kind are highly liable to errors of interpretation and I am arranging for the honourable member to be sent a 1976 British Medical Journal leading article which reviews the technique under the heading 'Misleading Statistics'. Until the associations suggested by Mr Robinson's work have been tested by further studies of the nature described in this article, it would be premature to come to any conclusions on his findings.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Nuclear Power in Australia

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for National Development and Energy, upon notice, on 4 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: What is the basis for the projection made by the Australian Atomic Energy Commission, published in Atomic Energy in Australia, July 1980, that by the year 2000, there will be 900 megawatts of nuclear power installed in Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for National Development and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The figure quoted represented the AAEC's 'best estimate' of future nuclear power capacity based on information publicly available at the time. The possible location of a reactor was not specified, and the projected capacity of 900 MWe took account of the typical size of nuclear reactors being sold on the international market.

In reaching its estimate the Commission noted a Western Australian Government publication, An Energy Policy for Western Australia, which stated that the WA Government had 'taken positive action in establishing firm plans for the introduction of nuclear generation in the 1990s . . .' (page 3) and that 'Planning and siting studies will be carried out so that Western Australia can proceed to the installation of a nuclear power station by 1995' (page 11).

The Commission's projections also included a 'low estimate' of zero, to cover the possibility that no reactor might be installed in Australia by the year 2000, and a 'high estimate' of 1500 MWe in case reactors are installed by more than one State.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Infant Mortality

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 4 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to (a) the claims of the Infant Formula Action Coalition (INFACT) that more than one million infants die each year in Third World countries due, amongst other reasons, to the use of polluted water in the preparation of infant milk formulas and (b) the fact that Australia voted in favour of a world-wide advertising ban on the marketing of infant milk formulas.

(2) Can the high rate of infant mortality amongst Australian Aboriginals be attributed to (a) contaminated water supplies on Aboriginal reserves and the use of contaminated water in the preparation of infant formulas or (b) excessive dilution of infant formula.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (b) Yes. Australia voted in favour of the draft International Code of Marketing of Breastmilk Substitutes which was adopted by the World Health Assembly, Geneva on 21 May 1981.

(2) (a) and (b) No. The high infant mortality rate among Aboriginals as compared to the non-Aboriginal infant mortality rate is due to a variety of factors not least of which are the adverse environmental and living conditions prevailing in many Aboriginal communities which place infants at risk from respiratory, gastrointestinal and other communicable disease. To attribute this entirely to the use of contaminated water or excessive dilution of infant formula, in the preparation of infant feeds, as has been reputed to occur in Third World countries, would be incorrect.

Sporadic incidents and occasional epidemics of gastrointestinal infections do still occur, but the presence of Aboriginal health workers, (chosen by their communities), who are trained in preventive measures and capable of administering prompt and effective treatment, has resulted in a decline in both mortality and morbidity. Breast feeding is also encouraged and where formula feeding is necessary, health workers can assist and train mothers in hygiene and other measures necessary in preparation of feeds.

The Government recognises that while there has been some improvement in Aboriginal health status in recent years, it is still unacceptably low and, among measures necessary to achieve further improvement, priority is being given to the provision of appropriate housing, clean and adequate water supplies and sanitation.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Foreign Investment in Australia

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 5 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: What has been the net effect on the balance of payments of foreign investment in enterprises in Australia in each year since 1970-71.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The inflow of foreign investment in enterprises in Australia, depending upon the uses to which it is put, can have several effects on the capital and current accounts of the balance of payments. In addition to its direct and immediate effect of providing Australia with financial resources from the rest of the world, the investments undertaken with foreign capital may reduce Australia's reliance upon imports or develop exports and also affect the current account through servicing payments.

While it is not possible to trace through all the effects of foreign investment inflows on the capital and current accounts of the balance of payments, it is clear that Australia has been able to sustain a deficit on current account, and thus have command over a greater pool of goods and services than are able to be produced domestically, because of the contribution of foreign capital.

The relative importance of foreign investment in enterprises in Australia can be gauged from a comparison of such inflow with an indicator of aggregate economic activity in Australia. ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Mobile Homes

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Housing and Construction, upon notice, on 5 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the nature and extent of work being carried out within his Department in relation to the design and development of mobile homes or transportable homes.
(2) Which company or companies are involved in the design or development of a prototype mobile home or transportable home.

(3) What other Commonwealth and State authorities are involved, or have been involved, in consideration of proposals for the design, development, marketing, sale or rental of mobile homes and mobile homes' parks.
(4) Which locations have been considered for the placement of mobile homes and transportable homes.
(5) What measures are available for the transportation of mobile homes.
(6) What planning codes in each State and Territory would require amendment to allow for the sale or rental of mobile or transportable homes for dwelling purposes.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Department of Housing and Construction has been undertaking work on a type of manufactured housing, commonly called mobile homes, which has been very successful in the USA.
The Commonwealth-State Ministerial Council on Housing Costs has been considering the potential of manufactured/ mobile homes to offer lower cost housing in Australia.

The Department undertook a review of mobile homes in Australia and overseas for the Council. It is assisting the Council to develop model guidelines for the construction and siting of manufactured homes. The construction guidelines are being developed within the principles implicit in the Australian Model Uniform Building Code to maintain acceptable health and safety standards without the emphasis on conventional site building techniques.

The Department is acquiring a prototype manufactured house based on North American design principles featuring a lightweight stressed skin construction box beam design on an integrated steel chassis with its own running gear and suitable for replacement on low cost foundations. The prototype will help governments, industry, and consumers to assess the quality and potential of this type of dwelling.
(2) Neilsen Design Associates Pty Limited were engaged by the Department to assist with the preparatory design work for the prototype as the basis for tenders.
The contract to construct the prototype manufactured house has been let to Yarrawonga Housing Industries Pty Limited.
(3) I am not aware of any other Commonwealth authority being involved in the design or development of mobile homes and mobile home parks.

State and Territory Governments are participating with the Commonwealth in the Ministerial Council on Housing Costs in reviewing the potential of manufactured housing and developing model guidelines. The Council has informed the Planning Ministers Conference and the Local Government Ministers Conference.

While I understand from meetings of the Council that some States are interested in giving more detailed consideration to manufactured housing, I have no information on specific proposals they may be considering.
The Age newspaper of 5 June 1981 reported that the Victorian Housing Minister was reviewing proposals for a pilot scheme in Victoria.

The New South Wales Parliamentary Inquiry into Caravan and Mobile Home Parks recommended that mobile homes be studied as a form of alternative housing and consideration be given to a pilot scheme of mobile homes in a mobile home park. I am informed that following the Inquiry a committee of officials on mobile homes was set up to pursue this recommendation.

(4) The Department of Housing and Construction is not involved in the placement of mobile homes other than the prototype manufactured house, for which consideration is being given to various locations for display in the eastern States.
I have no specific information on locations being considered by the States for the placement of mobile homes.

Transportable houses have been used by Commonwealth authorities and others in various parts of Australia, especially rural and remote areas, over a long period and usually where they are a more practical option to site building.

(5) Transportation of a mobile home in North America usually consists of running gear which is attached to the integrated steel chassis. The running gear can be subsequently removed and re-used or left on the house. It is also possible to place the home on a low loader.

The Australian Transport Advisory Council and the National Association of State Roads Authorities are considering appropriate policies and regulation for the movement of manufactured housing. It will be up to the market place to develop the most appropriate cost-effective means of transportation.
(6) I understand that the sale or rental of mobile or transportable homes for dwelling purposes is not generally subject to planning codes.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Welfare Housing

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Housing and Construction, upon notice, on 5 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: In view of the statement made during his second reading speech on the Housing Assistance Bill 1981 that a total sum of $630m was made available for welfare housing in 1979-80 (Hansard, 14 May 1981, page 2440), (a) what sum was provided by (i) the Commonwealth and (ii) each State and Territory, (b) for what purposes was it provided and (c) what was the equivalent sum provided by the Commonwealth and each State and Territory for these purposes in each year from 1974-75.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) and (b) The information in respect of the six States is shown at Table 2 (pages 6 and 7) of the Annual Report on the operations of the Housing Assistance Act 1978 during 1979-80, which was tabled in the Parliament on 6 May 1981.
Appendix VI of the Report contains information for the Northern Territory.

(c) The Annual Report to Parliament on the operations of the Housing Assistance Act 1978 for the 1978-79 financial year, at Table 2 (pages 6 and 7) shows the information for the six States. Details are not available for the Northern Territory for 1978-79.
For years prior to 1978-79, a similar analysis of sources of funds is not available.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Future Dwelling Stock Requirements

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Housing and Construction, upon notice, on 5 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: On the basis of the projections contained in the Review of Australia's Demographic Trends prepared by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs in February 1981 and on the basis of the most recent and reliable assumptions of the growth in household headship ratios, what are the (a) projected total dwelling stock requirements to the year 2001 and (b) average annual dwelling completion requirements to the year 2001 for (i) each State and Territory and (ii) Australia as a whole.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) and (b) Projections of the type requested, especially over such a long period, are subject to considerable uncertainty at the national level and even greater uncertainty at the State and Territory level, where interstate migration is an important factor to be considered. Whilst it is possible to produce a single set of figures as requested, this would imply a degree of precision in forecasting methodologies which does not pertain.

That is why a range of projections of annual additional dwelling requirements for each State were presented in Chapter 5 of the 1981 Report of the Indicative Planning Council for the Housing Industry which I tabled in the Parliament on 10 June 1981. The demographic projections on which the demand estimates in that Report are based are generally consistent with the sets of assumptions suggested in the Review of Australia's Demographic Trends although this Review did not produce population estimates below the national level.
Projections of total dwelling stock requirements can be derived from these estimates, after allowing for replacement for stock losses, and the 1976 Census count of dwellings.
I therefore refer the honourable member for Reid to the 1981 Report of the Indicative Planning Council for the Housing Industry.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Service Personnel: Discharge for Use of Marijuana

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 5 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Were a number of Service personnel discharged, for the use of marijuana whilst not on duty, in the Wagga area, NSW.
(2) If so, were they prosecuted for a breach of the law and were they convicted.
(3) Are Service personnel who have been charged and convicted in connection with the use of alcohol discharged from the Services.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Twelve airmen and airwomen of RAAF Base Wagga were discharged during May 1981 as a result of their involvement in the non-medical use of drugs.
(2) Disciplinary action was not taken. However, the members involved were discharged from the RAAF according to prescribed administrative procedures.
(3) Each case is considered on its merits. Servicemen are not normally discharged as the result of a civilian or military conviction in connection with the use of alcohol.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Medical Benefits: Transcendental Meditation

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 5 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are medical benefits paid for professional attendances consisting of exercises in Transcendental Meditation (TM).
(2) If so, on what basis did his Department decide that TM is a medical service.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) No. However, if transcendental meditation was prescribed as a relaxation technique by a medical practitioner during the course of a professional attendance, benefits would be payable for that attendance under the appropriate consultation item. In this situation the benefits are payable on the grounds that there is a physical attendance by a legally qualified medical practitioner upon the patient.

The fact that benefits are payable for an attendance at which transcendental meditation is prescribed should not be construed as an indication of support for the practice. As medical benefits are attracted for consultations by legally qualified medical practitioners, it would be neither practical nor desirable to attempt to restrict the way in which doctors choose to conduct their consultations. I might also mention that a request for a specific Medical Benefits Schedule item for transcendental meditation was rejected.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: New Zealand/Australia Free Trade Agreement

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 9 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a submission of 20 May 1981 by the Queensland Commercial Fishermen's Organisation to the Queensland Premier and others protesting at imports of sea perch fish and fillets from New Zealand produced on giant Soviet trawlers in the Tasman Sea built, owned and manned by Soviet citizens, with crews trained by their Government, using fuel exempt from OPEC price agreements and engaged in joint ventures with New Zealand partners, with a 20 per cent New Zealand export subsidy and no right to sell in New Zealand under New Zealand law.
(2) If so, has this product rivalled reef fish in appeal.
(3) Does this product cost wholesale, as alleged, approximately $3.10 per kilogram at the Queensland Fish Board compared to $4.10 per kilogram for Queensland mackerel.

(4) Has the Government received a request for anti-dumping action under Article 10 of the New Zealand/Australia Free Trade Agreement; if not, will he consult urgently with the State authorities on this matter.

(5) Has there been months-long delays in providing the promised extension of Rural Reconstruction Funds to the fishing industry; if so, have the deliberations of the Committee of Review of Commonwealth Functions been responsible for the delays.

(6) Is he able to say whether the Queensland Fish Board has blamed, over-ridden and reduced payments to fishermen consistently as a means of attacking marketing problems despite long dissatisfaction of fishermen with the management with the Board's promotion, marketing efficiency, communication with them and buy-in prices.

(7) Will he assist fishermen planning regional co-operatives to overcome these problems and liaise with the Queensland Government to achieve industrial democracy in industries protecting Australia from unfair competition from nationalised big business which is free of the bureaucratic inefficiencies and restraints suffered by Queensland fishermen on their fuel prices and orderly marketing.

(8) Will he (a) inquire whether the Soviet fishermen get better conditions and more prompt replies to their organisation's correspondence from their marketing managers than the Queensland Commercial Fishermen's Organisation gets from the Queensland Fish Board, or (b) sponsor cultural exchanges between the fishermen and marketing managers of Australia and those of the Soviet Union and other efficient fishing nations to prevent international tensions such as those which led to the ruinous cod war between Britain and Iceland.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I have been advised that the Queensland Commercial Fishermen's Organisation has expressed concern about imported New Zealand fish although my attention has not been drawn to that particular submission.
(2) and (3) While prices of both types of fish vary, I understand that the imported sea perch does rival reef fish in appeal and is cheaper.

(4) The Government has not received any specific request for anti-dumping action on New Zealand sea perch, although complaints have been made that imports of fish from New Zealand and elsewhere are causing difficulties for Australian fishermen. I have already been in touch with the Queensland Minister for Primary Industries concerning the matter.

(5) The question of structural adjustment for the fishing industry was discussed at a meeting on 26 June 1981 between Federal, State and Northern Territory Ministers responsible for the administration of the Rural Adjustment Scheme.
Ministers reached agreement on the framework of a scheme for the fishing industry but a decision to proceed with its implementation was deferred pending resolution of some issues relating to funding.
The deliberations of the Committee of Review of Commonwealth Functions have not delayed consideration of this matter.
(6) and (7) These are matters which should be addressed to the Queensland Government.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Opinion Polls: Publication before Elections

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 9 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say whether the French Government disallows the publication of results of opinion polls for a number of days before the beginning of their Presidential elections.
(2) Is it a fact that some controversy surrounded the effects of opinion polls on the National election held in Australia on 18 October 1980.
(3) Did he express the view, during the course of the election campaign, that opinion could have a distorting influence on the outcome of the election.
(4) Will he consider adopting a similar policy to that adopted in France toward the publication of results of opinion polls prior to Australian elections.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (4) Any effect that opinion polls may or may not have on the outcome of elections is a matter for debate.
The most important elements in determining the outcome of elections are the policies and performance of the parties involved.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Oil Pollution

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Johnson The Hon L.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 9 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to research designed to deal with the problems of oil slicks being undertaken by British Petroleum (BP) at the research centre at Sunbury on Thames, United Kingdom.
(2) Will he investigate this new process, to see whether as is alleged it does solidify oil into a substance which is cleaner to handle and can be readily collected.
(3) If so, and if the process is seen to be successful, will he seek the introduction of this new process without delay in the fight to prevent the oil pollution of Australian waters.
(4) If the Government is of the view that the process is not suitable, will he provide full details of the reasons for its decision.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. Details of this research have been advised by the United Kingdom Government authorities and by BP Australia Ltd.

(2) The research is a continuation of laboratory work that has been in progress for two and a half years. Basically the treatment involves the preparation of a synthetic compound which, when applied to spilled oil at the rate of approximately one part of compound to five parts of oil, solidifies the oil into rubber like lumps. These lumps are apparently clean to handle and may be physically lifted from the water surface.
It is expected that sea tests will be conducted during July 1981. The results of these tests will be passed onto my Department by the United Kingdom Government authority involved.
(3) If the solidification process is seen as successful and its application feasible consideration will be given to its incorporation in the National Plan to Combat Pollution of the Sea by Oil.
(4) The process has not yet been field tested so the information on which to base a decision is not yet available.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Conference System of Shipping

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morris Mr P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 10 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: What specific action is he proposing in respect of the liner restrictive practices of the Conference System of shipping used to transport Australia's general cargo overseas trade given the Government's stated policy of supporting competition and free enterprise.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The framework for commercial negotiations under the shipping provisions of the Trade Practices Act 1974 is consistent with the Government's free enterprise policies. The Government recognises the benefits to Australian exporters which a well managed conference system can provide in terms of frequency, reliability and regularity of services. However, it also welcomes the competitive element provided by alternative commercial services as long as they do not adversely affect the adequacy of shipping services for Australian trading interests.

The proposals for changes to Australia's overseas cargo shipping legislation which were foreshadowed in the last Parliament are currently under examination in the light of further advice from industry.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Statistical Wind Data

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Innes Mr U.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 10 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Do published International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) standards require the use of statistical wind data within the 95 per cent probability when designing locator patterns if this wind data is available.
(2) Has statistical wind data from the nearest official bureau of meteorology weather measuring station been utilised when calculating the locator pattern boundary at Ripley.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. ICAO has not published Standards and Recommended Practices relating to the design of holding patterns. The ICAO procedures which have been published are statements of operation practices with respect to which a measure of international uniformity is desirable. It is important to note that, where statistical wind data are available, the published ICAO material recommends the use of maximum wind speed within the 95 per cent probability calculated on an omnidirectional basis.

(2) No. Because statistical wind data are not always available, the Australian practice is to use an alternative ICAO formula for calculating wind velocities. This then allows standardised holding patterns to be used in all cases and produces a result which is less restrictive, in most cases, then the use of statistical data.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: National Health Scheme Prescriptions

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 10 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the definition of an urgent prescription left to the discretion of the prescriber when determining to request dispensing by telephone or other means of National Health Scheme (NHS) items before receipt of written prescription by the dispenser.
(2) What categories of persons are (a) recognised and permitted and (b) forbidden to communicate the contents of such a prescription from prescriber to dispenser.

(3) If no third party arrangements are allowed in such cases will this mean the NHS dispensing fee will be increased to allow for two trips by pharmacists (a) to collect prescriptions from hospitals and clinics and (b) to deliver the items prescribed, instead of as frequently at present one trip where the prescription and item are checked by each party before being exchanged.

(4) When an agreement exists for one pharmacist to relieve another for after-hours dispensing, what restrictions are there on the rights of the dispenser to collect the patient moiety from the pharmacist with whom the patient has a continuing account.
(5) If 5 litres of intravenous fluid are prescribed on NHS and only 2 litres used by the patient, what must the hospital do with the remaining 3 litres.

(6) Will intravenous NHS items be placed on the same basis for hospitals and doctors as doctors' bag supplies so that no patient moiety is charged, at least where a responsible hospital officer acknowledges receipt of those items.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Under the National Health legislation it is the prescriber, that is a medical practitioner or participating dental practitioner who determines whether or not a prescription is required to be dispensed urgently and who is required to communicate the prescription to the dispenser in order that the pharmaceutical benefit can be supplied before the prescription is surrendered to the dispenser.

(3) (a) and (b) The medical practitioner or participating dental practitioner who has comdispenser shall reduce the communicated prescription to writing within 24 hours of the communication and despatch the prescription to the dispenser.

Only one professional fee is payable for each supply of a pharmaceutical benefit. However, the approved chemist supplying the benefit is entitled to charge the patient the cost of delivery when supply is made other than at the premises in respect of which he is approved.

(4) It is the responsibility of the approved person supplying the pharmaceutical benefit from the particular premises in respect of which he is approved, to charge the patient contribution for each supply of a pharmaceutical benefit except where supply is made to eligible pensioners or sickness beneficiaries in which case no patient contribution is payable.

(5) Under the terms of the National Health legislation when a pharmaceutical benefit is supplied to the patient it becomes the property of that patient for whom it is prescribed. Section 103 (4) of the National Health Act states:

'A person for whom a prescription for a pharmaceutical benefit is written or to whom a pharmaceutical benefit is supplied shall not use, dispose of or otherwise deal with the pharmaceutical benefit in a way other than that for which the prescription was written or the pharmaceutical benefit supplied.

(6) It is the function of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee, an independant statutory body, to make recommendations to me, as Minister for Health, on matters concerning the availability of items listed as pharmaceutical benefits. Such matters would include any recommendation that intravenous fluids be made available as benefits in a similar arrangement to that which applies to those items available as Emergency Drug (Doctor's Bag) Supplies.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Commission: Australian Labor Party Campaign

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 9 April 1981 (Hansard, page 1519) Mr Ian Robinson asked me, as Minister for Communications, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is it a fact that a senior reporter with the Australian Broadcasting Commission maintained a virtual open line contact with a senior Australian Labor Party campaign official throughout the 1980 Federal election campaign and that the Australian Labor Party used this link to try to apply pressure on ABC producers? It is further a fact that the Australian Labor Party was being given advance information about the content of ABC current affairs programs and that the Australian Labor Party through this contact attempted to influence the coverage given to the Government side? Were program producers threatened by the Australian Labor Party? Did they find it necessary to complain to the management? Finally, can the Minister inform the House whether at the end of the election campaign the reporter concerned was a guest at a 'thank you' party put on by the Australian Labor Party?
The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

The General Manager of the ABC has advised me that it is normal practice, during an election campaign, for reporters to have daily contact with officers of all political parties. There is no evidence to suggest any untoward contact existed between an ABC reporter and an ALP official during the last Federal election campaign.

The General Manager further points out that had advance information about the content of ABC public affairs programs been given to such an official by a reporter, that information could not have been used to influence the content of the programs, professional responsibility for which rests not with the reporter but with an executive producer.

It is a fact that on one occasion during the election campaign an executive producer answered a persistently-ringing telephone while a reporter was otherwise engaged and spoke to a person who identified herself as being a press officer with the ALP. It is also true that this person spoke forcefully to the executive producer who asked if she was attempting to bring political pressure to bear. At that point the caller terminated the conversation and apologised.
The incident caused concern and was brought to the attention of a member of the ABC's senior management.

It is not unusual for reporters to attend parties given by all contenders in an election. As the honourable member does not name a particular reporter whether or not this reporter attended an ALP party, and if so, in what capacity, is not known.

(2) Are personal telephone calls, particularly trunk and STD calls, made by staff of his Department controlled; if so, in what way.

(2) What sum will the Government save as a result of this action.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Compulsory Rent Control was abolished in the Australian Capital Territory on 16 December 1976 and was replaced by a voluntary fair renting scheme whereby lessors, owners or lessees could make application to the Rent Controller for a Fair Rent to be determined. However, very few lessors/lessees have taken advantage of the provisions of this scheme, with only 23 determinations being made in the 12 months to 30 April 1981. This is despite the fact that it is estimated that there are currently at least 10,000 privately let residential premises in the Australian Capital Territory.
The Government's recent decision will do away with all forms of Rent Control in the Territory and thus reduce the cost of bureaucracy and leave rent levels subject to competitive forces.
Emergency housing for those in need is available.
(2) The potential administrative savings, based on the level of activity over the past 2 years, would be in the order of $8,000 in a full year.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Post-graduate Engineering Students

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Mr B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 2 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the assertion of Professor Lance Endersbee, Dean of Engineering at Monash University, Victoria, that only 20 per cent of post-graduate engineering students at Monash University are Australian residents.
(2) Is there any substance to this claim; if so, can he say what is the major reason for the small numbers of Australian engineers proceeding with post-graduate studies.
(3) Does the Government endeavour to encourage more Australians to continue these studies in this field.

(4) Is the high drop-out rate in Australian post-graduate studies largely attributable to low levels of tertiary assistance compared to salaries offered by businesses to young graduates in some disciplines.
(5) If so, will the imposition of fees for second degrees exacerbate this tendency.
(6) Will he undertake to reconsider the future national implications of the reimposition of fees for second degrees.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) Information provided to the Universities Council of the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission by Monash University shows that, out of a total of 239 students enrolled for higher degree courses in the Engineering Faculty in 1980, approximately 50 were identified as being overseas students. Even allowing for some discrepancies arising from various definitions of overseas students, it would appear that a substantial majority of students undertaking post-graduate engineering courses at Monash University are Australian residents.

(3) Under the Commonwealth Post Graduate award scheme it has been the policy since the scheme began not to earmark awards for particular fields of study. The scheme is seen to be one of general support across the whole range of higher degree studies.

(4) The stipend under Post Graduate Awards has always been significantly lower than the salaries available to graduates in employment. It is for the individual to assess whether the pursuit of higher degree studies under award conditions is preferable to the immediate financial advantages of employment. Acceptance of the award reflects the view that it is in the Award holder's long term interest to pursue a higher level of research and study at that stage rather than embark upon or continue in employment.

(5) and (6) A significant number of higher degree students, including full-time academic staff in tertiary institutions and holders of Commonwealth Government awards will be exempt from tuition fees. Higher degree students holding awards of $3500 per annum or more from State governments, universities and colleges of advanced education will also be exempt from tuition fees.

The Government acknowledges the importance of tertiary education to the economy and to the community generally but it believes that there are substantial benefits which flow to individuals from tertiary education and the community as a whole should not be expected to meet all of the costs. The Government is proceeding with arrangements for the re-introduction of fees in 1982. It will monitor the experience in that year.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Tuition Fees: Universities and Colleges of Advanced Education

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Young Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 4 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are tuition fees to be introduced in universities and colleges of advanced education for students undertaking degrees and diplomas subsequent to an initial tertiary qualification, except for recognised double degree or diploma combinations; if so, what is the definition of an initial tertiary qualification and will diplomas or associate diplomas gained in technical and further education institutions be classified as an initial tertiary qualification.
(2) What are recognised double degree or diploma combinations.

(3) Are fees to apply to new enrolments from 1982; if so, (a) what will be the definition of a new enrolment, (b) will students who have deferred their higher degree enrolment be liable for fees and (c) will only students classified by the institutions as continuing students be eligible for exemption from the payment of fees.

(4) Will postgraduate students who receive Commonwealth postgraduate awards and university or college scholarships be exempt from the payment of fees; if so, will students who extend their enrolment beyond the length of their award become liable for the payment of fees.
(5) Will students on private scholarships be liable to pay fees.

(6) Will overseas students currently (a) exempted from the payment of the Overseas Student Charge under Statutory Rules No. 290, section 4, and (b) required to pay the Overseas Student Charge, be required to pay the new tuition fee.

(7) Will students who fail to complete their first qualification and enrol in another course be required to pay tuition fees for the second course; if so, for what proportion of the second course will they be required to pay fees.
(8) What will be the level of fees set and will it be different for universities and colleges of advanced education.
(9) Will a separate rate be levied for (a) part-time students and (b) external students; if so, what will be the levels in each case.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Tuition fees will be introduced for students undertaking degrees and diplomas subsequent to an initial qualification be it a degree or diploma or recognised combined course. Students will not be required to pay tuition fees if they are upgrading a diploma to a degree, or an associate diploma (or other equivalent course) to a diploma or degree in the same field as the initial qualification.
(2) I will be announcing details of recognised combined courses as soon as possible.

(3) (a) The new arrangements for the payment of tuition fees will apply to students enrolling to commence second or higher qualifications in 1982. (b) Students who have deferred their higher degree enrolment will be liable for tuition fees if they have not commenced the higher degree course before 1982. (c) No. See answer to (a) above.

(4) Higher degree students in receipt of Commonwealth Government awards will be exempt from tuition fees as will higher degree students in receipt of awards of at least $3500 per annum from universities, colleges of advanced education and State Governments. Higher degree students who extend their enrolment beyond the length of these awards will be exempt from tuition fees for the remainder of the course.
(8) An annual tuition fee of $1000 will apply for full-time students in universities and colleges of advanced education.
(9) Tuition fees for internal and external part-time students will be calculated by individual tertiary institutions on a pro rata basis.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Regulation and Control of Nuclear Activities

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Trade and Resources, upon notice, on 9 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to the Prime Minister's statement to the Parliament on 30 April 1981, as part of the Review of Commonwealth Functions, that responsibilities for the regulation and control of nuclear activities are to be implemented as far as possible by the States and Northern Territory, with the Commonwealth maintaining a co-ordinating role (Hansard, page 1837), which responsibilities for the regulation and control of nuclear activities within his portfolio will no longer be implemented by the Commonwealth.
(2) Have assurances been sought from the States that they will now implement these responsibilities; if so, what replies have been forthcoming.
(3) What arrangements exist or are proposed for the Commonwealth to play a co-ordinating role.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) As Minister of State for Trade and Resources, I have certain responsiblities for the regulation and control of nuclear activities under the Atomic Energy Act as set out for my portfolio in the Administrative Arrangements Order. On 5 June 1981, in a joint statement with the Minister for National Development and Energy, I foreshadowed far reaching changes to Commonwealth legislation on nuclear matters which would affect, in particular, the Atomic Energy Act. In line with the Government's decision on the Review of Commonwealth Functions, responsibility for the regulation and control of nuclear activities in Australia will be implemented as far as possible by the States and the Northern Territory with the Commonwealth maintaining a co-ordinating role. Any changes which might occur in the responsibilities within my own portfolio could depend, to an extent, on the outcome of the discussions and negotiations with the States and the Northern Territory on control and regulation of nuclear matters.

(2) and (3) The Government in co-operation with the States and the Northern Territory will seek to establish a revised legal basis to cover nuclear activities through appropriate State legislation, complemented as necessary by Commonwealth legislation, taking account of the respective competences of the Commonwealth, the States and the Northern Territory. In the development of the new legislative base, Government officials have been asked to maintain close consultation with the States and the Northern Territory.
