ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Mineral Extraction, Processing and Export Developments

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morris Mr P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 7 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many studies has he commissioned the Bureau of Transport Economics or his Department to undertake into the implications and requirements that expanded mineral extraction, processing and export developments will pose for the Australian transport sector.
(2) What priorities in terms of resources and personnel have been given to these studies.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The implications of resource developments for the Australian Transport sector are taken into account in the ongoing work of the Bureau of Transport Economics, the Department, the Australian Railway Research and Development Organisation and in the intergovernmental consultative fora of the Australian Transport Advisory Council and the Marine and Ports Council of Australia. Moreover, close liaison is maintained with both industry and other Government portfolios.
Recent examples of the work of the Bureau of Transport Economics include a Study of Western Australian Ports, and the Economic Evaluation of Proposed Completion of the Sandy Hollow-Maryvale Railway.

The Study of Western Australian Ports was carried out jointly by the Office of the Director General of Transport in Western Australia and the Bureau of Transport Economics and included consideration of the needs of the expanding mineral industry. The Sandy Hollow-Maryvale Railway study was concerned with the development of the Ulan coal seam and the carriage of grain and metalliferous concentrates.

At the instigation of the Marine and Ports Council of Australia the Bureau of Transport Economics is to undertake a study of the extension of the standard gauge rail links to the ports of Brisbane, Melbourne and Geelong. As a matter of course this will comprehend forecast impacts of resource developments projects.

At a more general level my Department will be providing a submission to the Senate Standing Committee on Trade and Commerce Inquiry into the Australian export coal industry. Furthermore, the Bureau of Transport Economics is preparing a paper on the transport implications of resource developments for the Transport Outlook Conference later this year.

The honourable member may be interested to know that the jointly funded State/Commonwealth body Australian Railway Research and Development Organisation is expected to release its 1981 Report on Rail later this year. The report will articulate a basis for rail's future role and is expected to outline future rail infrastructure investment requirements.

Within the Australian Transport Advisory Council, the Railway Group is giving consideration to the question of rail infrastructure requirements. It is expected that this work will be further progressed on completion of the ARRDO 1981 Report. This will of course have direct relevance to the infrastructure requirements of the resources boom.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Nuclear Power Plants

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for National Development and Energy, upon notice, on 8 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Can the Minister say how many deaths resulted from breakdowns and accidents in (a) nuclear power plants in (i) Britain, (ii) the United States of America, (iii) the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and (iv) Switzerland between 1947 and 1970, and (b) alternative energy industries producing the same proportion of the electrical supply for the same countries.

(2) Can he also say what compensation was paid by governments or companies to farmers and others for damage done by unplanned nuclear contamination from nuclear reactors in the countries referred to in part (1).

(3) Can he also say whether the Price-Anderson Act limits the United States of America government and corporate liability to $560 million for each nuclear generator despite the likelihood that a melt-down accident would cause billions of dollars of property damage and casualties comparable to the Hiroshima bombing.
(4) Is it a fact that insurance firms offered cover for nuclear accidents with premiums comparable to those for other power plants in the United States.

(5) Is it also a fact that short-term employees in nuclear plants are used to limit radiation doses to 30 to 100 times recommended civilian dose tolerances of gamma rays without monitoring of alpha and beta radiation.
(6) Can he say whether the short-term employees referred to in part (5) are free to seek return employment at other reactors in the United States without checking previous radiation exposure.

(7) Can he also say whether recommended limits of exposure for civilians are roughly twice background radiation levels and believed to cause double the incidence of malignant diseases attributable to or contributed to by background radiation.

(8) Can he also say whether medical follow-up records are kept to monitor incidences of leukemia for 10 years and cancers for 20 years after industrial exposure to radiation as is done for those exposed to Hiroshima and Nagasaki bomb fallout; if so, (a) where are the follow-ups practised and (b) which employees are informed of the importance of these follow-ups while in relevant employment.

(9) Has his attention been drawn to claims that hundreds were killed, tens of thousands affected and a dead wasteland created after a nuclear disaster in Kyshtym, USSR in 1958, and that these details were first released from Central Intelligence Agency files in 1977 under the Freedom of Information Act.
(10) Has the Government plans to pass legislation for Australia similar to the United States Freedom of Information Act.

(11) Are (a) costs of decommissioning, (b) waste disposal, (c) guarding of waste and (e) estimated increases in radioactive contamination of humans and other species included in estimates of costs of nuclear-generated electricity; if so, what proportion of the cost is so assessed.
(12) How do costs of nuclear-generated power in the United States compare with charges for electricity made to aluminium smelting firms in Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for National Development and Energy has provided the following answers to the honourable member's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) and (b) The Government does not maintain comprehensive statistics regarding deaths from breakdowns and accidents in overseas power generating plants. However, there have been no fatal radiation accidents at commercial nuclear power plants in Britain, the United States of America or Switzerland, and I am not aware of any fatal radiation accidents at USSR nuclear power plants. Comparative studies of electricity generation from various energy sources indicate that, in terms of occupational and public health risk, and taking into account all stages of the relevant fuel cycles, nuclear powered plants are considerably safer than coal or oil fired plants.

(2) The only nuclear reactor accident in Britain during the period 1947 to 1970 resulting in radioactive contamination of property was the Windscale accident in 1957. The United Kingdom Atomic Energy Authority, in accepting responsibility for the accident, paid claims amounting to #Stg 70,000 mainly for financial losses incurred by the Milk Marketing Board and local farmers as a result of radioactive iodine contamination. I am not aware of any accident to a nuclear reactor in the USA, USSR or Switzerland during the period in question resulting in contamination of farms or other property.
(3) The Price-Anderson Act currently limits the aggregate liability of licensees of nuclear plants in the United States for a single nuclear incident to $US560 million.

(4) In the United States nuclear plants must be insured in accordance with the Price-Anderson Act. Rates and policies have been arrived at under special arrangements with the insurance industry, and are not directly comparable with premiums applying to non-nuclear power plants.

(5) The International Commission on Radiological Protection (ICRP) recommends that radiation workers, whether short term or long term, should receive no more than 50 millisieverts in a year and that members of the public should receive no more than 5 millisieverts in a year for short term (a few years) exposure and no more than an average of 1 millisievert a year when averaged over a lifetime. These limits do not include doses received from background radiation or medical procedures. The 1977 report of the United Nations Scientific Committee on the Effects of Atomic Radiation (UNSCEAR) shows the average doses received by radiation workers in United States nuclear power plants to be 10 millisieverts per year, and in Britain 2-5 millisieverts per year. Almost all radiation experienced in nuclear power plants is gamma radiation, associated with a small proportion of beta radiation. The proportions of gamma and beta radiation are measured by film dosimetry. The only time alpha radiation would be present is in the handling of ruptured fuel, and if suspected is monitored separately.
(6) Short term employees seeking employment elsewhere in the industry in the United States are required to disclose their previous radiation exposure levels.

(7) Exposure to the maximum long term ICRP recommended dose of 1 millisievert in addition to the average natural background radiation dose, also of 1 millisievert, could be expected to double the mortality risk attributable to background radiation alone. The combined risk, however, would only amount to 1.4 per cent of that from cancer from all causes.

(8) (a) In most countries with large nuclear industries, licensees maintain cumulative records relating to employees' radiation exposures. Some countries, e.g. Canada, have established national registries for this purpose. Studies of the incidence of cancers arising in radiation workers have been undertaken in several countries, for example, USA and UK. In Australia, records of radiation exposures are kept by centres operating personal monitoring services. The Australian Radiation Laboratory of the Department of Health is remodelling its personal monitoring service to provide for determination of working lifetime doses. This service covers over half of the radiation workers in Australia.

(b) Licensees are required to instruct all individuals, working in or frequenting any portion of a restricted area, on the health protection problems associated with exposure to radioactive materials or radiation.

(9) There have been conflicting reports of the cause and magnitude of the claimed USSR disaster. No information has been released by Soviet authorities. The honourable member's attention is also drawn to answers to Questions Nos. 1633 and 1658 answered in the Senate on 25 February 1977 (pages 508 and 509).
(10) The Attorney-General introduced the Freedom of Information Bill in the Senate on 2 April 1981.

(11) (a) Currently not all power generating authorities include decommissioning costs in their rates. In the United States typical quotes for allocations to cover decomissionings are around $2.5-3.5 million per year which translates to about 2-4 per cent of current generation costs. Similar percentages have been estimated recently for the Federal Republic of Germany.

(b) and (c) Generally the cost of guarding and disposing of the wastes arising from the nuclear generation of electricity using current disposal methods are included in the rates charged by the generating authorities. This is a small fraction of the total generating cost, e.g. the cost of ultimate disposal of all waste arising from the light water reactor fuel cycle was estimated by an International Nuclear Fuel Cycle Evaluation (INFCE) study to be in the range of 0.10 to 0.16 cents per kilowatt hour (1978 US dollars). This would be about 3-5 per cent of the total generating cost for a reactor coming on line in the 1977-78 period.

(e) Regulatory requirements for the nuclear industry ensure that radioactive contamination of humans and other species does not exceed limits established by public health and environment protection authorities. The costs associated with meeting these regulatory requirements are included in the costs of nuclear generated electricity.

(12) A recent analysis of nuclear generation costs for 1979 prepared by the US Department of Energy, including data from 61 operating nuclear power stations (all rated over 400 MWe), indicated a unit cost of the order of 2.1 cents US/kWH: at current rates of exchange, this is equivalent to 1.9 cents Aust./kWH. The price of electricity to Australian smelters is publicly available in only two cases. ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Sale of Post Offices

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 14 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Are there any plans to (a) close down or (b) hand over or sell to the private sector, any post offices in Western Australia; if so, which post offices will be affected and when is it anticipated that this will be done.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) Australia Post continually reviews its network of post offices to ensure that the facilities and services provided best meet the reasonable needs of the community, having regard to economy in operation. Under this program, post offices in all States may be identified for closure, where the level of business transacted is not sufficent to justify retention. It is Australia Post's objective to ensure that reasonable alternative arrangements for postal services are made for communities affected by a closure.

In Western Australia, the following offices are scheduled for closure, because the level of postal business transacted at each office cannot justify their continued operation. Australia Post considers that alternative arrangements for postal services in each area affected will meet the reasonable needs of residents concerned.
All relevant Federal and State Members of Parliament and local representative bodies have been advised of the proposed closures.

(b) Australia Post has no plans to hand over or to sell any post offices to the private sector. It is Australia Post policy, however, that small official post offices may be converted to the non-official method of operation, when the volumes of postal business transacted are no longer sufficient to justify continuation under official conditions. Under non-official conditions, Australia Post arranges for the conduct of post offices on an agency type basis, but it still retains control of these offices. No offices in Western Australia have been identified, at this stage, for conversion to non-official conditions.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Concessions to Pensioners for Funeral Expenses

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister, representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 27 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is a pensioner whose income falls below the tax-free threshold and who meets the funeral expenses of a deceased next of kin and former taxpayer, entitled to any financial concession in respect of the funeral expenses.
(2) What financial concession is made available to a (a) taxpaying pensioner and (b) non-taxpaying pensioner in respect of funeral expenses.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) A pensioner who is a taxpayer may be entitled to funeral benefit and/or (2) taxation concessions in respect of the funeral expenses of a deceased person.

Under the provisions of the Social Services Act a funeral benefit of up to $40 is payable to any age, invalid or widow pensioner or supporting parent beneficiary whose annual income apart from pension or benefit is less than $2,040 (single) or $1,768 (married person) and who is liable for the funeral costs of either an age, invalid or widow pensioner or supporting parent beneficiary whose income also falls within those limits, or a spouse, or a child in his care. Where the pensioner or beneficiary has dependants, the income limits are higher than those mentioned.

A funeral benefit of up to $20 is payable to any person who is not entitled to the $40 benefit but who is liable for the funeral costs of an age or invalid pensioner whose income fell within the limits stated above.

I am informed that the current income tax lay provides that amounts paid by a taxpayer for the funeral expenses of deceased dependants, not exceeding $100 in respect of each deceased dependant, shall be treated as rebatable amounts.

For this purpose a dependant is defined to include the spouse of a taxpayer, a child of the taxpayer less than 21 years of age, or a person towards whose maintenance the taxpayer contributes during the year of income and is thereby entitled to a concessional rebate in respect of that person. This latter group would include an invalid relative, as that term is defined in the Income Tax Assessment Act, and the parents or parents-in-law of the taxpayer.

Unless the total of the rebatable amounts exceeds $1,590 a rebate of tax is not allowable. Where the total of the rebatable amounts exceeds $1,590 the rebexcess of the rebate amount over $1,590. Other rebatable amounts include medical, hospital and chemist expenses, education expenses, rates and land taxes and life assurance and superannuation contributions.
A pensioner who is not a taxpayer may qualify for funeral benefit as detailed above but would not be eligible for taxation concessions.

4. All dwellings nominally under my control, which have come from normal government stock, have been in the Australian Capital Territory under control of the Department of the Capital Territory. The numbers of these dwellings are:

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Government Housing, Canberra

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence the following question, upon notice, on 3 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are 20 Government houses vacant in Miller Street, O'Connor, Australian Capital Territory.
(2) If so, how long have these houses been vacant.

(3) Will these houses be made available to the general Government housing pool to alleviate the long delays of up to 18 months currently experienced by the 1,889 persons on the waiting list; if not why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There are 14 Defence houses vacant in Miller Street, O'Connor, Australian Capital Territory.
(2) Since 1978, they have been vacant for periods ranging from seven to 40 months.

(3) Most of the Defence houses in O'Connor have been vacant because their general standard has fallen below that approved for Service personnel. In view of civilian housing needs in the area, a study was undertaken to determine if these houses could be released or brought up to Defence standards.

As the houses are structurally sound and well located for use by Defence Force personnel, it was decided that they should be upgraded. A program of full internal upgrading and other improvements has been authorised. On completion of these works later this year, the houses will be occupied by Service families.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Reviews of Defence Science and Technology Organisation

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 9 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did he commission external and internal reviews of the Defence Science and Technology (DST) Organisation for the Government approximately 3 months ago; if so, has he received the results of the reviews.
(2) Did he undertake to table the reviews and the Government's response to them for discussion by the Parliament and interested parties.
(3) Did his Department inform staff organisations on 8 May 1981 that the reviews would be tabled before the end of the autumn period of sittings.

(4) Do the reviews comment very favourably on the efficiency and detailed research being undertaken by the DST Organisation and that this view is contrary to the Government's overriding intention to cut defence staff and research facilities without consideration for the long term defence needs of Australia; if so, is this the reason for the Government's refusal to table the reviews.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I announced the Reviews referred to by the honourable member on 13 November 1979. They were conducted in 1980 and the Reports were received in November 1980.

(2) It was my intention to table the Reports during the Autumn period of sittings. However some of the recommendations of the Reports come within the terms of reference of the recently announced Defence Review. The Government decided therefore to refer the Reports to the Defence Review. That body has now identified a number of recommendations it wishes to consider. Rather than delay action on the remaining recommendations I have therefore released the reports and the Government's response to those recommendations not being considered by the Defence Review. I tabled the reports on 19 August 1981.

(3) My Department did not indicate the Reports would be tabled but stated that it was expected that this would be the case. Subsequently the Government decided to refer the Report to the Defence Review.

(4) The reviews make a number of comments on the efficiency and detailed research being undertaken by DSTO. Some are favourable, some critical. They identified deficiencies in the organisation, management administration and operations of the DSTO which the Government is anxious to see remedied. The honourable member can be assured that the Government has no intention of taking any action with regard to the DSTO without the long term defence needs of Australia well in mind. It is in this spirit that we have responded to the recommendations of both reviews.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Social Security: Disclosure of Information

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister, representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 9 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Social Security Act prevent the disclosure of information such as the address of a social security beneficiary to the beneficiary's parents, next of kin, or State or Federal police even in those cases where the beneficiary is between 16 and 18 years old and listed as a missing person.
(2) If so, will the Minister consider raising the age limit whereby information concerning the whereabouts of social security beneficiaries is given to the beneficiaries' parents or legal guardians.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Social Services Act prohibits the disclosure of any information with respect to the affairs of another person which has been acquired in the performance of duties or functions under the Act. These provisions apply regardless of the age of the person concerned.

Information may, however, be disclosed to third parties where the person to whom the information relates has expressly or impliedly authorised such disclosure or where the Minister for Social Security or the Director-General of Social Services certifies that it is in the public interest to disclose the information.
(2) The existing confidentiality provisions of the Act are necessary to protect the privacy of clients of the Department, while permitting access to information in situations mentioned above.

Where a person or authority is anxious to get in touch with a client of the Department of Social Security, the Department has a procedure under which it will forward on correspondence to the client or will advise him of the name and address of the person who wishes to contact him.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Estimates of Total Transportation Costs

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morris Mr P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 10 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: What are the most recent estimates that can be provided of the total transportation costs, from origin to overseas port, disaggregated by (a) mode, (b) service, (c) stage of production and (d) cost and as a percentage of the total cost of the product before unloading at an overseas port for (i) coal, (ii) bauxite, (iii) alumina, (iv) aluminium ingots, (v) iron ore, (vi) bulk grain, (vii) containerised wool and (viii) general containerised cargo in (A) full container loads and (B) less than container loads.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The question is a complex and wide-ranging one, requiring details of transport costs at each stage of production for a range of unspecified origins and destinations in respect of eight commodities. Against the background that much of the information sought is confidential to the organisations concerned, I do not believe that the employment of staff resources to undertake the considerable research needed to provide a detailed answer would be justified.

As the honourable member would be aware, most bulk commodities are transported on both land and sea at contract rates, details of which are not released by the organisations concerned. Consequently, the 'book' rates published by the various Australian rail systems do not reflect the actual rates charged for these traffics. Likewise, in respect of shipping the spot rates published in trade journals do not provide an adequate guide to rates applicable to long-term trade arrangements made between exporters and shipping companies.
In addition, it should be noted that for some commodities, especially iron ore, mining companies or customers provide their own transport for the rail or sea freight task.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Import of Ivory Products

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Trade and Resources the following question, upon notice, on 10 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Do any restrictions apply to the import of ivory products into Australia; if so, what are the details?
(2) Has the Government raised in any international organisation of which Australia is a member, the question of restrictions on the slaughter of elephants; if so, to what effect?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Restrictions do apply to the import of ivory products into Australia. The restrictions are contained in the Customs (Endangered Species) Regulations which give effect to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora. The Convention, which took effect in Australia on 27 October, 1976 provides, inter alia, for regulation of the international trade in elephant ivory.

(2) At the third meeting of the Conference of the Parties to the Convention in New Delhi (February/March 1981) the Australian delegation assisted in drafting a resolution, subsequently adopted by the Conference, which recommended in summary:
(i) that any imports, exports or re-exports of African elephant ivory by a Party be authorised only if the Party is satisfied that the ivory was legally acquired in the country of origin.
(ii) that permits or certificates for raw ivory be accepted only if they mention the actual country of origin.
(iii) that Parties do not accept raw ivory which is not clearly marked.

(iv) that where possible Parties adopt domestic measures whereby importers, exporters or re-exporters of raw ivory would be subject to a licence to conduct such trade, unless such trade is only conducted by the Party itself.
